(7)  To permit any person to remain in or upon the licensed premises when such person does not have his or her buttocks, anus, breast and genitals covered with a nontransparent material. 
(8)  To permit the showing of film, still pictures, electronic reproduction or other visual reproductions depicting: 
a.  Acts or simulated acts of sexual intercourse, masturbation, sodomy, bestiality, oral copulation, flagellation, or any sexual acts which are prohibited by law. 
b.  Any person being touched, caressed or fondled on the breast, buttocks, anus or genitals. 
c.  Scenes wherein a person displays the vulva or the anus or the genitals. 
d.  Scenes wherein artificial devices or inanimate objects are employed to depict, or drawings are employed to portray, any of the prohibited activities described in this section. 
(Ord. No. 684, § 1, 8-20-12) 
Sec. 6-37. - Possession, consumption of alcoholic beverage on public lands-Prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to consume, carry, transport, or have in his possession any beverage containing alcohol in any amount upon the public sidewalks, streets, alleys, or other public lands in the city, unless such beverage is in an unopened, sealed container. 
(Ord. No. 684, § 1, 8-20-12) 
Sec. 6-38. - Same-Exceptions. 
    The provisions of section 6-37 do not apply to occasions and events conducted in public parks, and the provisions of section 6-37 may be waived from time to time by the city council, or its designated representative, for specific occasions and events conducted upon public rights-of-way or other public lands in the city. 
(Ord. No. 684, § 1, 8-20-12) 
Secs. 6-39-6-60. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - LICENSES 

Sec. 6-61. - License required. 
    No person may directly or indirectly, on any pretense or by any device, sell, barter, keep for sale, charge for possession, or otherwise dispose of alcoholic beverages as part of a commercial transaction without having obtained the required license or permit. Rental of or permission to use public facility is not a commercial transaction for the purpose of this article. Licenses shall be of two kinds: "on-sale" and "off-sale." 
(1)  On-sale liquor license. On-sale liquor licenses shall be issued only to hotels, clubs, restaurants bowling centers, theaters and establishments for the sale of liquors exclusively, and shall be granted to permit the sale of liquor by the glass or by the drink for consumption on the licensed premises only. 
(2)  Off-sale liquor license. Off-sale liquor licenses shall be issued only to drugstores and exclusive liquor stores, and shall be granted to permit the sale of liquor in the original package for consumption off of the licensed premises only. 
(3)  On-sale wine license. On-sale wine licenses shall be issued only to restaurants which meet the minimum requirements of M.S.A. § 340A.404. 
(4)  On-sale wine license, one-day. On-sale one-day wine licenses shall be issued only to non-profit groups and organizations upon such terms and conditions as may be approved from time to time by the city council. The terms and conditions set by the council may vary from those set forth in section 6-62 at the discretion of the council and as permitted by state law. 
(5)  On-sale brewer taproom license . A brewer licensed under M.S.A. § 340A.301, subd. 6(c), (i), or (j) may be issued an on-sale brewer taproom license, subject to the provisions of M.S.A. § 340A.26. 
(6)  On-sale brewpub license . A brewpub licensed under M.S.A. § 340A.301 may be issued an on-sale brewpub license in compliance with M.S.A. § 340A.24 subject to the following terms. An on-sale brewpub license may be issued only to restaurants operated at the place of manufacture and shall permit the sale of malt liquor produced on the licensed premises subject to the provisions of M.S.A. § 340A.24. A licensee cannot sell more than 3,500 barrels of the malt liquor produced on the licensed premises per year. A licensee may hold both an on-sale license and an on-sale brewpub license. 
(7)  Off-sale brewer license. A brewer with an on-sale brewer taproom or brewpub license may be issued an off-sale malt liquor brewer license which shall permit the off-sale of malt liquor produced on site and sold at the brewer's licensed premises subject to the provisions of M.S.A. § 340A.28 and 340A.285. 
(8)  On-sale cocktail room license. The holder of a microdistillery license under M.S.A. § 340A.22 may be issued a cocktail room license subject to the provisions therein. Such license authorizes the on-sale of distilled liquor produced by the distiller for consumption on the premises of or adjacent to one distillery location owned by the distiller. A distiller may have only one cocktail room license and may not have an ownership interest in a distillery licensed under M.S.A. § 340A.301 subd. 6, paragraph (a). No single entity may hold a cocktail room and taproom license and no such two licenses may be co-located. 
(9)  Off-sale microdistillery license. A microdistillery may be issued a license for off-sale of distilled spirits. The license may allow the sale of one 375 milliliter bottle per customer per day of product manufactured on-site subject to the terms of M.S.A. § 340A.22 subd. 4. 
(10)  On-sale license; Temporary. The city may issue a temporary license for the on-sale of intoxicating liquor in accordance with M.S.A. § 340A.404, subd. 10. 
(11)  On-sale license; Culinary classes . The city may issue a limited on-sale intoxicating liquor license to a business establishment if it meets the requirements of M.S.A. § 340A.4041. Such license fee shall be established annually by resolution of the city council. 
(12)  Off-sale licenses; Temporary wine auctions. The city may issue a temporary license for the off-sale of wine at an auction with the approval of the commissioner pursuant to M.S.A. § 340A.405, subd. 4. 
(Ord. No. 684, § 1, 8-20-12; Ord. No. 728, § 2, 5-16-16; Ord. No. 737, § 3, 6-19-17) 
Sec. 6-62. - Applications. 
(a)  Every person desiring a license for an off-sale or on-sale wine license shall file a verified application therefor in writing with the city administrator in the form prescribed by the state commissioner of public safety and with such additional information as the council may require. All applications shall be subject to the approval of the state commissioner of public safety. 
(b)  Every person desiring an on-sale liquor license shall file an application therefor in writing with the city administrator in the form prescribed by the city council. 
(c)  All applications for licenses under this article shall be accompanied by: 
(1)  A surety bond to be approved as to legal form by the city attorney and as to sufficiency by the council. In the case of an application for on-sale licenses, the penal sum of such bond shall be in the sum of $3,000.00. In the case of an application for off-sale license, the penal sum of such bond shall be in the amount of $2,000.00. All surety bonds shall be conditioned upon the following: 
a.  That the licensee will obey all laws relating to such license business. 
b.  That the licensee will pay to the city, when due, all taxes, license fees, penalties and other charges provided by law. 
c.  In the event of any violation of the provisions of any law relating to the licensed business, such bond shall be forfeited to the city. 
d.  The licensee will pay, to the extent of the principal amount of such bond, any damages for death or injury caused by or resulting from the violation of any provisions of law relating thereto, and in such cases recovery under this subsection (c)(1)d. may be had from the surety on its bond. 
(2)  Proof of financial responsibility with regard to liability imposed by M.S.A. § 340A.801, complying with all requirements of M.S.A. § 340A.301. If compliance with this requirement is furnished in the form of an insurance policy or pool providing minimum coverages, or bond, any such written proof shall include a provision that the insurer or surety may not cancel coverage without ten days' prior written notice to the city. 
(d)  The amount specified in any surety bond required by this section is declared to be a penalty, the amount recoverable to be measured by the actual damages; provided, however, that in no case shall such surety be liable for any amount in excess of the penal sum of the bond. The cancellation of a bond shall automatically revoke a license if a satisfactory bond is not substituted for the effective date of such cancellation. 
(e)  It shall be unlawful to make any false statement in any application for a license under this article. 
(f)  The area must be secured and have controlled access. Storage of alcoholic beverages is not allowed on the attached deck or patio. Upon receipt of an application, the city administrator shall be responsible for promptly processing the application, including conferring with department heads, city commissions, and the applicant as necessary to implement the provisions of this chapter, and, when required by this chapter, forwarding the processed application to the city council with a recommendation to approve, approve with conditions or modifications, or deny the application. 
(g)  Applications for the renewal of an existing license shall be made at least 60 days prior to the date of the expiration of the license and shall be made in such abbreviated form as the city clerk may approve. Proposed enlargement, alteration or extension of premises previously licensed shall be reported to the city clerk at or before the time application is made. If, in the judgment of the city clerk, good and sufficient cause is shown by the applicant for failure to file for a renewal within the time provided, the city council may, if the other provisions of this article are complied with, grant the application. Changes in the corporation articles or partnership agreement, as the case may be, shall be submitted to the city clerk within 30 days after such changes are made. In the case of a corporation, the licensee shall notify the city clerk when a person not listed in the application requires an interest in the corporation and shall give all information about the person as is required in an initial application. 
(Ord. No. 684, § 1, 8-20-12) 
Sec. 6-63. - Fees. 
    All applications for licenses shall be accompanied by a certified check payable to the city in an amount equal to the fee required by the provisions of chapter 42, together with such other fee or deposits as may be required by the provisions of section 6-64. Provided, however, that one-half of the applicable annual license fee for an on-sale intoxicating liquor license may be paid at the time of the application therefor; the remaining one-half of such license fee to be paid to the city administrator on or before July 1 of the license year. Failure to pay the remaining one-half of such license fee on or before July 1 of the license year shall automatically invalidate any such license for the last six months of the license year. All such fees shall be paid into the general fund of the city. Upon rejection of any application for a license, the administrator shall return the certified check and bond of the applicant to the applicant. 
(Ord. No. 684, § 1, 8-20-12) 
Sec. 6-64. - Investigation and fee. 
    On an initial application for an on-sale license and on any application for transfer of an on-sale license, and where the council deems it in the public interest in the event of an application for renewal of any on-sale license, the city shall conduct a background and financial investigation of the applicant as provided by M.S.A. § 340A.412. Applications shall be on a form prescribed by the state bureau of criminal apprehension, with such additional information as council may require. Investigation may be conducted by the council or conducted by the state bureau of criminal apprehension at the request of the council. The applicant shall pay the actual cost of the investigation, not to exceed $500.00, or if investigation outside the state is required, not to exceed $10,000.00. Payment of the maximum investigation fee must accompany the license application; any difference between such fee and the actual cost of the investigation shall be refunded to the applicant when the investigation is completed. 
(Ord. No. 684, § 1, 8-20-12) 
Sec. 6-65. - Granting of license. 
    After investigation of the applicant for a license under this article and approval of the required bond, the city council shall grant or refuse such license in its sole discretion; provided, that no off-sale license or on-sale wine license shall become effective until the application, together with the bond, will have been approved by the state commissioner of public safety. 
(Ord. No. 684, § 1, 8-20-12) 
Sec. 6-66. - Transfer. 
    No license under this article may be transferred to another person or place without council approval. Any transfer of stock of a corporate licensee is deemed a transfer of the license, and a transfer of such stock without council approval is grounds for revocation of the license. The council shall be informed of any change in the officers of a corporation holding a license. 
(Ord. No. 684, § 1, 8-20-12) 
Sec. 6-67. - Conditions of licenses. 
    All licenses granted under this article shall be subject to all applicable laws of the city and all of the state and federal laws and regulations, and in addition thereto shall be subject to the following: 
(1)  The licensee is responsible for the conduct of his place of business and the conditions of sobriety and order within it. The act of any employee of the licensee is deemed the act of the licensee as well, and the licensee shall be liable for all penalties provided by this Code and other laws, equally with all employees and the licensee. 
(2)  Every licensee shall allow any peace officer, building inspector, or other properly designated officer and employee of the city, to enter, inspect and search the premises of the licensee during business hours and for a reasonable period after closing time, without a warrant. 
(3)  No license shall be granted for operation on any premises on which taxes, assessments, or other financial claims of the city, county, or state are delinquent or unpaid. 
(4)  No on-sale licensee shall sell liquor by the bottle or container for removal from the licensed premises; no off-sale licensee shall permit the consumption of any liquor on the licensed premises. 
(5)  No license shall be granted to an underaged person. 
(6)  No licensee shall keep, possess, or operate or permit the keeping, possession or operation of, on the licensed premises, or in any room adjoining the licensed premises controlled by him, any gambling device, unless a permit therefor shall have been issued by the city council. 
(Ord. No. 684, § 1, 8-20-12) 
Sec. 6-68. - Hours and days of sale. 
    The hours of operation and days of sale shall be those set by M.S.A. § 340A.504, as it may be amended from time to time except that the city council, may, by ordinance, provide for more restrictive days or hours than state law allows. 
(Ord. No. 684, § 1, 8-20-12; Ord. No. 728, § 3, 5-16-16; Ord. No. 737, § 4, 6-19-17) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 737, § 4, adopted June 19, 2017, amended § 6-68 title to read as herein set out. The former § 6-68 title pertained to hours of sale. 
Sec. 6-69. - Sunday sales, when permitted. 
(a)  All applicable sections of this chapter shall apply to any license granted under this article, unless any such section thereof shall be specifically modified or amended by this section. 
(b)  Any person holding an on-sale or off-sale brewer license may apply for a special on-sale license for the sale of intoxicating liquor on Sundays. Applications for such special license shall be in such form and shall require such information as the council shall determine. 
(c)  All applications for special Sunday licenses shall be accompanied by a certified check payable to the city in the amount of the license fee set forth in chapter 42. All fees shall be paid into the general funds of the city, and upon rejection of any application for a special license, the city administrator shall return the certified check of such applicant to the applicant. 
(d)  The holder of an on-sale intoxicating liquor license may be granted a Sunday on-sale license in accordance with M.S.A. § 340A.504 subdivision 3 for the hours specified in section 6-68 of this Code. 
(e)  The holder of an off-sale brewer license under section 6-61(7) of this Code may be granted a Sunday off-sale license in accordance with M.S.A. §§ 340A.28 and 340A.285. Sunday off-sale may only occur during the hours specified in section 6-68 of this Code. 
(f)  Except as specifically modified in this section, M.S.A. § 340A.504 is hereby adopted and made a part of this Code by reference thereto. 
(Ord. No. 684, § 1, 8-20-12; Ord. No. 728, § 4, 5-16-16; Ord. No. 737, § 5, 6-19-17) 
Sec. 6-70. - Revocation, suspension, and civil penalties. 
    Upon a finding that a licensee has sold alcoholic beverages to another retail licensee for the purpose of resale, purchased alcoholic beverages from another retail licensee for the purpose of resale, conducted or permitted the conduct of gambling on the licensed premises in violation of the law, failed to remove or dispose of alcoholic beverages when ordered by the commissioner of public safety to do so under M.S.A. § 340A.508, subdivision 3 or failed to comply with any applicable statute, rule, or ordinance relating to alcoholic beverages, the council may revoke the license, suspend the license for up to 60 days, impose a civil penalty of up to $2,000.00 for each violation, or impose any combination of these sanctions. No suspension or revocation may take effect until the licensee has been given an opportunity for a hearing under sections 14.57 to 14.69 of the Minnesota Administrative Procedure Act. This section does not require such hearing to be conducted before an employee of the office of administrative hearings. 
(Ord. No. 684, § 1, 8-20-12) 
Secs. 6-71-6-100. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - 3.2 PERCENT MALT LIQUOR 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 6-101. - Statutory provisions adopted. 
    Except where otherwise specifically provided in this article, the provisions of M.S.A. ch. 340A, relating to the definition of terms, licensing, consumption, sales, conditions of bonds of licensees, and all other matters pertaining to the retail sale, distribution, and consumption of 3.2 percent malt liquor, are adopted and made a part of this Code as if fully set out in this section. 
(Ord. No. 684, § 1, 8-20-12) 
Sec. 6-102. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Licensed premises is the premises described in the approved license application subject to the provisions of M.S.A. § 340A.410, subdivision 7. 
(Ord. No. 684, § 1, 8-20-12) 
Sec. 6-103. - Consumption, when prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to consume 3.2 percent malt liquor on the licensed premises of any on-sale licensee, except during the hours when sales are permitted under the provisions of section 6-137, and it shall be unlawful for any licensee, his agents, servants and employees, to permit the consumption of 3.2 percent malt liquor on the licensed premises occupied by such licensee, except during the hours when sales are permitted under the provisions of section 6-137. 
(Ord. No. 684, § 1, 8-20-12) 
Sec. 6-104. - Loitering, when prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person, except the licensee, his agents, servants and employees, to loiter on the licensed premises occupied by a licensee for the sale of 3.2 percent malt liquor, and it shall be unlawful for any licensee, his agents, servants and employees to permit any person, other than the licensee, his agents, servants and employees, to loiter on the licensed premises occupied by any licensee for the sale of 3.2 percent malt liquor between the following hours: 
(1)  Between 2:15 a.m. and 8:00 a.m. on any weekday, Monday through Saturday, inclusive, for those licensees holding a 2:00 a.m. permit in accordance with M.S.A. § 340A.504, subdivision 7; 
(2)  Between 1:15 a.m. and 8:00 a.m. on the days of Monday through Saturday for those licensees who do not possess a 2:00 a.m. permit in accordance with M.S.A. § 340A.504, subdivision 7; 
(3)  Between 2:15 a.m. and 12:00 noon on any Sunday. 
(Ord. No. 684, § 1, 8-20-12; Ord. No. 728, § 5, 5-16-16) 
Sec. 6-105. - Vacating licensed premises after closing hour. 
    It is the intent of the city council, by enactment of this article, to prohibit the sale of 3.2 percent malt liquor between the hours set forth in section 6-137, and it is the further intent of the city council by enactment of this article to allow the licensee 15 minutes after the closing hour within which to vacate the licensed premises occupied by such licensee for the sale of 3.2 percent malt liquor of all customers and patrons. Every licensee licensed to sell on-sale 3.2 percent malt liquor shall display, at all times, in the licensed premises a sign of such size and placed in such a position as to be clearly visible to all patrons, reading substantially as follows: 
The laws of St. Paul Park prohibit the sale of 3.2 percent malt liquor after 2:00 a.m. and require that all persons be out of this establishment by 2:15 a.m. 
Licensees who have not obtained a special 2:00 a.m. license from Minnesota Alcohol and Gambling Enforcement Division to substantially read as follows: 
The laws of St. Paul Park prohibit the sale of 3.2 percent malt liquor after 1:00 a.m. and require that all persons be out of this establishment by 1:15 a.m. 
(Ord. No. 684, § 1, 8-20-12) 
Sec. 6-106. - Restrictions on consumption. 
(a)  Every licensee under this article shall be responsible for the conduct of his place of business and for conditions of sobriety and order therein. 
(b)  No person may directly or indirectly, on any pretence or by any devise, sell, barter, keep for sale, or otherwise dispose of 3.2 percent malt liquor as part of a commercial transaction without having obtained a licensed issued by city council, and then only during the hours in which sales of 3.2 percent malt liquor liquors are permitted pursuance to the provisions of this Code. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for any licensee to sell or for any person to consume 3.2 percent malt liquor, at any time upon the licensed premises, except for the premises described in the approved license application in which the licensee dispenses and sells 3.2 percent malt liquor, and then only during the hours in which sales of 3.2 percent malt liquor are permitted pursuant to the provisions of this Code. The licensee shall post and maintain in a conspicuous place within the licensed premises at the exits clearly visible to customers: one sign 141/2 inches wide by eight inches high, which states no alcoholic beverages are allowed beyond this point. 
(Ord. No. 684, § 1, 8-20-12) 
Sec. 6-107. - Underaged persons. 
(a)  The provisions of M.S.A. § 340A.503 are hereby adopted and incorporated in and made a part of this Code as completely as if set out in full in this section. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any licensee or any of his employees to permit any underaged person to loiter or to remain in a room where 3.2 percent malt liquor is being sold or served unless accompanied by his parent or legal guardian; and it shall be unlawful for an underaged person to loiter or to remain in a room where 3.2 percent malt liquor is being sold or served unless accompanied by his parent or legal guardian. 
(Ord. No. 684, § 1, 8-20-12) 
Sec. 6-108. - Conduct on licensed premises. 
    The city council ordains that it is in the best interest of the public health, safety and general welfare of the people of the city that certain types of activities, as set forth in this section, are prohibited upon the premises of licensed liquor, wine, and beer establishments so as to best protect and assist the owners, operators and employees of these premises, as well as patrons and the public in general. Further, the city council ordains that the standards in this section reflect the prevailing community standards in the city. This section is intended to prevent harm stemming from the physical immediacy and combination of alcohol, nudity, and sex. The city council also desires to prevent any subliminal endorsement of sexual harassment or activities likely to lead to the possibility of various types of criminal conduct such as prostitution, sexual assault, and disorderly conduct. The following conduct or acts are prohibited: 
(1)  To employ or use any person in the sale or service of alcoholic beverages in or upon the licensed premises while such person is unclothed or in such attire, costume or clothing as to expose to view any portion of the female breast below the top of the areola or of any portion of the pubic hair, anus, cleft of buttocks, vulva or genitals. 
(2)  To employ or use the services of any hostess or other person to mingle with the patrons while such hostess or other person is unclothed or in such attire, costume or clothing as described in subsection (1) of this section. 
(3)  To encourage or permit any person on the licensed premises to touch, caress or fondle the breasts, buttocks, anus or genitals of any other person. 
(4)  To permit any employee or person to wear or use any device or covering exposed to view, which simulates the breast, genitals, anus, pubic hair or any portion thereof. 
(5)  To permit any person to perform acts of or acts which simulate: 
a.  Sexual intercourse, masturbation, sodomy, bestiality, oral copulation, flagellation or any sexual acts which are prohibited by law. 
b.  The touching, caressing or fondling of the breast, buttocks, anus or genitals. 
c.  The displaying of the pubic hair, anus, vulva or genitals. 
(6)  To permit any person to use artificial devices or inanimate objects to depict any of the prohibited activities described in this section. 
(7)  To permit any person to remain in or upon the licensed premises who exposes to public view any portion of his genitals or anus. 
(8)  To permit the showing of film, still pictures, electronic reproductions or other visual reproductions depicting: 
a.  Acts or simulated acts of sexual intercourse, masturbation, sodomy, bestiality, oral copulation, flagellation, or any sexual acts which are prohibited by law. 
b.  Any person being touched, caressed or fondled on the breast, buttocks, anus or genitals. 
c.  Scenes wherein a person displays the vulva or the anus or the genitals. 
d.  Scenes wherein artificial devices or inanimate objects are employed to depict, or drawings are employed to portray, any of the prohibited activities described in this section. 
(Ord. No. 684, § 1, 8-20-12) 
Sec. 6-109. - Possession, consumption of alcoholic beverages on public lands-Prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to consume, carry, transport, or have in possession any beverage containing alcohol in any amount upon the public sidewalks, streets, alleys, or other public lands in the city, unless such beverage is in an unopened, sealed container. 
(Ord. No. 684, § 1, 8-20-12) 
Sec. 6-110. - Same-Exceptions. 
    The provisions of section 6-109 do not apply to occasions and events conducted in public parks, and the provisions of section 6-109 may be waived from time to time by the city council, or its designated representative, for specific occasions and events conducted upon public rights-of-way or other public lands in the city. 
(Ord. No. 684, § 1, 8-20-12) 
Secs. 6-111-6-130. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - LICENSES GENERALLY 

Sec. 6-131. - License required. 
    No person shall, directly or indirectly, upon any pretense or by any device, manufacture, import, sell, exchange, barter, dispose of or keep for sale any 3.2 percent malt liquor without first having obtained a license therefor as provided in this division. Licenses shall be of two kinds: On-sale and off-sale. 
(1)  On-sale license. On-sale licenses shall be issued only for the sale of 3.2 percent malt liquor to be consumed on the licensed premises. 
(2)  Off-sale license. Off-sale licenses shall be issued only to permit the sale of 3.2 percent malt liquor for consumption off of the licensed premises only. 
(3)  On-sale license, one-day. On-sale one-day licenses shall be issued only for the sale of 3.2 percent malt liquor to be consumed on the licensed premises to non-profit groups and organizations upon such terms and conditions as may be approved from time to time by the city council. The terms and conditions set by the council may vary from those set forth in section 6-132 at the discretion of the council and as permitted by state law. 
(Ord. No. 684, § 1, 8-20-12) 
Sec. 6-132. - Applications. 
(a)  All applications for any license to sell 3.2 percent malt liquor shall be made on forms to be supplied by the city, setting forth the name of the person asking for such license, his age, representations as to his character with such references as may be required, his citizenship, the location where such business is to be carried on, whether such application is for on-sales or off-sales, the business in connection with which the proposed license will operate, whether the applicant is the owner and operator of such business, the time such applicant has been in that business at that place, and such other information as the council may require from time to time. It shall be unlawful to make any false statement in an application. 
(b)  All applications for a license under this division shall be accompanied by proof of financial responsibility with regard to liability imposed by M.S.A. § 340A.801, complying with all requirements of M.S.A. § 340A.409. If compliance with this requirement is furnished in the form of an insurance policy or pool providing minimum coverages, or bond, any such written proof shall include a provision that the insurer or surety may not cancel coverage without ten days' prior written notice to the city. Proof of financial responsibility as required in this section shall be submitted by all applicants regardless of the amount of their annual sales of 3.2 percent malt liquor. 
(c)  The area must be secured and have controlled access. Storage of beverages is not allowed on the attached deck or patio. Upon receipt of an application, the city administrator shall be responsible for promptly processing the application, including conferring with department heads, city commissions, and the applicant as necessary to implement the provisions of this chapter, and, when required by this chapter, forwarding the processed application to the city council with a recommendation to approve, approve with conditions or modifications, or deny the application. 
(d)  Applications for the renewal of an existing license shall be made at least 60 days prior to the date of the expiration of the license and shall be made in such abbreviated form as the city clerk may approve. Proposed enlargement, alteration or extension of premises previously licensed shall be reported to the city clerk at or before the time application is made. If, in the judgment of the city clerk, good and sufficient cause is shown by the applicant for failure to file for a renewal within the time provided, the city council may, if the other provisions of this article are complied with, grant the application. Changes in the corporation articles or partnership agreement, as the case may be, shall be submitted to the city clerk within 30 days after such changes are made. In the case of a corporation, the licensee shall notify the city clerk when a person not listed in the application requires an interest in the corporation and shall give all information about the person as is required in an initial application. 
(Ord. No. 684, § 1, 8-20-12) 
Sec. 6-133. - Fees. 
    All applications for licenses under this division shall be accompanied by a certified check payable to the city in an amount equal to the fee required by the provisions of chapter 42. All such fees shall be paid into the general fund of the city. Upon rejection of any application for a license, the city administrator shall return the certified check of the applicant to the applicant. 
(Ord. No. 684, § 1, 8-20-12) 
Sec. 6-134. - Granting of license. 
    After investigation of the applicant for a license under this division and approval of the required bond, the city council shall grant or refuse such license in its sole discretion. 
(Ord. No. 684, § 1, 8-20-12) 
Sec. 6-135. - Transfers. 
    No license granted under this division may be transferred to another person or place without council approval. Any transfer of stock of a corporate licensee is deemed a transfer of the license, and a transfer of such stock without council approval is grounds for revocation of the license. The council shall be informed of any change in the officers of a corporation holding a license. 
(Ord. No. 684, § 1, 8-20-12) 
Sec. 6-136. - Conditions of license. 
    All licenses granted under this division shall be subject to all applicable laws of the city and all of the state and federal laws and regulations, and in addition thereto shall be subject to the following: 
(1)  The licensee is responsible for the conduct of his place of business and the conditions of sobriety and order within it. The act of any employee of the licensee is deemed the act of the licensee as well, and the licensee shall be liable for all penalties provided by this Code and other laws, equally with all employees and the licensee. 
(2)  Every licensee shall allow any peace officer, health officer, or other properly designated officer and employee of the city to enter, inspect and search the premises of the licensee during business hours and for a reasonable period after closing time, without a warrant. 
(3)  No license shall be granted for operation on any premises on which taxes, assessments, or other financial claims of the city, county, or state are delinquent or unpaid. 
(4)  No on-sale licensee shall sell liquor by the bottle or container for removal from the licensed premises; no off-sale licensee shall permit the consumption of any liquor on the licensed premises. 
(5)  No license shall be granted to an underaged person. 
(6)  No licensee shall keep, possess, or operate or permit the keeping, possession or operation of, on the licensed premises, or in any room adjoining the licensed premises controlled by him, any gambling device, unless a permit therefor shall have been issued by the city council. 
(Ord. No. 684, § 1, 8-20-12) 
Sec. 6-137. - Hours and days of sale. 
    The hours of operation and days of sale shall be those set by M.S.A. § 340A.504, as it may be amended from time to time except that the city council, may, by ordinance, provide for more restrictive hours than state law allows. 
(Ord. No. 684, § 1, 8-20-12; Ord. No. 737, § 6, 6-19-17) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 737, § 6, adopted June 19, 2017, amended § 6-137 title to read as herein set out. The former § 6-137 title pertained to hours of sale. 
Sec. 6-138. - Revocation, suspension, and civil penalties. 
    Upon a finding that a licensee has sold alcoholic beverages to another retail licensee for the purpose of resale, purchased alcoholic beverages from another retail licensee for the purpose of resale, conducted or permitted the conduct of gambling on the licensed premises in violation of the law, failed to remove or dispose of alcoholic beverages when ordered by the commissioner of public safety to do so under M.S.A. § 340A.508, subdivision 3 or failed to comply with any applicable statute, rule, or ordinance relating to alcoholic beverages, the council may revoke the license, suspend the license for up to 60 days, impose a civil penalty of up to $2,000.00 for each violation, or impose any combination of these sanctions. No suspension or revocation may take effect until the licensee has been given an opportunity for a hearing under sections 14.57 to 14.69 of the Minnesota Administrative Procedure Act. This section does not require such hearing to be conducted before an employee of the office of administrative hearings. 
(Ord. No. 684, § 1, 8-20-12) 
Secs. 6-139-6-160. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - LICENSES FOR THE SALE OF NONINTOXICATING LIQUIDS FOR MIXING WITH INTOXICATING LIQUOR 

Sec. 6-161. - Statutory provisions adopted. 
    Except where otherwise specifically provided in this division, the provisions of M.S.A. ch. 340A relating to the definition of terms, licensing, consumption, sales, conditions of bonds of licensees, and all other matters pertaining to the retail sale, distribution, and consumption of nonintoxicating liquids for the purpose of mixing with intoxicating liquor, are adopted and made a part of this Code as if fully set out in this section. 
(Ord. No. 684, § 1, 8-20-12) 
Sec. 6-162. - License required. 
    No person shall, directly or indirectly, upon any pretense or by any device, sell, exchange, barter or dispose of any nonintoxicating liquid for the purpose of mixing with intoxicating liquor on the premises, without first having obtained a license therefor as provided in this division. 
(Ord. No. 684, § 1, 8-20-12) 
Sec. 6-163. - Applications. 
(a)  Every person desiring a license for the sale of nonintoxicating liquids for the purpose of mixing with intoxicating liquors shall file a verified application therefor in writing with the city administrator in the form prescribed by the city council. 
(b)  If the applicant for a license under this division is not the holder of a duly issued license for the sale of on-sale intoxicating liquor, then in such event, the application shall be accompanied by a copy of the permit issued to such applicant by the state commissioner of public safety authorizing the sales permitted under this division, pursuant to the provisions of M.S.A. § 340A.504. 
(Ord. No. 684, § 1, 8-20-12) 
Sec. 6-164. - Fees. 
    All applications for licenses under this division shall be accompanied by certified check payable to the city in the amount of the fee as set forth in chapter 42 and all such fees shall be paid into the general fund of the city. Upon rejection of any application for license, the city administrator shall return the certified check to the applicant. 
(Ord. No. 684, § 1, 8-20-12) 
Sec. 6-165. - Granting of license; posting; transfer. 
    The city council shall cause an investigation to be made of all representations set forth in the application for a license under this division and shall, if requested by the applicant or any other person, hold a hearing to consider the granting of such license. After such investigation, and hearing, if requested, the city council shall grant or refuse such license in its discretion. All licensed premises shall have the licenses posted in a conspicuous place therein at all times. No license shall be transferable either as to the licensee or the premises without the prior approval of the council. 
(Ord. No. 684, § 1, 8-20-12) 
Sec. 6-166. - Conditions of license. 
(a)  All licenses granted under this division shall be granted subject to all restrictions of this chapter and subject to all other codes of the city and the laws of the state applicable thereto. 
(b)  Every licensee under this division shall be responsible for the conduct at his place of business and the conditions of sobriety and order therein. No sales under the terms of this division shall be made to any underaged person, and no underaged person shall be employed in any room constituting the place in which sales permitted under this division are made. 
(c)  No license under this division shall be issued to any person not a citizen of the United States or to any person not of good moral character and repute nor to any person who shall be convicted of any willful violation of any law of the United States, the state or the city with regard to the manufacture, sale, distribution, or possession for sale or distribution of intoxicating liquor, nor to any person whose license under this chapter shall be revoked for any willful violation of any such laws or codes. 
(d)  No license under this division shall be granted for operation on any premises upon which taxes or assessments or other financial claims of the city are delinquent and unpaid. 
(Ord. No. 684, § 1, 8-20-12) 
Sec. 6-167. - Hours of operation. 
(a)  Sales shall be made pursuant to a license granted under this division only during hours when on-sales of intoxicating liquor are permitted pursuant to section 6-137. 
(b)  No sales shall be made by any licensee under this division, who is also the holder of a duly issued on-sale intoxicating liquor license, at any time during which sales of intoxicating liquor are permitted by such licensee. 
(Ord. No. 684, § 1, 8-20-12) 
Sec. 6-168. - Revocation, suspension, and civil penalties. 
    Upon a finding that a licensee has sold alcoholic beverages to another retail licensee for the purpose of resale, purchased alcoholic beverages from another retail licensee for the purpose of resale, conducted or permitted the conduct of gambling on the licensed premises in violation of the law, failed to remove or dispose of alcoholic beverages when ordered by the commissioner of public safety to do so under M.S.A. § 340A.508, subdivision 3 or failed to comply with any applicable statute, rule, or ordinance relating to alcoholic beverages, the council may revoke the license, suspend the license for up to 60 days, impose a civil penalty of up to $2,000.00 for each violation, or impose any combination of these sanctions. No suspension or revocation may take effect until the licensee has been given an opportunity for a hearing under sections 14.57 to 14.69 of the Minnesota Administrative Procedure Act. This section does not require such hearing to be conducted before an employee of the office of administrative hearings. 
(Ord. No. 684, § 1, 8-20-12) 
Chapter 7 - SOCIAL HOST 

Sec. 7-1. - Purpose and findings. 
    The city council intends to discourage underage possession and consumption of alcohol, even if done within the confines of a private residence, and intends to hold persons criminally responsible who host events or gatherings where persons under 21 years of age possess or consume alcohol regardless of whether the person hosting the event or gathering supplied the alcohol. The city council finds that: 
(a)  Events and gatherings held on private or public property where alcohol is possessed or consumed by persons under the age of 21 may be harmful to those persons and constitute a potential threat to public health. 
(b)  Prohibiting underage consumption protects underage persons, as well as the general public, from injuries related to alcohol consumption, such as alcohol overdose or alcohol-related traffic crashes. 
(c)  Alcohol is an addictive drug which, if used irresponsibly, could have adverse effects on those who use it as well as those who are affected by the actions of an irresponsible user. 
(d)  Often, events or gatherings involving underage possession and consumption occur outside the presence of parents. However, there are times when the parent(s) is/are present and, condone the activity, and in some circumstances provide the alcohol. 
(e)  Even though giving or furnishing alcohol to an underage person is a crime, this ordinance is necessary to help further combat underage consumption. 
(f)  A deterrent effect will be created by holding a person criminally responsible for hosting an event or gathering where underage possession or consumption occurs. 
(Ord. No. 685, § 1, 8-20-12) 
Sec. 7-2. - Authority. 
    This chapter is enacted pursuant to M.S.A. § 145A.05, subdivision 1. 
(Ord. No. 685, § 1, 8-20-12) 
Sec. 7-3. - Definitions. 
    For purposes of this chapter, the following terms have the following meanings: 
    Alcohol means ethyl alcohol, hydrated oxide of ethyl, or spirits of wine, whiskey, rum, brandy, gin, or any other distilled spirits including dilutions and mixtures thereof from whatever source or by whatever process produced. 
    Alcoholic beverage means alcohol, spirits, liquor, wine, beer, and every liquid or solid containing alcohol, spirits, liquor, wine, or beer, and which contains one-half of one percent or more of alcohol by volume and which is fit for beverage purposes either alone or when diluted, mixed, or combined with other substances. 
    Event or gathering means any group of three or more persons who have assembled or gathered together for a social occasion or other activity. 
    Host means to aid, conduct, allow, entertain, organize, supervise, control, or permit a gathering or event. 
    Parent means any person having legal custody of a juvenile: 
 As natural, adoptive parent, or step-parent; 
 As a legal guardian; or 
 As a person to whom legal custody has been given by order of the court. 
    Person means any individual, partnership, co-partnership, corporation, or any association of one or more individuals. 
    Residence or premises means any home, yard, farm, field, land, apartment, condominium, hotel or motel room, or other dwelling unit, or a hall or meeting room, park or any other place of assembly, public or private, whether occupied on a temporary or permanent basis, whether occupied as a dwelling or specifically for a party or other social function, and whether owned, leased, rented, or used with or without permission or compensation. 
    Underage person is any individual under 21 years of age. 
(Ord. No. 685, § 1, 8-20-12) 
Sec. 7-4. - Prohibited acts. 
(1)  It is unlawful for any person(s) to host or allow an event or gathering at any residence, premises, or any other private or public property where alcohol or alcoholic beverages are present when the person knows or reasonably should know that an underage person will or does consume or possess any alcohol or alcoholic beverage with the intent to consume it; and the person fails to take reasonable steps to prevent possession or consumption by the underage person(s). 
(a)  A person is criminally responsible for violating subsection (1) above if the person intentionally aids, advises, hires, counsels, or conspires with or otherwise procures another to commit the prohibited act. 
(b)  A person who hosts an event or gathering as described in subsection (1) above does not have to be present at the event or gathering to be criminally responsible. 
(Ord. No. 685, § 1, 8-20-12) 
Sec. 7-5. - Exceptions. 
(a)  This chapter does not apply to conduct solely between an underage person and his or her parents while present in the parent's household. 
(b)  This chapter does not apply to legally protected religious observances. 
(c)  This chapter does not apply to retail intoxicating liquor or 3.2 percent malt liquor licensees, municipal liquor stores, or bottle club permit holders who are regulated by M.S.A. § 340A.503, subdivision 1(a)(1). 
(d)  This chapter does not apply to situations where underage persons are lawfully in possession of alcohol or alcoholic beverages during the course and scope of their employment. 
(Ord. No. 685, § 1, 8-20-12) 
Sec. 7-6. - Enforcement. 
    This chapter can be enforced by any police officer or sheriff's deputy in the county. 
(Ord. No. 685, § 1, 8-20-12) 
Sec. 7-7. - Severability. 
    If any section, subsection, sentence, clause, phrase, word, or other portion of this chapter is, for any reason, held to be unconstitutional or invalid, in whole, or in part, by any court of competent jurisdiction, such portion shall be deemed severable, and such unconstitutionality or invalidity shall not affect the validity of the remaining portions of this law, which remaining portions shall continue in full force and effect. 
(Ord. No. 685, § 1, 8-20-12) 
Sec. 7-8. - Penalty. 
    Violation of section 7-4 is a misdemeanor. 
(Ord. No. 685, § 1, 8-20-12) 
Sec. 7-9. - Effective date. 
    This chapter shall take effect 30 days following its final passage and adoption. 
(Ord. No. 685, § 1, 8-20-12) 
Chapter 10 - ANIMALS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Authority to regulate the keeping of animals, M.S.A. § 412.221, subd. 21. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 10-1. - Definitions adopted. 
    Except otherwise specifically provided in this chapter, the provision of M.S.A. §§ 347.50-347.56 and as it may be amended from time to time, relating to the definition, dangerous dogs registration, dangerous dogs requirements, potentially dangerous dogs, confiscation, microchip identification, and penalty, are adopted and made a part of this chapter as if fully set out herein. 
(Ord. No. 637, § 1, 11-17-08) 
Sec. 10-2. - Authority to issue citations. 
    The duly appointed animal control officer of the city is authorized to issue a citation in lieu of arrest or continued detention for violation of any provision of this chapter. 
(Code 1982, § 14.03; Ord. No. 637, § 1, 11-17-08) 
Editor's note- Ordinance No. 637, § 1, adopted November 17, 2008, added § 10-1. Therefore, such ordinance renumbered 10-1 as 10-2. 
Sec. 10-3. - Keeping of pigeons. 
(a)  Intent and purpose. It is the purpose and intent of this section to permit the keeping, maintenance and flying of certain registered pigeons as a recreational sport and hobby, subject to regulations hereinafter set forth. The keeping, breeding, maintenance and flying of fancy, racing and sporting breeds of pigeons, as defined herein, is determined not to be a nuisance and is not detrimental to the public welfare, if regulated as hereafter set forth. It is recognized that the keeping, breeding, maintenance and flying of such pigeons is now mainly engaged in by members of local, district and national organizations, and such persons keep their pigeons in suitable permanent structures constructed and maintained for such purpose, and keep such structures in a clean and sanitary manner, and do not permit their pigeons to remain at large in the community in such manner as to disturb their neighbors or to prevent the full enjoyment of property rights by their neighbors. 
(b)  Definitions: 
(1)  Pigeon means a member of the family Columbidae, and shall include "racing pigeons", "fancy pigeons" and "sporting pigeons" as defined in this section. 
(2)  Racing pigeon means a pigeon which, through selective past breeding, has developed the distinctive physical and mental characteristics as to enable it to return to its home after having been released a considerable distance therefrom, and which is accepted as such by the American Racing Pigeon Union, Inc. or the International Federation of Racing Pigeon Fanciers. Also, commonly known as Racing Homer, Homing Pigeon, or Carrier Pigeon. 
(3)  Fancy pigeon means a pigeon which, through past breeding, has developed certain distinctive physical and performing characteristics as to be clearly identified and accepted as such by the National Pigeon Association, the American Pigeon Club or the Rare Breeds Pigeon Club. Examples: Fantails, Pouters, Trumpeters. 
(4)  Sporting pigeon means a pigeon which, through selective past breeding, has developed the ability to fly in a distinctive manner, such as aerial acrobatics or endurance flying. Examples: Rollers, Tipplers. 
(5)  Loft means the structure(s) for the keeping or housing of pigeons permitted by this section. 
(6)  Mature pigeon means a pigeon aged six months or older. 
(7)  Owner means the owner of pigeons subject to this section. 
(c)  Conditions. The keeping, breeding, maintenance and flying of pigeons may be permitted subject to the following: 
(1)  All premises on which pigeons are kept or maintained shall be kept reasonably clean from filth, garbage, and any substances which attract rodents. The loft and its surroundings must be cleaned daily. 
(2)  The loft must be constructed and maintained so as to be rodent-proof. 
(3)  All pigeons shall be fed within the confines of the loft on the premises on which the pigeons are housed. The pigeons shall be confined to the loft except when they are released for exercise, performance, training, or to return from areas outside the city limits for the purpose of engaging in a race or returning from training flights. 
(4)  All grains and food stored for the use of the pigeons on a licensed premise shall be kept in a rodent proof container. 
(5)  Pigeons shall not be kept in such a manner as to constitute a nuisance to the occupants of adjacent property. 
(6)  Pigeon lofts will be located in the rear yard only and shall be at least 50 feet from adjacent habitable structures. 
(7)  The loft will provide a minimum of one square foot of floor space per bird. 
(8)  No one shall release pigeons to fly for exercise, training or competition except owner(s) of pigeons who are member(s) in good standing of an organized pigeon club, such as the American Racing Pigeon Union, Inc., the International Federation of Racing Pigeon Fanciers, the National Pigeon Association, the American Tippler Society, the International Roller Association, the Rare Breeds Pigeon Club or a local club which has rules that will help preserve the peace and tranquility of the neighborhood. 
(9)  All pigeons shall be banded and registered with one of the local or national associations/registries. 
(d)  Application for license. Applicant shall complete an application form provided by the city. The application shall include, but not limited to the following information: a site plan showing the location and size of the premises and the location, size and type of all structures for the housing of pigeons, said structure/loft will comply with city zoning requirements, the maximum number of pigeons to be kept on the premises at one time, and an agreement by the applicant that the premises may be inspected by the city at all reasonable times so as to assure compliance with the conditions outlined in subparagraph (c) of this section. 
(1)  Duration of license; fee. 
a.  Each license issued hereunder shall expire on December 31 in the year of issuance unless sooner revoked. A license must be renewed annually to continue the keeping of pigeons. Not more than three licenses will be issued in a given year. 
b.  The annual fee for a permit shall be in such amount as set forth in chapter 42, which shall be paid at the time of the making of the application therefore. 
(2)  Number of animals. The permit shall state the number of pigeons which may be maintained on the premises. In no case shall the number of pigeons exceed 100 birds. The permittee shall immediately inform the city in writing when the number of animals maintained on the premises exceeds the number allowed by the permit so long as the number does not exceed 100. The permit may be denied or revoked if the city objects to the proposed number of pigeons. 
(3)  Size of structure/loft. The size of the structure shall follow the city's accessory structure ordinance. 
(e)  Right of entry for inspection. The animal control officer may enter and inspect any property or loft at any reasonable time for the purpose of investigating either an actual or suspected violation or to ascertain compliance or noncompliance with this section. 
(f)  Violation and penalties. When the animal control officer finds a violation to have occurred, the officer shall give written notice thereof to the owner. If said violation is not remedied within ten days, the animal control officer may issue a citation to appear in district court to answer the charges stated thereon. Any owner found violating any of the provisions of this section shall upon conviction be guilty of a misdemeanor punishable by a fine. Any conviction shall result in the revocation of the permit by the city council. 
(Ord. No. 641, § 1, 3-16-09) 
Sec. 10-4. - Keeping of animals other than dogs. 
    No horse, mule, donkey, pony, cow, goat, swine, sheep or animal raised for fur-bearing purposes shall be kept within the city limits. 
(Code 1982, § 14.020; Ord. No. 637, § 1, 11-17-08) 
Editor's note- Ordinance No. 637, § 1, adopted November 17, 2008, added § 10-1. Therefore, such ordinance renumbered § 10-2 as § 10-3 and repealed existing § 10-3 which pertained to stables and derived from § 14.021 of the 1982 Code. Subsequently, Ord. No. 641, § 1, adopted March 16, 2009, added § 10-3. Therefore, this section was renumbered as § 10-4. 
Sec. 10-5. - Chicken coops, kennels and pens. 
(a)  No chicken coop, dove cote, dog kennel, rabbit warren, honeybee hive, or other ward or establishment where small animals or fowls are kept shall be maintained closer than 300 feet to any apartment building, hotel, restaurant, boardinghouse, retail food store, building used for school, religious or hospital purposes, or residence other than that occupied by the owner or occupant of the premises upon which such creatures are kept. 
(b)  Not more than three dogs, cats, rabbits, guinea pigs, ducks, geese or turkeys more than four months old, nor one of any such animals for each 2 1/2 square feet of chicken yard space, shall be kept on any premises within the city limits, except in an outlying district where there are not more than three residences other than that occupied by the owner or occupant of the premises upon which such creatures are kept, within a radius of 100 feet of the structure or area enclosing such creatures, without a special written permit issued by the city after an inspection of the premises and a finding of fact to the effect that no nuisance will be created thereby. 
(Code 1982, § 14.022; Ord. No. 637, § 1, 11-17-08; Ord. No. 694, § 2, 4-1-13) 
Sec. 10-6. - Maintenance of structures. 
    All structures, pens, coops, or yards therein where animals or fowl are kept or permitted to be shall be maintained in a clean and sanitary condition, devoid of all rodents and vermin and free from objectionable odors. The interior walls, ceilings, floors, partitions and appurtenances of all such structures shall be whitewashed or painted annually or more often as the city shall direct. The city, upon the complaint of any individual, shall inspect any such structure or premises and issue any such order as may be necessary to carry out the provisions of this chapter. 
(Code 1982, § 14.023) 
Sec. 10-7. - Animals not to roam at large. 
    No persons shall suffer or permit any horse, mule, donkey, pony, cattle, sheep, goat, swine, rabbit, chicken, geese, duck, or turkey of which he is the owner, caretaker, or custodian to be at large within the city. Any such creature shall be deemed to be at large when it shall be off the premises owned or rented by its owner and unaccompanied by the owner or an agent or employee of the owner. 
(Code 1982, § 14.024) 
Sec. 10-8. - Disposal of manure. 
    No manure shall be dumped or left on any street, alley, sidewalk or any open area or lot in any inhabited portion of the city. Neither shall any manure be used to grade in whole or in part any sidewalk, street, open area or lot in such area, unless such manure is completely covered with at least four inches of dirt. 
(Code 1982, § 14.025) 
Sec. 10-9. - Cruelty to animals. 
(a)  Unlawful acts. It shall be unlawful for any person to do any of the following: 
(1)  Intentionally overwork, torture, cruelly treat, kill or injure any animal or bird; 
(2)  Fail without reasonable excuse to provide necessary water, food, care or shelter for any animal or bird in his custody; 
(3)  Intentionally and without the owner's consent poison any domestic animal or bird of another or place poison in any place with intent that it be taken by a domestic animal or bird of another; 
(4)  Intentionally transport or confine any animal in overcrowded conditions or other cruel manner; 
(5)  Intentionally bait an animal or bird or cause or allow one animal or bird to fight with another; or train animals or birds for such fighting; or permit premises under his control to be used for such purposes; or 
(6)  Abandon an animal or bird in his possession under circumstances which he knows or reasonably should know will expose it to suffering. 
(b)  Exceptions. The provisions of subsection (a) of this section do not prohibit qualified experiments carried on for scientific research or acts in the course of veterinary practice. 
(Code 1982, § 23.03) 
Sec. 10-10. - Limited keeping of chickens. 
(a)  Intent and purpose. It is the intent and purpose of this section to set standards for the limited keeping of chickens in urban settings as a noncommercial hobby independent of the requirements found in section 10-5. 
(b)  Conditions. The limited keeping of chickens may be permitted as an accessory use to a legally established single family residence subject to the following: 
(1)  The property shall be occupied with a single-family home. The owner of the chickens shall live in the dwelling on the property and the property owner is in receipt of a license as required by this section. 
(2)  No person shall keep more than four total hen chickens. 
(3)  No person shall keep roosters or adult male chickens. 
(4)  Chickens shall be kept within a separate enclosed accessory building and/or fenced outdoor containment area subject to the following: 
a.  The accessory building shall be less than 120 square feet in size and not exceed six feet in height. 
b.  The accessory building shall comply with all setbacks and other standards for accessory buildings, unless otherwise stated herein. 
c.  Any outdoor containment areas shall be screened from view from all neighboring properties and right-of-ways. Outdoor containment areas shall not exceed 20 feet per bird and shall not have a fenced enclosure greater than six feet in height. 
d.  Any accessory building or containment area shall be located in the rear yard only and shall be at least 50 feet from adjacent habitable structures on neighboring properties. 
e.  Fencing used to contain chickens shall comply with applicable conditions of the city Code. 
f.  Chickens shall not be kept within the dwelling unit or garage. 
g.  The accessory building and/or containment area shall be maintained in good repair, in a clean and sanitary manner, free of vermin, and free of objectionable odors. 
h.  Chickens shall remain in the accessory building and/or containment area at all times and shall not run at large. 
i.  Chickens shall remain in the accessory building from sunset to sunrise each day to prevent nuisance noise and the attraction of vermin and predators. 
j.  Accessory buildings for the purpose of this ordinance shall not count towards the one accessory building as stated in section 74-219(c) but are subject to the size limitations. 
(5)  The slaughter of chickens on site is prohibited. 
(6)  The raising of chickens for breeding purposes is prohibited. 
(7)  The sale of eggs or other commercial activity on the premises is prohibited. 
(8)  Feces and discarded feed shall be regularly collected and only stored temporarily on site in a leak-proof container with a tight-fitting cover to prevent nuisance odors and the attraction of vermin. Such waste shall not be composted on site. 
(9)  Chicken feed shall be stored in leak-proof containers with a tight-fitting cover to prevent attracting vermin. 
(10)  Cockfighting is prohibited. 
(c)  License required. A license is required for any person seeking to keep chickens as allowed by this section. Any applicant shall complete an application form provided by the city. Any amendment to an existing license shall constitute a new application and fee. The application shall include, but not limited to the following information: 
(1)  Site plan showing the location and size of the premises and the location, size and type of all structures and containment areas for the chickens. 
(2)  The number of chickens to be kept on site. 
(3)  Feces and waste removal plan. 
(4)  An agreement by the applicant that the premises may be inspected by the city at all reasonable times to ensure compliance with all applicable conditions. 
(d)  Duration of license and fee. 
(1)  Each license issued hereunder shall expire on December 31 in the year of issuance unless sooner revoked. A license shall be renewed annually to continue the limited keeping of chickens. 
(2)  The annual fee for a license shall be in such amount as set forth in chapter 42, which shall be paid at the time of the making of the application. 
(e)  Right of entry for inspections. The animal control officer or city administrator's designee may enter and inspect any property or accessory building for the keeping of chickens at any reasonable time for the purpose of investigating an actual or suspected violation to ascertain compliance or noncompliance with this section. 
(f)  Violation and penalties. When a violation is found to have occurred, the officer or agent of the city shall give written notice thereof to the owner. If said violation is not remedied within ten days, the city may issue a citation to appear in district court to answer the charges stated thereon. Any owner found violating any of the provisions of this section shall upon conviction be guilty of a misdemeanor punishable by a fine. Any conviction shall result in the revocation of the permit by the city council. 
(Ord. No. 669, § 1, 4-18-11; Ord. No. 693, § 1, 4-1-13) 
Sec. 10-11. - Limited keeping of honeybees. 
(a)  Intent and purpose. It is the intent and purpose of this section to set standards for the limited keeping of honeybees in urban settings as a non-commercial hobby independent of the requirements found in section 10-5. 
(b)  Definitions. 
(1)  Beekeeping equipment means anything used in the operation of keeping honeybees, such as hive bodies, supers, frames, top and bottom boards and extractors. 
(2)  Colony means an aggregate of honeybees consisting principally of workers, but having, when perfect, one queen and at times drones, brood, combs, and honey. 
(3)  Hive means the receptacle inhabited by a colony that is manufactured for that purpose. 
(4)  Honeybee means all life stages of the common domestic honeybee, Apis mellifera species of European origin. 
(5)  Nucleus colony means a small quantity of honeybees with a queen housed in a smaller than usual hive box designed for a particular purpose. 
(c)  Conditions. The limited keeping of honeybees may be permitted as an accessory use to a single family residence subject to the following: 
(1)  The property shall be occupied with a single-family home. The owner of the honeybees shall live in the dwelling on the property. The property owner shall be in receipt of a license as required by this Ordinance. 
(2)  Honeybees shall be kept in hives with removable frames, which shall be kept in sound and usable condition. 
(3)  A convenient source of water shall be available to the colony prior to and so long as colonies remain active outside of the hive. 
(4)  No wax comb or other material that might encourage robbing by other bees shall be left upon the property. Such materials once removed from the site shall be handled and stored in sealed containers, or placed within a building or other insect-proof container. 
(5)  For each colony, there may also be maintained upon the same lot, one nucleus colony in a hive structure not to exceed one standard nine and five-eighths inch depth ten-frame hive body with no supers. 
(6)  Beekeeping equipment shall be maintained in good condition including keeping the hives painted and securing unused equipment from weather, potential theft or vandalism and occupancy by swarms. It shall be a violation of this section for any unused equipment to attract a swarm, even if the property owner is not intentionally keeping honeybees. 
(7)  All hives shall be enclosed with a latching fence. 
(8)  Hives shall be located not less than 10 feet from the property line and located only in the rear yard. In each instance where a colony is kept less than 25 feet from a property line of the lot upon which the apiary is located, as measured from the nearest point on the hive to the property line, and any entrances to the hive faces the property line, there shall be established and maintained a flyway barrier at least six feet in height. The flyway barrier may consist of a wall, fence, dense vegetation or a combination thereof, such that honeybees will fly over rather than through the material to reach the colony. If a flyway barrier of dense vegetation is used, the initial planting may be four feet in height, so long as the vegetation normally reaches six feet in height or higher. The flyway barrier must continue parallel to the apiary lot line for ten feet in either direction from the hive. All other sides of the area encompassing the colonies shall consist of fencing, a wall, dense vegetation or combination thereof at least four-feet tall. The area encompassing the colonies need not entail the entire property. 
(9)  No more than two colonies shall be permitted per property. 
(d)  License required. A license is required for any person seeking to keep honeybees as allowed by this section. Any applicant shall complete an application form provided by the city. Any amendment to an existing license shall constitute a new application and fee. The application shall include, but not limited to the following information: 
(1)  Site plan showing the location and size of the premises and the location, size and type of all structures, colonies, hives, flyaway barriers, fences, storage containers, and any other item related to the beekeeping operation. 
(2)  An agreement by the applicant that the premises may be inspected by the city at all reasonable times to ensure compliance with all applicable conditions. 
(3)  Applicant must document 16 hours of beekeeping training in the form of a certificate from the University of Minnesota. Other similar training may be substituted if found to be acceptable by the city administrator. 
(e)  Duration of license and fee. 
(1)  Each license issued hereunder shall expire on December 31 in the year of issuance unless sooner revoked. A license shall be renewed annually to continue the limited keeping of honeybees. 
(2)  The annual fee for a license shall be in such amount as set forth in chapter 42, which shall be paid at the time of the making of the application. 
(f)  Public notification. Upon issuance of the first license, the applicant shall supply mailing labels for all properties within 150 feet of the property on which the honeybees are proposed to be kept. An informational notice shall be sent to the property owners within 150 feet at the applicant's expense. 
(g)  Right of entry for inspections. The animal control officer or city administrator's designee may enter and inspect any property licensed for the keeping of honeybees at any reasonable time for the purpose of investigating an actual or suspected violation to ascertain compliance or non-compliance with this section. 
(h)  Violation and penalties. When a violation is found to have occurred, the officer or agent of the city shall give written notice thereof to the owner. If said violation is not remedied within ten days, the city may issue a citation to appear in district court to answer the charges stated thereon. Any owner found violating any of the provisions of this section shall upon conviction be guilty of a misdemeanor punishable by a fine. Any conviction shall result in the revocation of the permit by the city council. 
(Ord. No. 694, § 2, 4-1-13) 
Secs. 10-12-10-40. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - DOGS 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 10-41. - Running at large prohibited. 
    No dog shall be permitted to run at large within the corporate limits of this city. 
(Code 1982, § 14.010) 
Sec. 10-42. - Dogs on leash. 
    The restriction imposed by section 10-41 shall not prohibit the appearance of any dog upon streets or public property when such dog is under the control of the owner or a member of his immediate family, either by leash or otherwise. 
(Code 1982, § 14.011) 
Sec. 10-43. - License required. 
(a)  Application; term; fee. No person shall keep any dog within the city without first securing a license therefore from the city administrator, who shall issue a metal tag for each license and who shall keep a record of the license number and description of the dog so licensed, including name, sex, color and breed and the name and address of the owner or keeper. All renewal licenses shall be issued for a period of one, two or three years. The license fee shall be in such amount as set forth in chapter 42. All licenses shall expire on December 31 in the year of issuance. Licenses shall not be transferable. Every application shall be accompanied by a certificate of vaccination as provided in subsection (b) of this section. In the event of loss, license tags may be replaced for a fee of $1.50. No refund of license fee shall be made if the licensed dog dies or leaves the city before expiration of the license period. In addition to the license fee, the city administrator shall collect a penalty of $5.00 from any applicant applying for a renewal between January 1 and January 31, and the city administrator shall collect a penalty of $10.00 from any applicant who shall apply for a renewal after January 31, provided, however, that the imposition of such penalty shall in no way be construed as preventing the city from prosecuting any person for violating any of the terms of this chapter. 
(b)  Vaccination required. No license shall be granted for a dog whose rabies certificate of vaccination at the time of application is not current. All dogs in the city over the age of six months shall be vaccinated for rabies and revaccinated at least once every three years. Vaccination shall be performed only by a doctor qualified to practice veterinary medicine in the state in which the dog was vaccinated. A veterinarian who vaccinated the dog to be licensed in the city shall complete a certificate of vaccination, one copy of which shall accompany the license application. 
(c)  Exceptions. 
(1)  A certificate of vaccination as provided in subsection (b) of this section shall not be required if the application is accompanied by the certificate of a licensed veterinarian stating that because of health reasons the dog, for which the license is applied, should not, in the opinion of such veterinarian, be vaccinated against rabies. 
(2)  The certificate of vaccination described in subsection (b) of this section shall not be required for any dog less than six months of age, provided, however, that such license shall automatically expire when such dog shall attain the age of seven months unless, prior thereto, the certificate of vaccination described in subsection (b) of this section shall have been filed with the city administrator. 
(Code 1982, § 14.012; Ord. No. 499, § 1, 6-18-90; Ord. No. 512, § 1, 12-16-91; Ord. No. 637, § 1, 11-17-08) 
Sec. 10-44. - Affixing tags. 
    The owner or keeper shall cause the license tag required by section 10-43 to be affixed by a permanent metal fastening to the collar of the dog so licensed in such a manner that the tag may be easily seen by the officers of the city. The owner shall see that the tag is constantly worn by such dog. 
(Code 1982, § 14.013) 
Sec. 10-45. - Impounding. 
(a)  Every dog within the corporate limits of the city not restrained or confined as provided in this article, or running at large, shall be immediately impounded. Every dog so impounded having no duly issued and current license tag affixed or attached to it shall be impounded for a period of 120 hours, and if not redeemed as provided in subsection (b) of this section, within such period, by the owner or keeper thereof, such dog shall be destroyed in a proper or humane manner, or otherwise disposed of. When any dog having a duly issued, current license tag attached to or affixed to it is so impounded, the owner thereof, if he be known or can be ascertained by reasonable effort, shall be promptly notified personally or by United States mail that such dog has been impounded and setting forth the terms of redemption as provided in subsection (b) of this section. If such owner does not redeem such dog within 120 hours after such notice, then such dog shall be disposed of in the manner provided for unlicensed dogs impounded. The time to redeem such dog shall begin to run with personal notice to the owner, or upon depositing such notice in the United States mail. The poundmaster shall house and feed in a humane manner any dog held at the pound. 
(b)  Any animal may be redeemed from the animal shelter where impounded by the owner, within the time as provided in subsection (a) of this section, by the payment to the city of an impounding fee of $50.00, and such boarding fees as may be charged by the animal shelter. 
(c)  The owner of any dog not redeemed within 120 hours as set forth in subsection (a) of this section; shall be personally responsible for the cost of disposal of such dog. 
(Code 1982, §§ 14.014, 14.015; Ord. No. 501, § 1, 2-19-91; Ord. No. 587, § 1, 7-21-03; Ord. No. 637, § 1, 11-17-08) 
Sec. 10-46. - Muzzling proclamation. 
    Whenever the prevalence of hydrophobia renders such action necessary to protect public health and safety, the mayor shall issue a proclamation ordering every person owning or keeping a dog to confine it securely on his premises unless it is so muzzled that it cannot bite. No person shall violate such proclamation, and any unmuzzled dog running at large during the time fixed in the proclamation shall be killed by the police without notice to the owner. 
(Code 1982, § 14.016) 
Sec. 10-47. - Civil liability for damage. 
    All owners or keepers of dogs allowing such dogs to run at large upon the premises of another person in the city shall be liable for any damage committed by such dogs, and nothing in this chapter shall be construed as limiting the right of citizens to recover the value of such damages in any action at law. 
(Code 1982, § 14.017) 
Sec. 10-48. - Barking dogs. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to own, keep or harbor any dog which is a barking dog as defined herein. A barking dog is any dog that barks, bays, cries, howls, or makes any other noise continuously or incessantly for a period of ten minutes or barks intermittently for 30 minutes or more at any time either day or night. A dog shall not be deemed a barking dog if, at the time that the dog is barking or making any other noise, a person is trespassing or threatening to trespass upon the private property upon which the dog is situated or when the dog is teased or provoked. 
(Code 1982, § 14.018) 
Sec. 10-49. - Removal of dog excrement from property not of owner. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to cause or permit a dog under his ownership or control to be on any property, public or private, not owned by such person, unless such person shall have in his possession a device for the removal of any excrement which might be deposited by such dog. Any person who owns or controls a dog which deposits excrement upon any property, public or private, shall promptly remove such excrement to a proper receptacle located on property owned or possessed by such person. This provision shall not apply to blind or physically handicapped persons while walking with their guide dog.
