Individually wrapped tobacco and tobacco products shall include, but not be limited to, single cigarette packs, single bags or cans of loose tobacco in any form, and single cans or other packaging of snuff or chewing tobacco. Cartons or other packaging containing more than a single pack or other container as described in this subdivision shall not be considered individually packaged. 
    Loosies. "Loosies" shall mean the common term used to refer to a single or individually packaged cigarette. 
    Minor. "Minor" shall mean any natural person who has not yet reached the age of 18 years. 
    Moveable place of business. "Moveable place of business" shall refer to any form of business operated out of a truck, van, automobile, or other type of vehicle or transportable shelter and not a fixed address store front or other permanent type of structure authorized for sales transactions. 
    Retail establishment. "Retail establishment" shall mean any place of business where tobacco, tobacco products, or tobacco-related devices are available for sale to the general public. Retail establishment shall include, but not limited to, grocery stores, convenience stores, and restaurants. 
    Sale. A "sale" shall mean any transfer of goods for money, trade, barter, or other consideration. 
    Self-service merchandising. "Self-service merchandising" shall mean open displays of tobacco, tobacco products, or tobacco-related devices in any manner where any person shall have access to the tobacco, tobacco products, or tobacco-related devices, without the assistance or intervention of the licensee or the licensee's employee. The assistance or intervention shall entail the actual physical exchange of the tobacco, tobacco product, or tobacco-related device between the customer and the licensee or employee. Self-service merchandising shall not include vending machines. 
    Tobacco or tobacco products. "Tobacco" or "tobacco products" shall mean any substance or item containing tobacco leaf, including but not limited to cigarettes; cigars; pipe tobacco; snuff; fine cut or other smoking tobacco; cheroots; stogies; periques; granulated, plug cut, crimp cut, ready rubbed, and other smoking tobacco; snuff flowers; cavendish; shorts; plug and twist tobaccos; dipping tobaccos; refuse scraps, clippings, duttings, and sweepings of tobacco; and other kinds and forms of tobacco leaf prepared in such manner as to be suitable for chewing, sniffing, or smoking. 
    Tobacco-related devices. "Tobacco-related devices" shall mean any tobacco product as well as a pipe, rolling papers, or other device intentionally designed or intended to be used in a manner which enables the chewing, sniffing, or smoking of tobacco or tobacco products. 
    Vending machine. "Vending machine" shall mean any mechanical, electrical or electronic, or other type of device which dispenses tobacco, tobacco products, or tobacco-related devices upon the insertion of money, tokens, or other form of payment directly into the machine by the person seeking to purchase the tobacco, tobacco products, or tobacco device. 
(Ord. No. 559, § 2, 12-21-98) 
Sec. 22-58. - License. 
    No person shall sell or offer any tobacco, tobacco products, or tobacco-related devices without first having obtained a license to do so from the city. 
(1)  Application. An application for a license to sell tobacco, tobacco products, or tobacco-related devices shall be made on a form provided by the city. The application shall contain the full name of the applicant, the applicant's residential and business addresses and telephone numbers, the name of the business for which the license is sought, and any additional information the city deems necessary. Upon receipt of a completed application, the city administrator shall forward the application to the council for action at its next regularly scheduled council meeting. If the administrator shall determine that an application is incomplete, he or she shall return the application to the applicant with notice of the information necessary to make the application complete. 
(2)  Action. The council may either approve or deny the license, or it may delay action for such reasonable period of time as necessary to complete any investigation of the application or the applicant it deems necessary. 
(3)  Term. Except as herein otherwise provided, licenses issued under this chapter shall be valid for one calendar year from the date of issue. The city, by ordinance, may from time to time establish one uniform period for all such licenses. 
(4)  Revocation or suspension. Any license issued under this chapter may be revoked or suspended as provided in the violations and penalties section of this chapter. 
(5)  Transfers. All licenses issued under this chapter shall be valid only on the premises for which the license was issued and only for the person to whom the license was issued. No transfer of any license to another location or person shall be valid without the prior approval of the council. 
(6)  Moveable place of business. No license, shall be issued to a moveable place of business. only fixed location business shall be eligible to be licensed under this chapter. 
(7)  Display. All licenses shall be posted and displayed in plain view of the general public on the licensed premise. 
(8)  Renewals. The renewal of a license issued under this section shall be handled in the same manner as the original application. The request for a renewal shall be made at least 30 days but no more than 60 days before the expiration of the current license. The issuance of a license issued under this chapter shall be considered a privilege and not an absolute right of the applicant and shall not entitle the holder to an automatic renewal of the license. 
(Ord. No. 559, § 2, 12-21-98) 
Sec. 22-59. - Fees. 
    No license shall be issued under this chapter until the fee set forth in chapter 42 of this Code shall be paid in full. 
(Ord. No. 559, § 2, 12-21-98; Ord. No. 590, § 1, 7-21-03) 
Sec. 22-60. - Basis for denial of license. 
    The following shall be grounds for denying the issuance or renewal of a license under this chapter; however, except as may otherwise by provided by law, the existence of any particular ground for denial does not mean that the city must deny the license. If a license is mistakenly issued or renewed to a person, it shall be revoked upon the discovery that the person was ineligible for the license under this section. 
(1)  The applicant is under the age of 18 years. 
(2)  The applicant has been convicted within the past five years of any violation of a federal, state, or local law, ordinance provision, or other regulation relating to tobacco or tobacco products, or tobacco-related devices. 
(3)  The applicant has had a license to sell tobacco, tobacco products, or tobacco-related devices revoked within the preceding 12 months of the date of application. 
(4)  The applicant fails to provide any information required on the application, or provides false or misleading information. 
(5)  The applicant is prohibited by federal, state, or other local law, ordinance, or other regulation, from holding such a license. 
(Ord. No. 559, § 2, 12-21-98) 
Sec. 22-62. - Prohibited sales. 
    It shall be a violation of this chapter for any person to sell or offer to sell any tobacco, tobacco product, or tobacco related-device: 
(1)  To any person under the age of 18 years. 
(2)  By means of any type of vending machine, except as may otherwise be provided in this chapter. 
(3)  By means of self-service methods whereby the customer does not need to a make a verbal or written request to an employee of the licensed premise in order to receive the tobacco, tobacco product, or tobacco-related device and whereby there is not a physical exchange of the tobacco, tobacco product, or tobacco-related device between the licensee or the licensee's employee, and the customer. 
(4)  By means of loosies as defined in section 22-57 of this chapter. 
(5)  Containing opium, morphine, jimsonweed, belladonna, strychnos, cocaine, marijuana, or other deleterious, hallucinogenic, toxic, or controlled substances except nicotine and other substances found naturally in tobacco or added as part of an otherwise lawful manufacturing process. 
(6)  By any other means, to any other person, or in any other manner or form prohibited by federal, state or other local law, ordinance, provision or other regulation. 
(Ord. No. 559, § 2, 12-21-98) 
Sec. 22-62. - Vending machines. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person licensed under this chapter to allow the sale of tobacco, tobacco products, or tobacco-related devices by the means of a vending machine unless minors are at all times prohibited from entering the licensed establishment. 
(Ord. No. 559, § 2, 12-21-98) 
Sec. 22-63. - Self-service sales. 
    It shall be unlawful for a licensee under this chapter to allow the sale of tobacco, tobacco products, or tobacco-related devices by any means whereby the customer may have access to such items without having to request the item from the licensee or the licensee's employee and whereby there is not a physical exchange of the tobacco, tobacco product, or the tobacco-related device between the licensee or his or her clerk and the customer. All tobacco, tobacco products, and tobacco-related devices shall either be stored behind a counter or other area not freely accessible to customers, or in a case or other storage unit not left open and accessible to the general public. Any retailer selling tobacco, tobacco products, or tobacco-related devices at the time this chapter is adopted shall comply with this section within 60 days following the effective date of this chapter except where 90 percent of the sales of the particular establishment are tobacco-related products and minors are at all times prohibited from entering the licensed establishment. 
(Ord. No. 559, § 2, 12-21-98) 
Sec. 22-64. - Responsibility. 
    All licensees under this chapter shall be responsible for the actions of their employees in regard to the sale of tobacco, tobacco products, or tobacco-related devices on the licensed premises, and the sale of such an item by an employee shall be considered a sale by the license holder. Nothing in this section shall be construed as prohibiting the city from also subjecting the clerk to whatever penalties are appropriate under this chapter, state or federal law, or other applicable law or regulation. 
Sec. 22-65. - Compliance checks and inspections. 
    All licensed premises shall be open to inspection by the city police or other authorized city official during regular business hours. From time to time, but at least once per year, the city shall conduct compliance checks by engaging, with the written consent of their parents or guardians, minors over the age of 15 years but less than 18 years, to enter the licensed premise to attempt to purchase tobacco, tobacco products, or tobacco-related devices. Minors used for the purpose of compliance checks shall be supervised by city designated law enforcement officers or other designated city personnel. 
    Minors used for compliance checks shall not be guilty of unlawful possession of tobacco, tobacco products, or tobacco-related devices when such items are obtained as a part of the compliance check. No minor used in compliance checks shall attempt to use a false identification misrepresenting the minor's age, and all minors lawfully engaged in a compliance check shall answer all questions about the minor's age asked by the licensee or his or her employee and shall produce any identification, if any exists, for which he or she is asked. Nothing in this section shall prohibit compliance checks authorized by state or federal laws for educational, research, or training purposes, or required for the enforcement of a particular state or federal law. 
Sec. 22-66. - Other illegal acts. 
    Unless otherwise provided, the following acts shall be a violation of this chapter. 
(1)  Illegal sales. It shall be a violation of this chapter for any person to sell or otherwise provide any tobacco, tobacco product, or tobacco-related device to any minor. 
(2)  Illegal possession. It shall be a violation of this chapter for any minor to have in his or her possession any tobacco, tobacco product, or tobacco-related device. This subdivision shall not apply to minors lawfully involved in a compliance check. 
(3)  Illegal use. It shall be a violation of this chapter for any minor to smoke, chew, sniff, or otherwise use any tobacco, tobacco product, or tobacco-related device. 
(4)  Illegal procurement. It shall be a violation of this chapter for any minor to purchase or attempt to purchase or otherwise obtain any tobacco, tobacco product, or tobacco-related device, and it shall be a violation of this chapter for any person to purchase or otherwise obtain such items on behalf of a minor. It shall further be a violation for any person to coerce or attempt to coerce a minor to illegally purchase or otherwise obtain or use any tobacco, tobacco product, or tobacco-related device. This subdivision shall not apply to minors lawfully involved in a compliance check. 
(5)  Use of false identification. It shall be a violation of this chapter for any minor to attempt to disguise his or her true age by the use of a false form of identification, whether the identification is that of another person or one on which the age of the person has been modified or tampered with to represent an age older than the actual age of the person. 
(Ord. No. 559, § 2, 12-21-98) 
Sec. 22-67. - Violations. 
(a)  Notice. Upon discovery of a suspected violation, the alleged violator shall be issued, either personally or by mail, a citation that sets forth the alleged violation and which shall inform the alleged violator of his or her right to be heard on the accusation. 
(b)  Hearings. If a person accused of violating this chapter so requests, a hearing shall be scheduled, the time and place of which shall be published and provided to the accused violator. 
(c)  Hearing officer. The city council shall serve as the hearing officer. 
(d)  Decision. If the hearing officer determines that a violation of this chapter did occur, that decision, along with the hearing officer's reasons for finding a violation and the penalty to be imposed under section 22-69 of this chapter shall be recorded in writing, a copy of which shall be provided to the accused violator. Likewise, if the hearing officer finds that no violation occurred or finds grounds for not imposing any penalty, such findings shall be recorded and a copy provided to the acquitted accused violator. 
(e)  Appeals. Appeals of any decision made by the hearing officer shall be filed in the district court for the city in which the alleged violation occurred. 
(f)  Misdemeanor prosecution. Nothing in this section shall prohibit the city from seeking prosecution as a misdemeanor for any alleged violation of this chapter. If the city elects to seek misdemeanor prosecution, no administrative penalty shall be imposed. 
(g)  Continued violation. Each violation, and every day in which a violation occurs or continues, shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Ord. No. 559, § 2, 12-21-98) 
Sec. 22-68. - Penalties. 
(a)  Licensees. Any licensee found to have violated this chapter shall be charged an administrative fine of $75.00 for a first violation of this chapter; $200.00 for a second offense at the same licensed premises within a 24-month period; and $250.00 for a third or subsequent offense at the same location within a 24-month period. In addition, after the third offense, the license shall be suspended for not less than seven days. 
(b)  Employees of licensees and other individuals. Employees of licensees and other individuals, other than minors regulated by subdivision (c) of this subsection, found to be in violation of this chapter shall be charged an administrative fine of $75.00 for a first violation of this chapter; $200.00 for a second offense within a 24-month period; and $250.00 for a third or subsequent offense within a 24-month period. 
(c)  Minors. Minors found in unlawful possession of, or who unlawfully purchase or attempt to purchase, tobacco, tobacco products, or tobacco-related devices, shall be charged an administrative fine of $75.00 for a first violation of this chapter; $200.00 for a second offense within a 24-month period; and $250.00 for a third or subsequent offense within a 24-month period. 
(d)  Community service and other conditions. The hearing officer may, in its sole discretion, allow community service to be substituted for some or all of the fine. Such substitution shall be at a rate established by the hearing officer. The hearing officer may also stay the imposition of some or all of the fine on such other conditions that it, in its sole discretion, deems appropriate. 
(e)  Misdemeanor. Nothing in this section shall prohibit the city from seeking prosecution as a misdemeanor for any violation of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 559, § 2, 12-21-98) 
Sec. 22-69. - Exceptions and defenses. 
    Nothing in this chapter shall prevent the providing of tobacco, tobacco products, or tobacco-related devices to a minor as part of a lawfully recognized religious, spiritual, or cultural ceremony. It shall be an affirmative defense to the violation of this chapter for a person to have reasonably relied on proof of age as described by state law. 
(Ord. No. 559, § 2, 12-21-98) 
Sec. 22-70. - Severability and savings clause. 
    If any section or portion of this chapter shall be found unconstitutional or otherwise invalid or unenforceable by a court of competent jurisdiction, that finding shall not serve as an invalidation or effect the validity and enforceability of any other section or provision of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 559, § 2, 12-21-98) 
Sec. 22-71. - Effective date. 
    This chapter shall take effect the day following publication in the city's official newspaper. 
(Ord. No. 559, § 2, 12-21-98) 
Secs. 22-72-22-100. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - GAME ROOMS 

Sec. 22-101. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Game room means an establishment or premises in which five or more coin-operated mechanical amusement devices as defined in this section are kept or maintained for the use of the public. 
    Mechanical amusement device means any machine which, upon the insertion of a coin, token, or slug, operates or may be operated by the public for use as a game, entertainment, or amusement, which amusement device contains no automatic payoff device for the return of money, coins, checks, tokens or merchandise, or which provides no such payoff by any other means or manner. The term "coin-operated mechanical amusement device" shall include so-called pinball machines; motion picture machines; amusement rides; table shuffleboard games; pool tables; foosball tables, or similar games of amusement for which a fee is charged players for the playing thereof; and all other machines which, by the insertion of a coin or token, operate for the entertainment or amusement of the player, excluding, however, weighing machines and machines supplying only music through records or tapes. 
(Code 1982, § 18.150) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 22-102. - License application, fee and term. 
(a)  All game room licenses shall be granted by the city council. Application for a game room license shall be made to the city administrator and shall contain, in addition to the following, such other information as he may require: 
(1)  Personal and business information concerning the applicant; 
(2)  Name and written consent of the landlord to operate a game room, if not part of the lease, and a copy of the lease; 
(3)  A list of coin-operated mechanical amusement devices to be placed or operated in the game room, together with the license numbers thereof; 
(4)  Name or names of managers hired to supervise the operation of the game room. 
(b)  The game room license fee shall be in the amount set forth in chapter 42 of this Code. 
(c)  All annual game room licenses shall expire on December 31 of the calendar year and applications for renewal shall be submitted to the city administrator together with the applicable fee, no later than December 1 of the year in which the current license shall expire. The license fee for an initial license covering less than a calendar year shall be prorated. 
(Code 1982, § 18.151) 
Sec. 22-103. - Manager. 
    The game room licensee shall himself act as manager, or hire other persons to act as managers, who shall be on duty and remain on the premises at all times such game room is open for business. It shall be the duty of the licensee or his managers to enforce all provisions of this article, and failure to comply with the requirements of this section shall be grounds for revocation of such license. 
(Code 1982, § 18.152) 
Sec. 22-104. - Hours of operation; regulations for conduct. 
(a)  Game rooms shall not be open for business during the hours of 1:00 a.m. and 8:00 a.m. of any day. 
(b)  The following code of conduct shall be posted in a prominent place in the game room, and shall be enforced by the licensee and managers: 
(1)  No persons soliciting vice or any other unlawful purpose shall be permitted to enter or remain on the licensed premises. 
(2)  No persons selling, transferring, giving, using, or in possession of any controlled substance, as defined in M.S.A. §§ 152.01-152.20, shall be permitted to enter or remain on the premises or remain in the area directly adjacent to the licensed premises. 
(3)  No persons shall be permitted to obstruct or interfere with pedestrian traffic on all sidewalk areas directly adjacent to the licensed premises, or to harass, threaten, or annoy any other person in the areas directly adjacent to the licensed premises. 
(4)  Gambling in any form on the licensed premises shall be prohibited. 
(5)  No licensee shall permit the operation of a music machine upon the licensed premises in such manner that the music is audible on adjoining premises to the disturbance of the residents of such premises. 
(Code 1982, § 18.153) 
Sec. 22-105. - Revocation of license. 
    A game room license may be revoked by the city council for a violation of any provision of this article; provided, however, that no such revocation shall become effective until the licensee has been given ten days' notice of the council's intent to revoke such license. If within such ten-day period the licensee shall request a hearing on the proposed revocation, the revocation shall not become effective unless and until the city council shall affirm such revocation after hearing. 
(Code 1982, § 18.154) 
Secs. 22-106-22-130. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - GAMES OF SKILL 

Sec. 22-131. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Game of skill means and includes any game, device or equipment making use of balls, discs, figures or other items of special equipment to be propelled by hand, mechanically, or by any other manner into special positions, to strike certain objects, or to achieve other desired results, which game, device or equipment may be played or used by the public generally at a price paid either directly or indirectly for such privilege, whether a prize is offered for the game or not. Such definition is intended to cover particularly, but not exclusively, such games as are commonly known as pinball, shuffleboard, miniature pool or miniature bowling. It is not intended to cover standard pool or billiard tables or standard bowling alleys. 
(Code 1982, § 18.070) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 22-132. - Licenses. 
(a)  Required. No person shall operate or keep for operation any game of skill without having applied for and received a license therefor from the city council as provided in this article. 
(b)  Application. Application for a license under this article shall be made to the city administrator upon a form to be supplied by the city and shall give the name and address of the owner and applicant, the place where such device or game is to be operated, what business is conducted at that place, and the name, number and description of the game or particular piece of equipment to be licensed. Every such application shall be accompanied by such license fee as is set forth in chapter 42 of this Code. Such application shall be considered by the council at its next regular meeting and granted or rejected. 
(c)  Term. All licenses under this article shall be for the term of one year for each such machine and shall expire on December 31 in the year for which issued. 
(d)  Transfer. Any license under this article may be transferred to another location in the city upon filing notice with the administrator of such transfer and upon payment to the city of the sum set forth in chapter 42 of this Code. 
(Code 1982, § 18.071) 
Sec. 22-133. - Display of license. 
    Every license granted under this article shall be posted in a conspicuous place on or near the game so licensed and shall identify the device or equipment by number or description. 
(Code 1982, § 18.072) 
Sec. 22-134. - Restrictions. 
    No license under this article shall be issued for any game of skill within 1,000 feet of any school building. No person shall use any device licensed under this article as a gambling device and no licensee shall permit any person to use any machine licensed under this article for gambling purposes, and the operation of any lottery or gambling device is declared to be contrary to this article. 
(Code 1982, § 18.073) 
Secs. 22-135-22-155. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - GAS INSTALLERS[3] 
Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Cross reference- Buildings and building regulations, ch. 18; utilities, ch. 70. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 22-156. - Permits. 
    A permit shall be required before the start of any installation, alteration, or repair, except such minor repair not involving removal of the burner from its application, of any gas burner or gas burner equipment. The permit fee shall be in the amount set forth in chapter 42 of this Code. The permit shall be kept and posted on the premises where work is to be done until the work has been completed, tested and approved by the gas inspector. 
(Code 1982, § 18.167) 
Cross reference- Gas connections during excavations, § 58-59. 
Sec. 22-157. - Exemption. 
    The requirements of this article shall not be construed to limit the right of the gas utility, and its authorized employees, to render necessary services. 
(Code 1982, § 18.168) 
Secs. 22-158-22-175. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - LICENSE 

Sec. 22-176. - Required. 
    No person shall engage in the business of altering, repairing, or servicing of gas burning equipment without first securing a license to do so from the city. 
(Code 1982, § 18.160) 
Sec. 22-177. - Application and fee. 
    All gas installer's licenses shall be obtained from the city administrator. Applications for such license shall be filed with the administrator on forms provided. The annual license fee shall be in the amount set forth in chapter 42 of this Code. 
(Code 1982, § 18.161) 
Sec. 22-178. - Expiration and renewal period. 
    All gas installer's licenses shall expire on December 31 following the date of issuance unless sooner revoked or forfeited. If a license granted under this article is not renewed prior to its expiration, any rights granted by such license shall cease and any work performed after the expiration of the license shall be in violation of this article. Persons renewing their license after the expiration date thereof shall pay the full annual license fee. 
(Code 1982, § 18.162) 
Sec. 22-179. - Qualifications of applicant. 
    Each applicant for a license under this article shall satisfy the city that he is competent by reason of education, special training and experience, and that he is equipped to perform the work for which a license is requested in accordance with all state laws and provisions of this Code. 
(Code 1982, § 18.164) 
Sec. 22-180. - License coverage; subcontractors. 
    A license granted to a gas installer shall include the right to perform all of the work included in his general contract, and such license shall include any and all of the persons performing the work, provided that the person performing such work is in the regular employ of such licensee and qualified under state law and the provisions of this article to perform such work. In all cases the licensee shall be responsible for all of the work so performed, including the work of any of his subcontractors, provided however, that all subcontractors shall be required to obtain any license for their particular type of work as may be prescribed by the city or state codes. 
(Code 1982, § 18.163) 
Sec. 22-181. - Insurance required. 
    Any person applying for a gas installer's license shall file with the city administrator, and shall maintain in full force and effect during the license period, proof of public liability and property damage insurance policies, issued to the applicant, in the following minimum amounts: 
(1)  One hundred thousand dollars for injuries, including accidental death, to any one person; $300,000.00 on account of any one accident. 
(2)  Fifty thousand dollars for damage to property. 
(3)  All liability insurance shall include completed operations coverage and shall contain the provision that the policies cannot be cancelled without ten days' prior written notice to the city administrator. 
(Code 1982, § 18.166) 
Sec. 22-182. - Suspension and revocation. 
(a)  The city council may suspend any license granted under this article for a period not exceeding 15 days upon the recommendation of the findings of the building inspector. 
(b)  Every license granted under this article may be revoked by the city council for a violation of any provision of this article, provided, however, no such revocation shall become effective until any such licensee has been given ten days' notice of the council's intent to revoke such license. If within such ten-day period the licensee shall request a hearing on the proposed revocation, the revocation shall not become effective unless and until the city council shall affirm such revocation after hearing. Any person whose license has been revoked pursuant to the provisions of this section may not make application for a new license for a period of one year from the effective date of such revocation. 
(Code 1982, § 18.165) 
Secs. 22-183-22-205. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VII. - GENERAL CONTRACTORS 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Secs. 22-206-22-220. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - LICENSE 

Sec. 22-221. - Required. 
    No person shall engage in the business of general construction, including erection, alteration or repair of buildings, within the city without first obtaining a license to do so, unless licensed by the state under state law. 
(Code 1982, § 18.130) 
Sec. 22-222. - Application and fee. 
    All general contractor's licenses shall be obtained from the city administrator. Applications for such license shall be filed with the city administrator on forms provided. The annual license fee shall be in the amount set forth in chapter 32 of this Code. 
(Code 1982, § 18.131) 
Sec. 22-223. - Qualifications of applicant. 
    Each applicant for a license under this division shall satisfy the city that he is competent by reason of education, special training and experience, and that he is equipped to perform the work for which a license is requested in accordance with all state laws and provisions of this Code. 
(Code 1982, § 18.134) 
Sec. 22-224. - Insurance required. 
    Any person applying for a general contractor's license shall file with the city administrator, and shall maintain in full force and effect during the license period, proof of public liability and property damage insurance policies, issued to the applicant, in the following minimum amounts: 
(1)  One hundred thousand dollars for injuries, including accidental death, to any one person; $300,000.00 on account of any one accident. 
(2)  Fifty thousand dollars for damage to property. 
(3)  All liability insurance shall include completed operations coverage and shall contain the provision that the policies cannot be cancelled without ten days' prior written notice to the city administrator. 
(Code 1982, § 18.136) 
Sec. 22-225. - Expiration and renewal period. 
    All general contractor's licenses shall expire on December 31 following the date of issuance unless sooner revoked or forfeited. If a license granted under this division is not renewed prior to its expiration, the rights granted by such license shall cease and any work performed after the expiration of the license shall be in violation of this division. Persons renewing their license after its expiration date shall pay the full annual license fee. 
(Code 1982, § 18.132) 
Sec. 22-226. - License coverage; subcontractors. 
    A license granted to a general contractor shall include the right to perform all of the work included in his general contract, and such license shall include any and all persons performing the work, provided that the person performing such work is in the regular employ of such general contractor and qualified under state law and the provisions of this Code to perform such work. In all cases the general contractor shall be responsible for all of the work so performed, including the work of any of his subcontractors; provided however, that all subcontractors shall be required to obtain any license for their particular type of work as may be prescribed by the city or state codes. 
(Code 1982, § 18.133) 
Sec. 22-227. - Suspension and revocation. 
(a)  The city council may suspend any license granted under this division for a period not exceeding 15 days upon the recommendation of the findings of the building inspector. 
(b)  Any license granted under this division may be revoked by the city council for a violation of any provision of this division, provided, however, that no such revocation shall become effective until the licensee has been given ten days' notice of the council's intent to revoke such license. If within such ten-day period any licensee shall request a hearing on the proposed revocation, the revocation shall not become effective unless and until the city council shall affirm such revocation after hearing. Any person whose license has been revoked pursuant to the provisions of this section may not make application for a new license for a period of one year from the effective date of such revocation. 
(Code 1982, § 18.135) 
Secs. 22-228-22-250. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VIII. - HOME OCCUPATIONS[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Cross reference- Zoning, ch. 74. 

Sec. 22-251. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Dwelling unit, except as specifically limited in this definition, means any living unit contained within a dwelling and occupied by a person or family as a residence. The term "dwelling unit" shall not include any dwelling units located in a building containing three or more dwelling units. A duplex or double bungalow shall be deemed to contain a total of two dwelling units. 
    Home occupation means the use of a dwelling unit for gainful employment through the manufacture of, or providing or sale of, goods and/or services. 
(Code 1982, § 18.171) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 22-252. - Intent. 
    It is the intent to license in dwelling units only those home occupations that are compatible with other permitted uses and character of residential neighborhoods. Only one license for a home occupation shall be granted for any one dwelling unit; provided, however, the city council may approve not more than two licenses for any one dwelling unit if the council shall find that the combined operation of the two home occupations will not exceed the performance standards set forth in section 22-258. Home occupations shall not be permitted in any building containing three or more dwelling units. 
(Code 1982, § 18.172) 
Sec. 22-253. - License-Required. 
    No person shall engage in or conduct a home occupation in any dwelling unit within the city, not otherwise zoned for such use, without first obtaining a license to do so; provided, however, no license shall be required of any day care or residential facility which holds a license issued by the commissioner of public welfare of the state under the provisions of M.S.A. ch. 245. 
(Code 1982, § 18.170) 
Sec. 22-254. - Same-Application. 
    All applicants for a license for a home occupation shall file with the city administrator a written application for such license on forms to be prescribed by the city. The application shall be submitted by the city administrator to the fire marshal, the building inspector, and such other city inspectors as may be appropriate. The approval or disapproval of the fire marshal and all city inspectors shall be delivered to the city administrator within 15 working days from the date application is received by the administrator. The appropriate license fee shall accompany each application. All licenses shall be approved by the city council and shall be subject to any additional terms or conditions which may be imposed by the council. 
(Code 1982, § 18.173) 
Sec. 22-255. - Same-Fee. 
    The annual license fee for a home occupation license shall be in the amount as set forth in chapter 42. In addition to the annual license fee, any additional cost incurred by the city in processing any application shall be borne by the applicant and shall be paid prior to the issuance of the license. The fee for any license issued for less than six months shall be in the amount as set forth in chapter 42. All licenses shall expire on December 31 in each year. All applications for renewal shall be submitted to the city administrator, together with the applicable fee, no later than December 1 prior to the effective renewal date. 
(Code 1982, § 18.174) 
Sec. 22-256. - Permitted home occupations. 
    The following home occupations shall be permitted: 
(1)  Dressmakers, seamstresses, and tailors. 
(2)  Music, art, or dancing teachers. 
(3)  Artists, sculptors, authors or composers. 
(4)  Office facility of lawyers, architects, engineers, realtors, insurance agents, brokers, contractors, and members of similar professions. 
(5)  Office facility of ministers, rabbis, priests, or members of religious orders. 
(6)  Office facility of salespersons, sales representatives or manufacturer's representatives. 
(7)  Home crafts, such as model making, rug weaving, lapidary work and ceramics. 
(8)  Antique shops. 
(9)  Barber or beauty shops. 
(10)  Pet clipping. 
(11)  Upholstering. 
(12)  Repair of nonmotorized bicycles, electrical appliances, typewriters, cameras or other similar small items. 
(13)  Carpentry work. 
(14)  Other uses deemed similar to those listed in this section, subject to approval by the planning commission and city council. 
(Code 1982, § 18.175) 
Sec. 22-257. - Prohibited home occupations. 
    The following uses shall not be permitted as home occupations: 
(1)  Animal hospitals or pet shops. 
(2)  Clinics or hospitals. 
(3)  Mortuaries. 
(4)  Private clubs. 
(5)  Renting of trailers. 
(6)  Auto repair, major or minor. 
(7)  Selling of auto parts. 
(8)  Repair shops or service establishments, other than those listed in section 22-256. 
(9)  Restaurants. 
(10)  Stables or kennels. 
(11)  Painting of vehicles, trailers or boats. 
(12)  Retail shopping stores. 
(Code 1982, § 18.176) 
Sec. 22-258. - Regulations and performance standards. 
(a)  No more than one person, for each licensed home occupation, other than a member of the immediate family occupying the dwelling unit, shall be employed on the licensed premises at any one time. 
(b)  No exterior identification sign shall be permitted, other than a sign attached to the building, not exceeding six inches by 12 inches, indicating the correct entrance to the licensed premises. No illuminated signs shall be permitted. One identification sign may be placed inside the dwelling unit, visible from the exterior, not exceeding, however, 12 inches by 18 inches (1.5 square feet). 
(c)  No home occupation shall be conducted in an accessory dwelling, except in an attached or detached garage. 
(d)  No home occupation shall create substantial additional traffic. More than 20 vehicles coming to the licensed dwelling unit for service or products in any one day shall constitute substantial additional traffic. 
(e)  Any need for parking shall be met off the street and other than in the required front yard. Any planned use of backyards for parking shall be detailed in the application for the home occupation license. 
(f)  No home occupation shall cause an increase in sewer or water usage to the extent that the combined total use for the licensed dwelling unit exceeds the normal average for comparable residences within the city. 
(g)  There shall be no storage or display of any kind of materials or products used or manufactured under the home occupation license which are visible from the outside of any buildings on the licensed premises. 
(h)  No use of the licensed premises of the home occupation shall result in a change in fire rating of the dwelling unit or the fire district in which the licensed dwelling unit is located. 
(i)  All licensed dwelling units shall retain their residential look, appearance and character; and the appearance of any such dwelling unit shall not be altered so as to change its residential look, appearance and character. No home occupation shall be conducted in the licensed dwelling unit which alters the residential character of the dwelling unit, either by the use of colors, materials, construction, lighting, or the use of advertising signs, other than those specifically permitted in this article. 
(j)  No home occupation shall be conducted in the licensed dwelling unit which results in the emission of sounds, odors, noises, vibrations, heat, glare, or electrical disturbances which constitute a nuisance to other property owners within the city. 
(Code 1982, § 18.177) 
Sec. 22-259. - Hours of operation. 
    No home occupation shall be conducted in any licensed dwelling unit before 7:00 a.m. or after 9:00 p.m. of any day. 
(Code 1982, § 18.178) 
Sec. 22-260. - Revocation of license. 
    Every license granted under this article may be revoked by the city council for a violation of any provision of this Code or of any ordinance, law, statute or regulation; provided, however, no such revocation shall become effective until the licensee has been given ten days' notice by mail or personal service of the council's intent to revoke such license. If, within such ten-day period the licensee shall request a hearing on a proposed revocation, the revocation shall not become effective until the city council shall affirm such revocation, after hearing. After revocation, no license shall be granted for the same dwelling unit during the three-month period following the effective date of any such revocation. 
(Code 1982, § 18.179) 
Secs. 22-261-22-285. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IX. - HOUSE MOVERS[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
Cross reference- Buildings and building regulations, ch. 18; streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 58; traffic and vehicles, ch. 66; utilities, ch. 70. 

Sec. 22-286. - Permit-Required. 
    No person shall move any house or other building on, over or across the streets of the city, or from one location to another on private property, without first having obtained a permit therefor as provided in this article. 
(Code 1982, § 18.010) 
Sec. 22-287. - Same-Application. 
(a)  Contents. Any person desiring a permit to move any house or building wholly within the city to another location within the city, or from the city to a location outside of the city, or from a location outside of the city to a location within the city, shall apply to the city council for a permit therefor. The application shall contain the following information: 
(1)  The present location of the building to be moved. 
(2)  The location to which such building is to be moved. 
(3)  The proposed route to be used in moving such building. 
(4)  The name and address of the owner of such building. 
(5)  The name and address of the applicant. 
(6)  At least three recent photographs of the building proposed to be moved shall accompany such application. 
(b)  Plans to accompany applications. If an application is submitted for a permit to move a building wholly within the city or from a location outside of the city to a location within the city, the application shall be accompanied by plans and specifications showing the proposed alterations intended to be effected on such building when relocated on its new location. 
(c)  Fees. The application for a permit under this article shall be accompanied by such fee as is set forth in chapter 42 of this Code. 
(d)  Verification of application. The application for a permit under this article shall be referred to the building inspector, who shall inspect the building proposed to be moved and the plans and specifications for the alteration thereof, and to the chief of police, who shall verify facts contained in the application and the proposed route over which such building is to be moved. The report and recommendations of the chief of police and the building inspector shall be forwarded to the city council within five days after receipt of such application by them. 
(Code 1982, §§ 18.011-18.014) 
Sec. 22-288. - Bond; insurance. 
    If the city council shall approve the application for a permit under this article, no permit shall be issued until the applicant shall file the following documents with the city administrator: 
(1)  A bond in such amount as may be determined by the city council. Such bond shall indemnify all parties, including the city, against damages, costs or suits arising out of or caused by any moving operations carried on under such permit and guaranteeing the payment of any final judgment obtained against such applicant by any person, including the city, injured in person or property by reason of the moving operation covered in such permit. 
(2)  A certificate of insurance, which policies shall be maintained in force and effect during the life of the permit, showing public liability and property damage insurance policies issued to the applicant in the following amounts: 
a.  One hundred thousand dollars for injuries, including accidental death to any one person; and $300,000.00 on account of any one accident. 
b.  Fifty thousand dollars for damage to property. 
If the city council shall deny such application, one-half of all fees paid to the city shall be refunded to the applicant. 
(Code 1982, § 18.015) 
Sec. 22-289. - Crossing private property. 
    It shall be the sole duty of the applicant for a permit under this article to obtain any necessary permission from any railroad company to cross its right-of-way and to obtain any necessary permission from any public utility company to displace, remove or otherwise interfere with any of its property. 
(Code 1982, § 18.016) 
Secs. 22-290-22-310. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE X. - JUNKYARDS AND JUNK DEALERS 

Sec. 22-311. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Junk dealer means and includes all persons who have an established place of business and maintain storage yards, storerooms, storehouses or other areas or buildings for the purpose of storing their junk or similar materials, and all persons who purchase junk or similar articles for the purpose of shipping or delivering such material outside of the city. 
(Code 1982, § 18.111) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 22-312. - License-Required. 
    No person shall engage in the business of gathering, buying, selling, or storing any motor vehicles, including motor vehicle parts and components, trucks and trailers separate from the cab, which are to be junked, or scrap metals or materials of any kind or description, collectively referred to in this article as junk, without first obtaining a license so to do. 
(Code 1982, § 18.110) 
Sec. 22-313. - Same-Application and fee. 
(a)  All applicants for licenses to deal in or buy junk as provided in section 22-312 shall file with the city administrator a written application for such license on forms to be provided by the city. The application shall correctly state the nature of the business for which a license is desired, the full name, age, and place of residence of the proposed licensee and whether or not the proposed licensee has been arrested or convicted of a violation of any license, law, or regulation within the last ten years, and if so, when and where. The application shall be submitted by the city administrator to the fire marshal for certification by the fire marshal that the proposed licensee and business address have been issued a permit pursuant to the provisions of Ordinance No. 345 of the city, adopted February 4, 1974. All licenses shall be approved by the city council, and shall be subject to any additional terms or conditions imposed by the council in any license so approved including the legal description of the premises upon which the business will be operated. 
(b)  The annual license fee for junk dealers shall be in the amount set forth in chapter 42 of this Code. All licenses shall expire on December 31 in each year. 
(Code 1982, §§ 18.112, 18.113) 
Sec. 22-314. - Records. 
    Each licensed junk dealer maintaining an established place of business shall keep a separate book in which shall be recorded a general description of all junk and similar articles purchased by the junk dealer, together with the name of the person from whom purchased, the date of the purchase, and the amount paid therefor. 
(Code 1982, § 18.114) 
Sec. 22-315. - Inspection for stolen property. 
    A junk dealer's premises shall at all reasonable times be subject to inspection by all law enforcement authorities for the purpose of discovering stolen property. All persons licensed under this article shall be conclusively presumed to have consented to such inspection and to have authorized the entrance on their premises by all law enforcement authorities for the purpose of such inspection. 
(Code 1982, § 18.115) 
Sec. 22-316. - Condition of premises. 
    Every junk dealer shall keep the premises where junk is kept or stored in a clean and orderly manner. No junk automobile parts or automobiles to be junked shall be parked or located upon any public right-of-way. 
(Code 1982, § 18.116) 
Sec. 22-317. - Screening required. 
    Every place of business licensed under this article shall be screened from public view by use of natural trees and vegetation or by use of fences. Every applicant for a license under this article shall submit with his application a screening plan which shall include the type and number of screening materials to be used and the height and location of such screening. The height and location of the screening must be sufficient to screen all junk from public view from any point within 100 feet of the exterior of the screening unless the terrain makes it physically impossible to screen. The council may refer the applicant's screening plan to the planning commission for its opinion and recommendation. 
(Code 1982, § 18.117) 
Sec. 22-318. - Transfer of license and revocation. 
(a)  No license granted under this article may be transferred from the licensee to any person without the approval of the city council. 
(b)  Any license granted under this article may be revoked by the city council for a violation of any provision of this article, provided, however, no such revocation shall become effective until any such licensee has been given ten days' notice of the council's intent to revoke such license. If within such ten-day period any licensee shall request a hearing on the proposed revocation, the revocation shall not become effective unless and until the city council shall affirm such revocation after hearing. 
(Code 1982, § 18.118) 
Sec. 22-319. - Expansion. 
    Any expansion of a junkyard beyond its original legal description would require a conditional use permit as described in chapter 74, zoning. 
Secs. 22-320-22-350. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XI. - LIMITED GAMBLING[6] 

Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
State Law reference- Authority to regulate gambling, M.S.A. § 349.213. 

Sec. 22-351. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Gambling devices means those gambling devices known as paddle wheels or tipboards, or apparatus used in conducting raffles. 
    Lawful purpose means one or more of the following: 
(1)  Benefiting persons by enhancing their opportunity for religious or educational advancement, by relieving or protecting them from disease, suffering or distress, by contributing to their physical well-being, by assisting them in establishing themselves in life as worthy and useful citizens, or by increasing their comprehension of and devotion to the principles upon which this nation was founded; 
(2)  Initiating, performing, or fostering worthy public works or enabling or furthering the erection or maintenance of public structures; 
(3)  Lessening the burdens borne by government or voluntarily supporting, augmenting or supplementing services which government would normally render to the people; or 
(4)  The improving, expanding, maintaining or repairing of real property owned or leased by an organization. 
Lawful purpose does not include the erection or acquisition of any real property, unless the local unit of government specifically authorizes the expenditures after finding that the property will be used exclusively for one or more of the purposes specified in this clause. 
    Paddle wheel means a wheel marked off into sections containing one or more numbers, and which, after being turned or spun, uses a pointer or marker to indicate winning chances. 
    Profit means the gross receipts from the operation of gambling devices and the conduct of raffles, less reasonable sums expended for prizes, local licensing fees, taxes and maintenance costs for the devices. 
    Qualified organization means any corporation, fund, foundation, trust, or association organized for exclusively scientific, literary, religious, charitable, educational, or artistic purposes, or for the purpose of making contributions to or for the use of the United States of America, this state, or any of its political subdivisions for exclusively public purposes, or for any combination of the above enumerated purposes, if no part of the net income of any such corporation, fund, foundation, trust, or association inures to the benefit of any private member, stockholder, or individual; or any clubs organized and operated exclusively for pleasure, recreation, or other nonprofitable purposes, no part of the net income of which inures to the benefit of any private member, stockholder, or individual; provided, that any such corporation, fund, foundation, trust, association, or club has been in existence for at least three years and has at least 30 active members. An active member means a member who has paid all of his dues to the organization and has been a member of the organization for at least six months. 
(Code 1982, § 18.120) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 22-352. - Unlicensed gambling prohibited. 
    Gambling in the city, in any form, is hereby prohibited unless a license therefor has been issued in accordance with the terms of this article. 
(Code 1982, § 18.121) 
Sec. 22-353. - Licenses-Application; fee; term. 
(a)  Any qualified organization desiring a license to conduct limited gambling pursuant to the terms of this article shall submit an application therefor to the city council, such application to be verified by a duly authorized officer of the organization and by the person designated by the organization as gambling manager of such organization. 
(b)  Every application for a license to conduct limited gambling shall be accompanied by a license fee in the amount set forth in chapter 42 of this Code. 
(c)  Every application for a license to conduct limited gambling shall include the following information: 
(1)  Name and address of the organization and the place or places where gambling devices will be operated. 
(2)  Name and address of the person designated as gambling manager by the organization. 
(3)  If the place or places where gambling will be operated by the organization are not premises owned by the organization, the application shall be accompanied by a copy of all written leases then existing between the organization and any person owning any premises where gambling will be operated by the organization. 
(4)  A statement that the applicant is a qualified organization as defined in section 22-351 and that the gambling manager designated by the organization complies with the provisions of section 22-355. 
(d)  No license under this article shall be issued until at least 30 days have elapsed after receipt of such application by the city council and the city council shall act on the license application within 180 days from the date of its receipt. 
(e)  No license under this article shall be issued for a period longer than one year. 
(Code 1982, § 18.122) 
Sec. 22-354. - Same-Investigation and issuance. 
    Upon receipt of an application for a license to conduct gambling, the city administrator shall refer the application to the chief of police, who shall make his investigation of the organization, the designated gambling manager, and designated place or places where gambling is to be operated. Upon completion of his investigation, the chief of police shall make his recommendation to the city council within 20 days after receipt of such application that such license either be granted or denied. 
(Code 1982, § 18.123) 
Sec. 22-355. - Operating regulations; bond. 
    All organizations licensed to conduct limited gambling shall comply with the following regulations: 
(1)  Profits from the operation of gambling devices or the conduct of raffles shall be used solely for lawful purposes as defined in section 22-351. 
(2)  All operation of gambling devices and the conduct of raffles shall be under the supervision of the gambling manager designated by the organization. The gambling manager shall be responsible for gross receipts and profits from gambling devices and raffles and for their operation. Unless otherwise waived by action of the city council, the gambling manager shall give a fidelity bond in the sum of $10,000.00 in favor of the licensed organization conditioned on the faithful performance of his duties. The terms of such bond shall provide that notice shall be given in writing to the city council not less than 30 days prior to its cancellation. Such bond shall be approved by the city attorney and a copy thereof shall be filed with the city administrator. The gambling manager shall be an active member of the organization. Any person may act as both gambling manager and bingo manager for a single organization, but a gambling manager for a single organization shall not act as either a gambling manager or bingo manager of any other organization. 
(Code 1982, § 18.124) 
Sec. 22-356. - Construction of article. 
    Nothing in this article shall be construed to authorize any use, possession or operation of: 
(1)  Any gambling device which is activated by the insertion of a coin or token; or 
(2)  Any gambling game or device in which the winning numbers, tickets or chances are in any way determined by the outcome of any athletic contest or sporting event. 
(Code 1982, § 18.125) 
Sec. 22-357. - Suspension or revocation of license. 
(a)  The city council may suspend any license granted under this article for a period not exceeding 15 days upon the recommendation of the findings of the chief of police that any licensee is conducting the operation of gambling in violation of any provision of this Code or of any statute of the state. 
(b)  Every license granted under this article may be revoked by the city council for a violation of any provision of this article; provided, however, no such revocation shall become effective until the licensee has been given ten days' notice of the council's intent to revoke such license. If within such ten-day period the licensee shall request a hearing on the proposed revocation, the revocation shall not become effective unless and until the city council shall affirm such revocation after hearing. 
(Code 1982, § 18.126) 
Secs. 22-358-22-399. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XII. - PEDDLERS[7] 

Footnotes: 
--- (7) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 682, §§ 1, 2, adopted June 4, 2012, amended Article XII in its entirety to read as herein set out. Former Article XII, §§ 22-401-22-405, pertained to similar subject matter, and derived from §§ 18.080-18.085 of the 1982 Code. 
State Law reference- Authority to regulate transient merchants, M.S.A. § 412.221, subdivision 19, § 437.02. 

Sec. 22-400. - Definitions. 
    The following words and terms when used in this article shall have the following meaning, unless the context clearly indicates otherwise: 
    Solicitor (solicit) : An individual who goes from place-to-place, including private property and private residences, without an invitation from the owner or occupant, for the purpose of: (1) advertising, promoting, selling, leasing, installing or explaining any product, service, organization or cause; (2) or for the purpose of procuring orders for the sale of merchandise or personal services for future delivery or future performance, whether or not the individual has a sample of the merchandise or is collecting advance payments for the orders. 
(Ord. No. 682, § 1, 6-4-12) 
Sec. 22-401. - Required. 
    No person shall solicit within the city without first having obtained a license as provided in this article. 
(Ord. No. 682, § 2, 6-4-12) 
Sec. 22-402. - Application; fee. 
(a)  Any person desiring to obtain a license to solicit as described in the article shall make application therefor to the city administrator, who shall grant such license, or who may refer the application to the city council with a recommendation to grant or deny such application. All such applications shall contain the following: 
(1)  Name and address of applicant. 
(2)  Description of merchandise to be solicited within the city; and description of manner in which such merchandise will be solicited. 
(3)  Description of any vehicles to be used by applicant. 
(b)  Application for a license under this article shall be accompanied by a license fee in the amount set forth in chapter 42 of this Code. 
(Ord. No. 682, § 2, 6-4-12) 
Sec. 22-403. - Display of license. 
    Every person granted a license under this article shall have such license with him for inspection at all times he is engaged in soliciting. No license issued under this article shall be transferable. 
(Ord. No. 682, § 2, 6-4-12) 
Sec. 22-404. - Exception. 
(a)  This article shall not apply to any person selling any kind of garden or farm produce, produced or raised by the seller or any member of his family. 
(b)  Individuals engaging in soliciting money, donations, or financial assistance of any kind or taking orders for goods sold by an exempt organization, or selling or distributing literature or merchandise for which a fee is charged or solicited on behalf of such an organization shall not be required to be licensed pursuant to this article but must have on them at all times while soliciting some form of exempt organization identification as defined in this article. The burden of proving the solicitor's exemption for licensing shall be on its claimant. This exception does not include individuals who are paid to engage in regulated activity. 
(c)  Individuals holding a valid license pursuant to M.S.A ch. 326, by the terms of which the city is preempted from separate license. 
(d)  No license shall be required under this article for any person going door-to-door for the purpose of advocating any religious, political, social or other position or belief protected by the federal or state constitution. This exemption does not apply and such person is required to obtain a license if the exercise of the person's constitutional rights are merely incidental to a commercial activity. 
(Ord. No. 682, § 2, 6-4-12) 
Secs. 22-405-22-430. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XIII. - MASSAGE THERAPY[8] 

Footnotes: 
--- (8) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 725, § 1, adopted Feb. 16, 2016, repealed the former Art. XIII, §§ 22-431-22-437, and enacted a new Art. XIII as set out herein. The former Art. XIII pertained to saunas and massage parlors and derived from Code 1982, §§ 18.140-18.146. 

Sec. 22-431. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Massage means any method of pressure on, or friction against, or the rubbing, stroking, kneading, tapping, pounding, vibrating, stimulating, or rolling of the external parts of the human body with the hands or with the aid of any mechanical or electrical apparatus, or other appliances or devices, with or without such supplementary aids as rubbing alcohol, liniment, antiseptic, oil, powder, cream, lotion, ointment, or other similar preparations. 
    Massage therapist means an individual who practices or administers massage to the public who can demonstrate to the issuing authority that he or she is affiliated with, employed by, or owns a therapeutic massage business licensed by the city. 
    Therapeutic massage business means an entity which operates a business which hires only massage therapists licensed by the city to provide therapeutic massage to the public. The owner/operator of a therapeutic massage business need not be licensed as a therapeutic massage therapist if he or she does not at any time practice or administer massage to the public. A therapeutic massage business may employ other individuals such as cosmetologists and estheticians, and these individuals are not required to have a massage therapist license as long as they are not providing therapeutic massage to the public. 
(Ord. No. 725, § 1, 2-16-16) 
Sec. 22-432. - Licenses-required. 
(a)  Therapeutic massage business license. It shall be unlawful for any person or entity to own, operate, engage in, or carry on, within the city, any type of massage services to the public for compensation without first having obtained a therapeutic massage business license from the city pursuant to this section. 
(b)  Massage therapist license. It shall be unlawful for any individual to practice, administer, or provide massage services to the public for compensation within the city without first having obtained a personal massage therapist license from the city pursuant to this section. 
(Ord. No. 725, § 1, 2-16-16) 
Sec. 22-433. - Therapeutic massage business license application. 
(a)  Application for a license under this article shall be made at the office of the city administrator. All applications shall be sworn to be true and correct by the applicant, under oath made to a notary public or other person authorized to administer oaths in the state, and shall contain the following information: 
(1)  A description of the location of the premises to be licensed. If the premises are not constructed and furnished at the time the application is completed, the detailed plans of the premises or furnishings shall be attached to the application; 
(2)  Names and addresses of the property owner, the business owner, the lessee, the manager, and operator; 
(3)  Names, residences and addresses of two persons, residents of the state, who may be referred to as to the applicant's, manager's or operator's character; 
(4)  Whether the applicant's manager or operator has ever been convicted of a crime or offense, other than a traffic offense within the last ten years and, if so, information as to the time, place and nature of such crime or offense, together with such other information as the council may require; and 
(5)  Names and addresses of all employees of the business and a statement as to whether any of such employees have ever been convicted of a crime or offense, other than a traffic offense, and if so, information as to the name of any such employee, the time, place and nature of such crime or offense, together with such other information as the council may require. 
(6)  Proof of commercial general liability insurance coverage with a minimum of $1,000,000.00 of coverage per occurrence. 
(b)  It shall be the obligation of the licensee to maintain the information required under subsection (a) of this section on a current basis and if there are any changes as to the property owner or the business owner or the lessee, the manager, operator or any of the employees of the licensee, the licensee shall immediately certify any such changes to the city. 
(Ord. No. 725, § 1, 2-16-16) 
Sec. 22-434. - Therapeutic massage business restrictions and regulations. 
(a)  Licenses under this article may be granted only in a district zoned for business. 
(b)  It shall be grounds for denial of the application for a license under this article if there is any fraud or deception involved in the license application. 
(c)  It shall be grounds for denial of the application for a license under this article if the applicant or persons in his employ are not complying with or have a history of violations of the laws that apply to health, safety, or moral turpitude. 
(d)  All establishments licensed under this article shall be maintained in a sanitary and clean condition and shall be well lighted. 
(e)  Individual lockers shall be made available for use by patrons of establishments licensed under this article, and such lockers shall have separate keys for locking. 
(f)  No therapeutic massage business shall employ or use any person to perform massage who is not licensed as a massage therapist under this section. 
(g)  No license shall be granted for operation on any premises on which taxes, assessments, or other financial claims of the city, county or state are delinquent or unpaid. 
(Ord. No. 725, § 1, 2-16-16) 
Sec. 22-435. - Therapeutic massage business hours. 
    No customers or patrons shall be allowed to enter the premises of any establishment licensed under this article after 10:00 p.m. and before 7:00 a.m. daily, and no customers or patrons shall be allowed to remain upon such licensed premises after 10:30 p.m. and before 7:00 a.m. daily. 
(Ord. No. 725, § 1, 2-16-16) 
Sec. 22-436. - Massage therapist license application. 
    An application for a massage therapist license shall be made on a form supplied by the city clerk and shall request the following information: 
(a)  The applicant's home telephone and cell phone number. 
(b)  The applicant's physical description, including weight, height, color of eyes, and color of hair. The applicant shall provide a color photocopy of the applicant's driver's license or state-issued I.D. front and back, or any other government-issued I.D. including proof the applicant is at least 18 years of age or older 
(c)  Whether the applicant has ever been convicted of any felony, crime, or violation of any ordinance other than a minor traffic offense and, if so, the time, place, and offense for each conviction. 
(d)  Whether the applicant has had an interest in, as an individual or as part of a corporation, partnership, association, enterprise, entity, business or firm, a massage license that was revoked or suspended within the last five years of the date the license application is submitted to the issuing authority. 
(e)  Whether the applicant is currently licensed in other communities to perform massage therapy, and if so, where. 
(f)  Whether the applicant has ever been engaged in the operation of massage services, and if so, information as to the name, place, dates and length of time of the involvement in such an establishment. 
(g)  Lists of education, credentials, memberships and/or qualifications the applicant has in the field of massage therapy to include but not limited to: 
(1)  High school diploma or its equivalent 
(2)  Current cardiopulmonary resuscitation and first aid certifications 
(3)  Successful completion of a curriculum from an approved education provider and successful completion of a competency exam. 
(h)  Current professional liability insurance coverage with a minimum of $1,000,000.00 of coverage epr occurrence. 
(i)  Description of all professional disciplinary action initiated against the applicant in any jurisdiction. 
(j)  Such other information as the city council shall require. 
(Ord. No. 725, § 1, 2-16-16) 
Sec. 22-437. - Massage therapist license restrictions and regulations. 
(a)  A massage therapist shall be employed by, affiliated with, or own a massage business licensed by the city. 
(b)  A person licensed as a massage therapist shall post the massage therapist license, along with a color photo, in a conspicuous place on the premises at which the therapist is associated. A massage therapist shall have readily available at all times that therapeutic massage services are rendered a government-issued photo identification card. 
(c)  A license for a massage therapist may be denied by the city in cases where 
(1)  There is any fraud or deception involved in the license application. 
(2)  The applicant is not complying with or have a history of violations of the laws that apply to health, safety, or moral turpitude. 
(3)  The applicant had a massage therapist or massage therapy business-related license in another jurisdiction that was suspended or revoked within ten years preceding the date of application; 
(4)  The applicant is not 18 years of age or older; 
(5)  The applicant has not demonstrated the education, credentials, and/or qualifications necessary to conduct massage therapy, in the judgement of the city council. 
(6)  The applicant has been denied a license under this article within the preceding 12 months. 
(Ord. No. 725, § 1, 2-16-16) 
Sec 22-438. - Licenses and inspections. 
(a)  Fees. The fees for therapeutic massage business and massage therapist licenses shall be as set forth by City Code chapter 42. An investigation fee shall be charged for therapeutic massage business licenses and individual massage therapist license. Each application for a license shall be accompanied by payment in full of the required license and investigation fees. An application shall be deemed incomplete unless it is accompanied with the required fees, all documentation required by this article, and is completed in its entirety. 
(b)  License application investigation. An investigation is required prior to the issuance of any license. No investigation fee in part of whole shall be refunded. Out of state investigations shall require the applicant to pay actual out-of-pocket expenses. A deposit of $500.00 for an out-of-state investigation shall be required in advance, the applicant shall be refunded any unused deposit upon completion of the investigation. The city council may order and conduct such additional investigation as it deems necessary. Upon completion of the investigation by the police department, the Council shall approve or deny the license. 
(c)  Inspections. In light of the high risk of involvement with illegal conduct an establishment providing massage therapy poses to the general public, city staff and/or the police department shall have the right to enter, inspect, and search the licensed premises during the hours in which the licensed premises is open for business to ensure compliance with all provisions of this article. Any search of the licensed premises is subject to reasonableness standards as recognized by the courts. With reasonable notice, the business records of the licensee, including income tax returns, shall be available for inspection during the hours in which the licensed premises is open for business. 
(d)  [Separate license.] A separate license shall be obtained for each place of business. 
(e)  [Licenses displayed.] The licensee shall display the license in a prominent place on the licensed premises at all times. 
(f)  [License expiration.] Each license shall expire on December 31 of the year for which issued. 
(Ord. No. 725, § 1, 2-16-16) 
Sec. 22-439. - Suspension or revocation of license. 
(a)  The city council may suspend any license granted under this article for a period not exceeding 15 days upon the recommendation of the findings of the chief of police that any licensee is conducting operations in the licensed premises in violation of any provision of this article or of any statute of the state. 
(b)  Every license granted under this article may be revoked by the city council for a violation of any provision of this article; provided, however, no such revocation shall become effective until the licensee has been given ten days' notice of the council's intent to revoke such license. If within such ten-day period the licensee shall request a hearing on the proposed revocation, the revocation shall not become effective unless and until the city council shall affirm such revocation after hearing. Any license granted under this article shall be revoked if the license of any person in the licensee's employ is convicted of any violation of any ordinance of the city or statutes of the state arising within the business establishment to which the license was granted. 
(Ord. No. 725, § 1, 2-16-16) 
Secs. 22-440-22-460. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XIV. - SPECIAL EVENTS 

Sec. 22-461. - Intent. 
    It is the purpose of the city council to regulate the time, place and manner of special events when the event's impact upon the health, sanitary, fire, police, transportation and utility services exceeds those regularly provided to that property. This article is enacted in order to promote the health, safety and welfare of all residents and visitors of the city by ensuring that special events do not create disturbances, become nuisances, menace or threaten life, health or property, disrupt traffic or threaten or damage private or public property. It is not the intent of the city council by enacting this article to regulate in any manner the content of speech or infringe upon the right to assemble, except for regulating the time, place and manner of speech and assembly and this article should not be interpreted or construed otherwise.
