(3)  Through or double frontage lots shall not be permitted except where such lots abut a thoroughfare or major highway. Such lots shall have an additional depth of ten feet for screen planting along the rear lot line. 
(4)  Watercourses. Lots abutting upon a watercourse, drainageway, channel or stream shall have an additional depth or width as required to assure that building sites are not subject to flooding. 
(c)  Lot remnants. All remnants of lots below minimum size left over after subdividing of a large tract must be added to adjacent lots, or a plan shown as to future use rather than be allowed to remain as unusable parcels. 
(d)  Access to thoroughfares. In the case where a proposed plat is adjacent to an arterial or collector street, vehicular access from individual lots to such streets and roads shall be limited to respect the function of those streets. 
(Code 1982, § 31.065) 
Sec. 62-92. - Easements. 
(a)  Provided for utilities. Easements at least 12 feet wide, centered on rear and other lot lines as required, shall be provided for utilities where necessary. Where underground utilities are being installed, a front or side yard easement may be required. These easements shall be covered by document. 
(b)  Provided for drainage. Easements shall be provided along each side of the centerline of any watercourse or drainage channel, whether or not shown on the comprehensive plan, to a sufficient width to provide proper maintenance and protection and to provide for stormwater runoff and installation and maintenance of storm sewers. 
(c)  Continuous utility easement locations. Utility easements shall connect with easements established in adjoining properties. These easements, when approved, shall not thereafter be changed without the approval of the city council after a public hearing. 
(d)  Guy wires. Additional easements for pole guys should be provided, where appropriate, at the outside of turns. Where possible, lot lines shall be arranged to bisect the exterior angle so that pole guys will fall along side lot lines. 
(e)  Dedication. Utility and drainage easements shall be dedicated for the required use. 
(Code 1982, § 31.066) 
Sec. 62-93. - Public utilities. 
(a)  Water supply. Extensions of the public water supply system shall, when available, be designed so as to provide public water service to each lot. 
(b)  Sewage disposal. Extensions of the public sanitary sewer system shall, when available, be designed so as to provide public sewer service to each lot. 
(Code 1982, § 31.067) 
Sec. 62-94. - Drainage. 
    A complete and adequate drainage system design shall be required for the subdivision and may include a storm sewer system or a system of open ditches, culverts, pipes and catchbasins, and ponding areas, or both such systems. 
(Code 1982, § 31.068) 
Sec. 62-95. - Stormwater management. 
    Every application for a subdivision shall be required to submit a stormwater management plan as may be required by section 74-240. 
(Code 1982, § 31.069; Ord. No. 658, § 1, 7-6-10; Ord. No. 716, § 4, 4-20-15) 
Sec. 62-96. - Protected areas. 
(a)  Where land proposed for subdivision is deemed environmentally sensitive by the city, due to the existence of floodable areas or steep slopes, the design of such subdivision shall clearly reflect all necessary measures of protection to ensure against adverse environmental impact. 
(b)  Based upon the necessity to control and maintain certain sensitive areas, the city shall determine whether protection of such areas will be accomplished through lot enlargement and redesign or dedication of those sensitive areas in the form of outlots. 
(c)  In general, measures of protection shall include design solutions which allow for construction and grading involving a minimum of alteration to sensitive areas. Where these areas are to be incorporated into lots within the proposed subdivision, the subdivider shall be required to demonstrate that the proposed design will not require construction on slopes over 18 percent, or result in significant alteration to the natural drainage system such that adverse impacts cannot be contained within the plat boundary. 
(Code 1982, § 31.0610) 
Secs. 62-97-62-130. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - PARKS, OPEN SPACE AND PUBLIC USE 

Sec. 62-131. - Conveyance of land for public use. 
    Pursuant to M.S.A. § 462.358, subd. 2b, the city council shall require all owners or developers as a prerequisite to approval of a plat, subdivision or development of any land to convey to the city or dedicate to the public use, for park or playground purposes, a reasonable portion of the area being platted, subdivided or developed as specified in this article, such portions to be approved and acceptable to the city, or in lieu thereof the owners or developers shall at the option of the city pay to the city, for use in the acquisition of public parks and playgrounds, development of existing public park and playground sites, and debt retirement in connection with land previously required for public parks and playgrounds, an equivalent amount in cash based upon the undeveloped land value of that portion of such land that would have otherwise been required to be dedicated. The form of contribution (cash or land, or any combination thereof) shall be decided by the city council based upon need and conformance with approved city plans. 
(Code 1982, § 31.070) 
Sec. 62-132. - Suitability of land to be dedicated. 
    Any land to be dedicated as a requirement of this article shall be reasonably adaptable for use for active park and recreation purposes and shall be at a location convenient to the people to be served. Factors used in evaluating the adequacy of proposed park and recreation areas shall include size, shape, topography, geology, tree cover, access and location. 
(Code 1982, § 31.071) 
Sec. 62-133. - Recommendations of parks and recreation commission. 
(a)  The parks and recreation commission shall develop and recommend to the city council for adoption standards and guidelines for determining what portion of each such development shall reasonably be required to be conveyed or dedicated. Such standards and guidelines may take into consideration the zoning classification to be assigned to the land to be developed, the particular use proposed for such land, amenities to be provided and factors of density and site development as proposed by the owners or developers. The parks and recreation commission shall further recommend changes and amendments from time to time to such standards and guidelines to reflect changes in the usage of land which may occur, changes in zoning classifications and concepts and changes in planning and development concepts that relate to the development and usages to which land must be put. 
(b)  The parks and recreation commission shall, in each case, recommend to the city council the total area and location of such land that the commission feels should be so conveyed or dedicated within the development for park or playground purposes. 
(c)  In those instances where a cash contribution is to be made by the owners or developers in lieu of a conveyance or dedication of land for park or playground purposes, the parks and recreation commission shall recommend to the city council the amount of cash the commission feels should be so contributed, which recommendation shall be based upon the fair market value of the equivalent undeveloped land value of the area that would otherwise have been conveyed or dedicated. Fair market value shall be determined as of the time of filing the final plat in accordance with the following: 
(1)  The parks and recreation commission and subdivider may agree as to the fair market value. 
(2)  The city council, after reviewing the parks and recreation commission's recommendation, may agree with the subdivider as to the fair market value. If agreement is not reached in this manner, then fair market value shall be determined in accordance with one of the following: 
a.  The fair market value as determined by the parks and recreation commission and city council based upon current appraisals submitted to the city by the subdivider at his expense. The appraisals shall be made by appraisers who are approved members of SREA or MAI, or equivalent real estate appraisal societies. 
b.  If the city disputes such appraisal amounts, it may at its expense obtain an appraisal of the property by a qualified real estate appraiser, which appraisal shall be accepted by the city as being an accurate appraisal of fair market value. 
(Code 1982, §§ 31.072-31.074) 
Sec. 62-134. - Land dedication required. 
(a)  Where a proposed park, playground or other recreational area, proposed school site or other public ground that has been indicated in the official map and/or comprehensive plan is located in whole or in part within a proposed subdivision, such proposed public site shall be designated as such and should be dedicated to the city, school district or other proper governmental unit. If the subdivider chooses not to dedicate an area in excess of the land required under this article for such proposed public site, the council shall not be required to act to approve or disapprove the plat of the subdivision for a period of 90 days after the subdivider meets all the provisions of the subdivision ordinance in order to permit the council, school board or other appropriate governmental unit to consider the proposed plat and to take the necessary steps to acquire, through purchase or condemnation, all or part of the public site proposed under the official map or master plan. 
(b)  Land area so conveyed or dedicated for park and playground purposes may not be used by an owner or developer as an allowance for purposes of calculating the density requirements of the development as set out in the zoning ordinance and shall be in addition to and not in lieu of open space requirements for planned unit developments pursuant to the zoning ordinance as amended. 
(Code 1982, §§ 31.075, 31.076) 
Sec. 62-135. - Credit for private open space. 
    Where private open space for park and recreation purposes is provided in a proposed subdivision and such space is to be privately owned and maintained by the future residents of a subdivision, such areas may be used for credit at the discretion of the city council against the requirement of dedication for park and recreation purposes, provided the city council finds it is in the public interest to do so and that the following standards are met: 
(1)  Yards, court areas, setbacks and other open space required to be maintained by the zoning and building regulations shall not be included in the computation of such private open space; 
(2)  The private ownership and maintenance of the open space is adequately provided for by written agreement; 
(3)  The private open space is restricted for park and recreational purposes by recorded covenants which run with the land in favor of the future owners of property within the tract and which cannot be eliminated without the consent of the city council; 
(4)  The proposed private open space is reasonably adaptable for use for park and recreational purposes, taking into consideration such factors as size, shape, topography, geology, access and location of the private open space land; 
(5)  Facilities proposed for the open space are in substantial accordance with the provisions of the recreational element of the comprehensive plan, and are approved by the city council; and 
(6)  Where such credit is granted, the amount of credit shall not exceed 25 percent of the amount calculated in section 62-138. 
(Code 1982, § 31.077) 
Sec. 62-136. - Disposition of cash contributions. 
    All cash contributions received from owners and developers in lieu of conveyance or dedication of land for park or playground purposes shall be deposited in the general fund marked in favor of the parks and recreation commission. The commission shall from time to time make recommendations to the city council for appropriations from such fund for acquisition of land for park and playground purposes, for developing existing park and playground sites, or for debt retirement in connection with land previously acquired for parks and playgrounds. 
(Code 1982, § 31.078) 
Sec. 62-137. - Administrative procedures. 
    The parks and recreation commission shall establish such administrative procedures as it may deem necessary and as required to implement the provisions of this article. 
(Code 1982, § 31.079) 
Sec. 62-138. - Percentage of land required for dedication. 
    Subdividers and developers of land within the city shall be required to dedicate to the city for park and playground purposes, as a minimum, that percentage, or value, of gross land area as follows: 
(1)  Residential areas: Ten percent. 
(2)  Commercial and industrial areas: Five percent. 
(Code 1982, § 31.0710) 
Secs. 62-139-62-160. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - IMPROVEMENTS 

Sec. 62-161. - General requirements. 
(a)  Before a final plat is delivered to the city by the subdivider, the subdivider of the land covered by such plat shall pay all applicable fees and execute and submit to the city council a developer's agreement which shall be binding on his heirs, personal representatives and assigns, a part of which agreement shall set forth that the subdivider will cause no private construction to be made on the lands within such plat, nor shall the subdivider file or cause to be filed any application for building permits for such construction, until all improvements required under this chapter have been made or arranged for in the manner and conforming to the requirements as set forth in this chapter. 
(b)  Prior to the delivery of the approved final plat, the subdivider shall deposit with the city administrator an amount equal to a minimum of 125 percent of the city engineer's estimated cost of the required improvements within the plat, either in a cash escrow fund, performance and indemnity bond, or letter of credit. The surety involved in such financial guarantees shall be approved by the city. The cash escrow, letter of credit or performance and indemnity bond shall be conditioned upon: 
(1)  The making and installing of all of the improvements required by the terms and conditions set forth by the city within one year. 
(2)  Satisfactory completion of the work and payment therefor, which work was undertaken by the subdivider in accordance with the developer's agreement referred to in subsection (a) of this section. 
(3)  The payment by the subdivider to the city of all expenses incurred by the city, which expenses shall include but not be limited to expenses for engineering, fiscal, legal, construction and administration. In instances where a cash escrow is submitted in lieu of a letter of credit or performance and indemnity bond, there shall be a cash escrow agreement which shall provide that if the required improvements are not completed within one year, all amounts held under the cash escrow agreement shall automatically be turned over and delivered to the city and applied by the city to the cost of completing the required improvements. If the funds available within such cash escrow agreement are not sufficient to complete the required improvements, the necessary additional cost to the city shall be assessed against the subdivision. Any balance remaining in the cash escrow fund after such improvements have been made and all expenses therefor have been paid shall be returned to the subdivider. In instances where a letter of credit is used in lieu of a cash escrow or performance and indemnity bond, the letter of credit shall be in a form satisfactory to the city and the terms thereof shall substantially comply with the procedure as set forth for a cash escrow fund. In instances where a performance and indemnity bond is used in lieu of a cash escrow or letter of credit, such bond shall be in a form acceptable to the city and shall comply with all requirements as set forth in state statutes, as amended, which statutes relate to surety bonds. 
(c)  No final plat shall be approved by the council without first receiving a report signed by the city engineer and the city attorney certifying that the improvements described therein together with the agreements and documents required under this article meet the requirements of the city. The city administrator shall also certify that all fees required to be paid to the city in connection with the plat have been paid. 
(d)  The city shall, where appropriate, require of a subdivider submission of a warranty/maintenance bond in the amount equal to the original cost of the required improvements, which shall be in force for one year following the final acceptance of any required improvements and shall guarantee satisfactory performance of such improvements. 
(e)  The council may elect to install any or all of the required improvements pursuant to a cash escrow agreement or, at its election, in lieu of any cash escrow or indemnity bond, the city council may elect to construct the required improvements and assess the cost against the benefited properties included in the subdivision. 
(f)  Reproducible as-built drawings as required by the city engineer shall be furnished to the city by the subdivider of all required improvements. Such as-built drawings shall be certified to be true and accurate by the registered engineer responsible for the installation of the improvements. 
(g)  All of the required improvements to be installed under the provisions of this chapter shall be approved by and subject to the inspection of the city engineer. All of the city's expenses incurred as the result of the required improvements shall be paid either directly, indirectly or by reimbursement to the city by the subdivider. 
(Code 1982, § 31.080) 
Sec. 62-162. - Installation of improvements. 
    Prior to the approval of a plat by the city council, the subdivider shall have agreed, in the manner set forth in this section, to install, in conformity with approved construction plans and in conformity with all applicable standards and ordinances, the following improvements on the site: 
(1)  Monuments. 
a.  All subdivision boundary corners, block and lot corners, road intersection corners and points of tangency and curvature shall be marked with survey monuments meeting the minimum requirements of state law. All U.S., state, county and other official benchmarks, monuments or triangulation stations in or adjacent to the property shall be preserved in precise position unless a relocation is approved by the controlling agency. 
b.  All lot corner pipes or iron rods shall be a minimum of one-half inch in diameter, 18 inches in length, and shall be inscribed with the registration number of the land surveyor making the survey as prescribed in M.S.A. ch. 505. All unmonumented quarter corners and section corners will be set by the county surveyor. 
c.  To ensure that all irons and monuments are correctly in place following the final grading of a plat, a second monumentation shall be required. Proof of the second monumentation shall be in the form of a surveyor's certificate. 
(2)  Streets. 
a.  Street grading. Streets shall be graded in accordance with a plan approved by the engineer. The grading shall include the entire width of the right-of-way and shall provide a boulevard section, in addition to the minimum pavement width. 
b.  Street pavement. The design of street pavement for all streets covered by this chapter shall be in accordance with the State of Minnesota Highway Department Road Design Manual No. 5-291 for flexible pavements. The designed thickness of the surfacing elements shall be in accordance with the flexible pavement standard for road classifications as follows: 
Classification Pavement design; 
axle load Arterial, collector streets, and commercial or industrial service streets As determined by traffic needs Local streets and marginal access streets 7 ton minimum  
c.  Gravel surface. Streets that at the present time will only have a gravel surface shall be designed so the base and subbase requirements as set forth in State of Minnesota Highway Department Road Design Manual No. 5-291 for flexible pavement are met. In all cases at least the top six inches of the street surface shall be of class 5 gravel or a material as approved by the engineer. 
d.  Curb and gutter. Concrete curb and gutter shall be constructed on both sides of streets. The construction shall be in accordance with MnDOT 1978 Standard Specifications for Highway Construction, Specification No. 2531. Concrete curb and gutter cross sections shall be either design no. B618 or design no. S518. 
e.  Soil tests. To determine subgrade soil classifications, soil samples shall be collected and analyzed by a reputable testing laboratory. Reports of the soil analysis shall be submitted to the engineer with the pavement plans. Soil samples shall be taken along the centerline of the proposed road at intervals not exceeding 300 feet. 
(3)  Boulevards. All boulevards shall have four inches of topsoil (black dirt) placed on them and then seeded or sodded. 
(4)  Street signs. All street signs shall be provided and installed by the community at the expense of the subdivider. 
(5)  Street trees. The type or species of tree planted shall be approved by the community. Trees with root structures that are less likely to interfere with utility lines, break up sidewalks, and cause other nuisance damage are required. Trees shall have a trunk diameter, measured 12 inches above ground level, of not less than 13/4 inches and shall be planted in not less than one cubic yard of good growing soil with a suitable amount of fertilizer. Approved multiple varieties shall be used alternately. 
(6)  Public sanitary sewer. 
a.  In all cases where trunk line sanitary sewer facilities are available, the subdivider shall be required to install sanitary sewers in the plat and connect the same to such trunk line sewers. 
b.  Unless otherwise required, a sanitary sewer of eight-inch vitrified clay pipe shall be installed as the minimum size, placed at grades approved by the engineer. Mains over eight inches in size may be required and the additional cost may be borne by the community. Serviceways shall be four inches. Root repellent joint material and yarns are required. 
c.  If such facilities are not available but it is expected they will be within five years, the council may require that such sewers, together with all necessary laterals extending from the main sewer to the street curb, shall be installed and capped for future connection as service becomes available. In that event the subdivider may also install on-site disposal units, provided they are so located as to permit easy and the least expensive connection to the sewer when it becomes available and usable. Where such on-site units are installed, the subdivider shall provide underground plumbing to the extent of three feet beyond the footing, which plumbing shall be plugged. The area around the stack shall be scored so that the septic tank line can be disconnected and connection can be made with the public sanitary sewer system. 
(7)  On-site sewage facilities. Where lots cannot be connected with a public sewerage system, provisions for sanitary sewerage facilities shall be in compliance with the on-site sewage regulations of the city. This does not mean that the installation of individual disposal devices shall be at the expense of the subdivider. 
(8)  Public water service. 
a.  In the case where mains from a public water system are available, the subdivider shall be required to install water mains in the plat and connect such mains to such public water system. 
b.  A minimum water main of six-inch ductile iron pipe shall be required. Mains over six inches in size may be required and the additional cost may be borne by the community. 
(9)  Individual water service. 
a.  In the case where mains from a public system are not available, alternative forms of water service may be provided. 
b.  An individual well shall produce at least ten gallons per minute, have a well casing at least four inches in diameter and be grouted to provide a safe, potable water supply. 
(10)  Trunk facilities. Where a larger size water main, sanitary sewer, storm drain or similar facility is required to serve areas outside the subdivision, the larger facility required must be constructed. Additional cost is to be borne by the benefiting properties and the assessments are to be determined accordingly by the council. 
(11)  House services. Each house service shall be run from the main to the property line where a cap or plug shall be placed until the service is extended to the structure. A one-inch type K copper water service, corporation cock, curb box and stop, and four-inch extra heavy cast iron soil pipe sewer service shall be the minimum requirements and may be placed in a common trench. 
(12)  Drainage facilities. Drainage facilities and easements shall be installed so as to adequately provide for the drainage of surface waters; a storm sewer system may be required. Drainageway easements for purposes of floodplain management, proper drainage, prevention of erosion, pedestrian access to water bodies, or other public purpose shall be provided. All such systems shall be in conformity to the community drainage plans and all piping shall provide complete removal and a permanent solution for the removal of drainage water. 
(13)  Utility placement. When practicable and feasible, all utilities shall be placed underground. All underground work shall be completed prior to street surfacing. All utility lines for telephone and electric service shall be placed in rear line easements when carried on overhead poles. 
(14)  Inspection. All required improvements shall be inspected by the engineer during construction at the expense of the subdivider. 
(Code 1982, § 31.081) 
Secs. 62-163-62-185. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VII. - APPEALS AND VARIANCES 

Sec. 62-186. - Recommendation by planning commission. 
(a)  The planning commission may recommend a variance from the minimum standards of this chapter, not procedural provisions, when, in its opinion, undue hardship may result from strict compliance with the terms of this chapter. In recommending any variance, the commission shall prescribe any conditions that it deems necessary to or desirable for the public interest. In making its recommendations, the planning commission shall take into account the nature of the proposed use of land and the existing use of land in the vicinity, the number of persons to reside or work in the proposed subdivision, and the probable effect of the proposed subdivision upon traffic conditions in the vicinity. A variance shall only be recommended when the planning commission finds that: 
(1)  There are special circumstances or conditions affecting the property such that the strict application of the provisions of this chapter would deprive the applicant of the reasonable use of his land. 
(2)  The granting of the variance will not be detrimental to the public health, safety and welfare or injurious to other property in the territory in which the property is situated. 
(3)  The variance is to correct inequities resulting from an extreme physical hardship such as topography, etc. 
(b)  After considerations of the planning commission recommendations, the city council may grant variances subject to the terms of subsections (a)(1) to (a)(3) of this section. 
(Code 1982, § 31.100) 
Sec. 62-187. - Procedures. 
(a)  Requests for a variance or appeal shall be filed with the city administrator on an official application form. Such application shall be accompanied by a fee as established by city council resolution. Such application shall also be accompanied by ten copies of detailed written and graphic materials necessary for the explanation of the request. 
(b)  Upon receiving the application for a variance or appeal, the city administrator shall refer the application, along with all related information, to the planning commission for a report and recommendation to the city council. 
(c)  The planning commission shall consider the variance at its next regular meeting unless the filing date falls within 15 days of such meeting, in which case the request would be placed on the agenda and considered at the regular meeting following the next regular meeting. The city administrator shall refer such application, along with all related information, to the planning commission for consideration and a report and recommendation to the city council. 
(d)  The applicant or a representative thereof shall appear before the planning commission in order to answer questions concerning the proposed variance request. 
(e)  The variance application shall be referred to the city staff for a report and recommendation to be presented to the planning commission. A preliminary draft of the city staff's report and recommendations shall be given to the planning commission at least ten days prior to the meeting at which such report and recommendations are to be presented. The final report and recommendations to the city staff is to be entered in and made a part of the permanent written record of the planning commission meeting. 
(f)  The planning commission and city staff shall have the authority to request additional information from the applicant concerning the variance or to retain expert testimony with the consent and at the expense of the applicant concerning such variance where such information is declared necessary to ensure the preservation of public health, safety and general welfare. 
(g)  The planning commission shall request the city administrator to set a date for a public hearing on the request for variance. Notice of such hearing shall be published in the official newspaper at least ten days prior to such hearing, and individual notices shall be mailed not less than ten days nor more than 30 days prior to the hearing to all owners of property within 500 feet of the parcel included in the request. 
(h)  Failure of a property owner to receive the notice required by this section shall not invalidate any variance proceedings as set forth within this article. 
(i)  The planning commission shall make a finding of fact and recommend such actions or conditions relating to the request for variance as it deems necessary to carry out the intent and purpose of this chapter. Such recommendation shall be in writing and be accompanied by the report and recommendation of the city staff. 
(j)  The city council shall not grant a variance until it has received a report and recommendation thereon from the planning commission and the city staff or until 60 days after the first regular planning commission meeting at which the request was considered. 
(k)  Upon receiving the report and recommendation of the planning commission and city staff, the city council shall set a date for a public hearing on the request for variance or appeal. Notice of such hearing shall be given in the same manner as the hearing provided for by section 62-37. Reports and recommendations received from the planning commission and city staff shall be entered into and made a part of the permanent written record of the city council meeting. 
(l)  Upon receiving the report and recommendation of the planning commission and city staff on the request for variance or appeal, the city council shall make a recorded finding of fact and impose any condition it considers necessary to protect the public health, safety and welfare. 
(m)  The city council shall decide whether to approve or deny a request for a variance or an appeal within 60 days after the public hearing on such request. 
(n)  A variance of this chapter or grant of an appeal shall be by majority vote of the full city council. 
(o)  The city administrator shall notify the originator of the variance or appeal of the city council's decision in writing. 
(Code 1982, § 31.101) 
Chapter 66 - TRAFFIC AND VEHICLES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- House movers, § 22-286 et seq.; placement of travel trailers and travel vehicles regarding flooding, § 34-113; unlicensed vehicles on public property, § 46-12; vehicle restrictions in parks, § 50-64. 
State Law reference- Traffic regulations, M.S.A. ch. 169; local authority, M.S.A. § 169.04. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 66-1. - Minnesota Highway Traffic Regulations Act and Minnesota Drivers' License Law adopted. 
    The regulatory provisions and definitions of the Minnesota Highway Traffic Regulations Act, M.S.A. ch. 169, and the regulatory provisions and definitions of the Minnesota Drivers' License Law, M.S.A. ch. 171, are hereby adopted and shall regulate the use of highways, streets, alleys and other portions of the city and the qualifications of drivers thereon and are hereby incorporated into and made a part of this chapter as completely as if set out in this section in full. 
(Code 1982, § 21.01(a)) 
Sec. 66-2. - Minimum statutory penalty. 
    If a minimum fine or imprisonment is prescribed by M.S.A. ch. 169, such minimum fine or imprisonment shall apply to any person convicted of the same offense under this chapter. 
(Code 1982, § 21.01(e)) 
Sec. 66-3. - Speed limits. 
(a)  Maximum speed. Except in areas where a lesser speed limit is posted, the speed limit within the city shall be 30 miles per hour, and any speed in excess thereof shall be unlawful. 
(b)  Speed in alleys. No person shall operate a motor vehicle in a speed in excess of ten miles per hour in any alley in the city. 
(Code 1982, § 21.01(b), (c)) 
Sec. 66-4. - Unnecessary acceleration. 
    No person shall start or accelerate any motor vehicle with an unnecessary exhibition of speed on any public or private roadway within the city limits. Unreasonable squealing or screeching sounds emitted by the tires, or the throwing of sand or gravel by the tires of such vehicle, or both, shall constitute prima facie evidence of such unnecessary exhibition of speed. 
(Code 1982, § 21.01(d)) 
Sec. 66-5. - Vehicle weight restrictions. 
(a)  Purpose. City council finds that it is necessary to impose restrictions as to weight of vehicles operated upon city roads, whenever any such road, by reason of deterioration, rain, snow, or other climatic conditions, will be seriously damaged or destroyed unless the permissible weight of vehicles thereon is reduced during certain periods. 
(b)  Definitions. The following terms when used in this section shall have the following meanings: 
    All season road means a road not subject to vehicle weight restrictions at any time. 
    Five-ton road means a road, travel upon which during applicable periods is restricted to vehicles with total weight of no greater than five tons per axle. 
    Seven-ton road means a road, travel upon which during applicable periods is restricted to vehicles with total weight of no greater than seven tons per axle. 
(c)  Designation of roads. The city's roads are regulated as follows: 
(1)  All season roads. The following roads are hereby designated as all season roads: 
Road From To Ninth Avenue East Line of Third Street East Line of Lincoln Avenue 11 th Avenue East Line of Third Street Burlington Northern Right-of-Way Robinson Avenue East Line of Third Street East to city limits St. Paul Park Road West Line of Summit Avenue North to city limits Third Street West Line of St. Paul Park Road South Line of 14 th Avenue Sixth Street South Line of 11 th Avenue Approx. 200 feet south of 13 th Avenue Summit Avenue South Line of Broadway Avenue North Line of Robinson Avenue Lincoln Avenue West Line of Hastings Avenue South Line of 18 th Avenue  
(2)  Five-ton roads. All roads not specifically described in this subsection or otherwise excepted are hereby designated as five-ton roads. 
(3)  Seven-ton roads. The following roads are hereby designated as seven-ton roads: 
Road From To Seventh Avenue East Line of Pleasant Ave West Line of Hastings Ave Eighth Avenue East Line of Summit Avenue West Line of Hastings Avenue Ninth Avenue East Line of Lincoln Avenue Line of Robinson Avenue Aurora Avenue West Line of Hastings Avenue North Line of Robinson Avenue  
(d)  Exceptions. All roads under the jurisdiction of any road authority other than the city are excepted from the provisions of this Code and vehicle weight restrictions thereon shall be governed solely by the laws and regulations of that road authority. 
(e)  Restriction periods. The city administrator, with approval of the city council, shall determine the applicable periods for imposing weight restrictions on all city roads. Restrictions shall be posted and otherwise disseminated to the general public in any feasible manner by the city administrator. 
(f)  Broadway Avenue restrictions. 
(1)  Notwithstanding anything herein to the contrary, no commercial motor vehicle, as defined in M.S.A. § 169.011, subdivision 16, as amended from time to time, may travel on Broadway Avenue between Summit Avenue and First Street. The city shall post signs designating St. Paul Park Road and Third Street as the designated commercial motor vehicle routes in accordance with M.S.A. § 169.87, subdivision 1(c), and all commercial motor vehicles shall follow that route. This section shall not apply to the following commercial motor vehicles: 
a.  Commercial motor vehicles making deliveries to or picking up goods for shipment from any business or residence located on Broadway Avenue within the restricted area; or 
b.  Any vehicle defined in M.S.A. § 169.87, subdivisions 3 through 7. 
(2)  The city administrator or designee shall have authority to consider and issue temporary permits, or to temporarily suspend the restrictions contained in paragraph (f) of this section, allowing commercial motor vehicles to operate on the restricted portions of Broadway Avenue when it is determined to be in the best interest of the city. Any suspension or issuance of a temporary permit may be reviewed, modified, or cancelled by the city council. 
(Ord. No. 509, § 1, 11-18-91; Ord. No. 675, § 1, 11-7-11; Ord. No. 718, § 1, 7-20-15; Ord. No. 736, § 1, 4-3-17) 
Sec. 66-6. - Use of public right-of-way. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to conduct business on or store any equipment or other materials of any kind or nature on any public right-of-way which has been opened or prepared for use; provided however, that the sidewalk or boulevard portion of any such right-of-way may be used for the temporary storage of equipment and materials while being loaded or unloaded to or from any motor vehicle. "Right-of-way," as used in this section, shall include the entire portion of any right-of-way lying between private property lines. 
(Code 1982, § 21.09) 
Editor's note- See the editor's note to § 66-134. 
Secs. 66-7-66-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - PARKING, STOPPING AND STANDING[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Stopping, standing and parking, M.S.A. § 169.32 et seq. 

Sec. 66-31. - Congested district parking. 
(a)  Congested district established. There is hereby established a district to be known as a congested district, which includes the following streets: Broadway Avenue between Chicago, Burlington and Quincy right-of-way to Second Street. 
(b)  Limited parking. The council may designate certain blocks or portions thereof within the congested district as 15-minute, 30-minute, one-hour or two-hour limited parking zones, and shall mark by appropriate signs any zone so established. Such zones shall be established in the congested district wherever necessary for a free flow of traffic and to minimize traffic hazards, or for the convenience of the public. 
(c)  Exception. The parking restrictions contained in subsection (b) of this section shall not apply on Sunday nor upon the following listed holidays: New Year's Day, Memorial Day, Independence Day, Labor Day, Thanksgiving and Christmas. 
(Code 1982, § 21.02(b)-(d)) 
Sec. 66-32. - Parking longer than 24 hours prohibited. 
    No vehicle shall be parked upon any street in any one place for a longer period than 24 hours. 
(Code 1982, § 21.02(g)) 
Sec. 66-33. - Through highway designated. 
    Hastings Avenue, between Broadway Avenue and the south city limits, is designated as a through highway. Stop signs shall be erected at all entrances of streets into Hastings Avenue entering between Broadway and the south city limits, excepting therefrom Broadway Avenue. 
(Code 1982, § 21.02(e), (f)) 
Sec. 66-34. - Diagonal parking. 
    Diagonal parking spaces shall be limited to the use of vehicles or a combination of vehicles and/or trailers not exceeding 20 feet overall in length; provided, that this restriction shall not apply to vehicles or a combination of vehicles and/or trailers while being loaded or unloaded. 
(Code 1982, § 21.02(i)) 
Sec. 66-35. - Prohibited parking areas. 
(a)  No vehicle shall be parked at any time on the west half of Fifth Street between the south boundary of the improved portion of 11th Avenue and the north boundary of lot 12, block 94, division no. 4 of the city. 
(b)  No vehicle shall be parked at any time on Front Street between Seventh Avenue and Eighth Avenue. 
(c)  No vehicle shall be parked at any time on Factory Street between Seventh Avenue and Eighth Avenue. 
(d)  No vehicle shall be parked at any time on Seventh Avenue west of Main Street. 
(e)  No vehicle shall be parked at any time on Front Street from Seventh Avenue to a distance 300 feet north of Seventh Avenue. 
(f)  No vehicle shall be parked at any time on Ninth Avenue west of Main Street. 
(g)  No vehicle shall be parked from 11:00 p.m. to 5:00 a.m. on the city boat launch premises located on block 54, division no. 2 of the city, being more particularly described as follows: 
The north half of block 55, division no. 2 of the city; 
All that part of the south 200 feet of block 53 lying east of the following described line: beginning at a point on the south line of said block 53, which is 400 feet west of the southeast corner thereof, and thence north 45 degrees east to a point on a line which is parallel with and 200 feet north of the south line of said block 53; 
All in division no. 2 of the city. 
Emergency vehicles or vehicles which have the consent of the city to be parked upon such premises are excepted from this subsection. 
(h)  No vehicle shall be parked at any time on the west half of First Street between Broadway Avenue and Seventh Avenue 
(i)  No vehicle shall be parked at any time near the standpipe for 644 2 nd Street located on the east half of Second Street between Broadway Avenue and Seventh Avenue, approximately 85 feet north of Seventh Avenue for a distance of approximately 20 feet. 
(j)  No vehicle shall be parked more than 90 minutes at any time between the hours of 6:00 a.m. and 5:00 p.m. on Monday through Friday on the west half of Second Street between Broadway Avenue and Seventh Avenue except for the location near the standpipe for 625 2 nd Street, approximately 318 feet north of Seventh Avenue for a distance of approximately 36 feet in which no vehicle shall be parked at any time. 
(k)  No vehicle shall be parked at any time on Seventh Avenue between First Street and Second Street. 
(Code 1982, § 21.02(j); Ord. No. 531, § 1, 4-18-94; Ord. No. 534, § 1, 6-6-94; Ord. No. 699, § 1, 8-19-13; Ord. No. 707, § 1, 2, 6-2-14) 
Sec. 66-36. - Removal, impoundment of motor vehicles. 
(a)  Authority to remove. 
(1)  Any vehicle, wherever found, whether on public or private property, in violation of the ordinances of the city or the laws of the state, is hereby declared to be a nuisance, and such vehicle may be summarily abated by or under the direction or at the request of a police officer to a place of storage, by means of a towing truck or otherwise in accordance with M.S.A. § 169.041, or the police officer may require the driver or owner to remove such vehicle off the paved or traveled portion of a street. 
(2)  Any vehicle found upon the streets of the city in such a damaged condition or state of disrepair that it cannot be driven and which, in the opinion of a police officer, constitutes an obstruction of the street, may be removed and impounded by the police department to a place of storage; provided, that if the owner or operator thereof has so requested, such vehicle may be towed to the owner's own or any other garage. 
(b)  Recovery of impounded vehicles. Before the owner or his agent shall be permitted to remove a vehicle impounded under this section from its place of storage, he shall: 
(1)  Furnish satisfactory evidence to the chief of police and the person in charge of such storage area of his identity and ownership of such vehicle. 
(2)  Pay to the person in charge of such storage all charges for the towing and storage of such vehicle. 
(3)  Sign a written receipt for such vehicle. 
(c)  Prosecution for violations. The removal of a vehicle which is parked in violation of an ordinance of the city or the laws of the state shall not prevent the prosecution for violation of such laws. 
(Code 1982, § 21.05) 
Sec. 66-37. - Truck, tractor and semitrailer parking in residential areas prohibited. 
(a)  Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this section, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Semitrailer means a vehicle of the trailer type so designed and used in conjunction with a truck-tractor that a considerable part of its own weight or that of its load rests upon and is carried by the truck-tractor and shall include a trailer drawn by a truck-tractor semitrailer combination as defined in M.S.A. § 168.002(30). 
    Truck means any truck licensed by any state exceeding a gross weight of 12,000 pounds as defined in M.S.A. § 168.002(13). 
    Truck-Tractor means a motor vehicle designed and used primarily for drawing other vehicles and not constructed to carry a load other than part of the weight of the vehicle and load draw; and a motor vehicle designed and used primarily for drawing other vehicles used exclusively for transporting motor vehicles or boats and capable of carrying motor vehicles or boats on its own structure as defined in M.S.A. § 168.002(38). 
(b)  Except as provided in subsection (c) of this section, it shall be unlawful for any truck, tractor and semitrailer to park on any street within the city located in any residence district for a period of longer than 15 minutes. 
(c)  This section shall not apply to any truck parked temporarily on any street in any residence district when necessary for the purpose of delivering any materials or the furnishing of any service to the occupant of any building within the city. 
(d)  It shall be unlawful to park or to leave standing on any public street, any nonmotorized vehicle or component part thereof, such as dumpsters and trailers separate from cab, without first obtaining permission from the chief of police of the city. 
(e)  Any vehicle or equipment parked, stopped or standing on residential property in violation of this section as of June 1, 1996, shall be removed from the property no later than June 1, 1999; provided that no such vehicle or equipment shall be permitted to remain on residential property after June 1, 1996, unless the owner has obtained a permit from the city administrator allowing such parking until June 1, 1999. No such permit shall be issued unless the owner agrees in writing to remove the vehicle or equipment no later than June 1, 1999. Such permit may be transferred to apply to a replacement vehicle or piece of equipment. No more than one vehicle or piece of equipment shall be allowed on a single parcel of property. 
(f)  It shall be unlawful for any truck, tractor, or semitrailer to operate in any residential district except vehicles engaged in delivery of goods or providing services in the residential area. Truck, tractor and semitrailers are prohibited from operating in residential districts for the purpose of drivers training. 
(Code 1982, § 21.03; Ord. No. 585, § 1, 7-7-03; Ord. No. 655, §§ 1, 2, 4-5-10) 
Sec. 66-38. - Municipal parking lots. 
(a)  No vehicle shall be parked within the limits of any designated municipal parking lot for a period longer than 48 hours. 
(b)  Municipal parking lots are designated for the parking of passenger vehicles only. No semitrailer or tractor or combination thereof shall be parked within the limits of any municipal parking lot, and no vehicle shall be parked within the limits of any municipal parking lot for the purpose of repair, either private or commercial. 
(Code 1982, § 21.04) 
Sec. 66-39. - Parking ban for snow removal. 
(a)  Between November 1 and April 1 next following, no vehicle shall be left standing or parked on the streets of the city between the hours of 2:00 a.m. and 6:00 a.m. on any day. At all other hours during such period, on-street parking shall be permitted only when such parking does not interfere with the removal of snow and ice from the city streets. 
(b)  All emergency and official vehicles, including doctors' automobiles responding to an emergency call, shall be excluded from the provisions of this section. 
(c)  Whenever any motor vehicle shall be parked or left standing within the city by any person other than the owner, with the consent of the owner, express or implied, the operator thereof shall be deemed to be the agent of the owner of such motor vehicle for the purposes of this section. 
(Code 1982, § 21.10) 
Secs. 66-40-66-60. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - ABANDONED MOTOR VEHICLES[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Cross reference- Nuisances, § 26-31 et seq. 
State Law reference- Towing of abandoned vehicles authorized, M.S.A. § 169.041. 

Sec. 66-61. - Findings and purpose. 
    Abandoned motor vehicles constitute a hazard to the health and welfare of the people of the city in that such vehicles can harbor noxious diseases, furnish shelter and breeding places for vermin, and present physical dangers to the safety and well-being of the children of the citizens. Abandoned motor vehicles and other scrap metals also constitute a blight on the landscape of the city and, therefore, a detriment to the environment. The abandonment and retirement of motor vehicles and other scrap metals constitutes a waste of a valuable source of useful metal. It is, therefore, in the public interest that the present accumulation of abandoned motor vehicles and other scrap metals be eliminated and that future abandonment of motor vehicles and other scrap metals be prevented. 
(Code 1982, § 21.06(a)) 
Sec. 66-62. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Abandoned motor vehicle means a motor vehicle as defined in this section that has remained for a period of more than 48 hours on public property illegally or lacking vital component parts, or has remained for a period of more than 48 hours on private property without consent of the person in control of such property or in an inoperable condition such that it has no substantial potential for the use consistent with its usual functions, unless it is kept in an enclosed garage or storage building. Such term shall also mean a motor vehicle voluntarily surrendered by its owner to the city. A classic car or pioneer car, as defined in M.S.A. § 168.10, shall not be considered an abandoned motor vehicle within the meaning of this article. For the purpose of this article, any vehicle moved a distance of not more than two blocks during such 48-hour period shall be deemed to have remained stationary. 
    Motor vehicle means every device in, upon or by which any person is or may be transported or drawn upon a highway, which device is self-propelled and not deriving its power from overhead wires; except devices moved by human power or used exclusively upon stationary rails or tracks. 
(Code 1982, § 21.06(b)) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 66-63. - Taking into custody. 
    The police department of the city may take into custody and impound any abandoned motor vehicle found within the city. 
(Code 1982, § 21.06(c)) 
Sec. 66-64. - Immediate sale. 
(a)  When an abandoned motor vehicle is more than seven model years of age, is lacking vital component parts, and does not display a license plate currently valid in this state or any other state or foreign country, it shall immediately be eligible for sale at public auction, and shall not be subject to the notification, reclamation, or title provisions of subsection (b) of this section and sections 66-65 and 66-66. 
(b)  When an abandoned motor vehicle does not fall within the provisions of subsection (a) of this section, the police department shall give notice of the taking thereof within ten days thereafter. The notice shall set forth the date and place of the taking, the year, the make, model and serial number of the abandoned motor vehicle, and the place where the vehicle is being held; shall inform the owner and any lienholders of their right to reclaim such vehicle pursuant to section 66-65 and shall state that the failure of the owner or lienholders to exercise the right to reclaim the vehicle shall be deemed a waiver by them of all right, title and interest in the vehicle and a consent to the sale of the vehicle at a public auction pursuant to section 66-66. The notice shall be sent by mail to the registered owner, if any, of the abandoned motor vehicle and to all readily identifiable lienholders of record. If it is impossible to determine with reasonable certainty the identity and address of the registered owner and all lienholders, the notice shall be published once in the official newspaper of the city. Published notices may be grouped together for convenience and economy. 
(Code 1982, § 21.06(d)) 
Sec. 66-65. - Right to reclaim. 
(a)  The owner or any lienholder of an abandoned motor vehicle shall have a right to reclaim such vehicle from the unit of government taking it into custody upon the payment of all towing and storage charges resulting from taking the vehicle into custody within 15 days after the date of notice required by section 66-64. 
(b)  Nothing in this article shall be construed to impair any lien of a garagekeeper under the laws of the state or the right of a lienholder to foreclose its lien. For the purposes of this section, "garagekeeper" is an operator of a parking place or establishment, an operator of a motor vehicle storage facility or an operator of an establishment for the servicing, repair or maintenance of motor vehicles. 
(Code 1982, § 21.06(e)) 
Sec. 66-66. - Sale of unclaimed vehicles; disposition of proceeds. 
(a)  An abandoned motor vehicle taken into custody and not reclaimed under section 66-65 shall be sold to the highest bidder at public auction or sale, following reasonable published notice thereof. The purchaser shall be given a receipt in a form prescribed by the state pollution control agency which shall be sufficient title to dispose of the vehicle. 
(b)  From the proceeds of the sale of an abandoned motor vehicle, the city shall reimburse itself for the cost of towing, preserving or storing the vehicle, and all notice of publication costs incurred pursuant to the terms of sections 66-63-66-66. Any remainder from the proceeds of the sale shall be held for the owner of the vehicle or entitled lienholder for 90 days and then shall be deposited in the city treasury. 
(Code 1982, § 21.06(f)) 
Sec. 66-67. - Disposal of vehicles not sold. 
(a)  Where no bid has been received for an abandoned motor vehicle, the city may dispose of such vehicle pursuant to a contract entered into under the provisions of subsection (b) of this section. 
(b)  Contracts for disposal. 
(1)  The city shall contract with any qualified person for collection, storage, volume reduction, transportation, or other services necessary to prepare abandoned motor vehicles and other scrap metal for recycling or other methods of disposal. Such contract shall only be entered into with a person in possession of a valid license for solid waste disposal issued by the state pollution control agency. 
(2)  All contracts entered into by the city with any person pursuant to the terms of subsection (b)(1) of this section shall be sent to the state pollution control agency for review and their determination as to whether such contract conforms to the agency's plan for solid waste disposal. 
(Code 1982, § 21.06(g), (h)) 
Secs. 66-68-66-90. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - RECREATIONAL VEHICLES 

Sec. 66-91. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Private property means all lands other than public property. 
    Public property means all lands owned by the United States, this state or any political subdivision thereof. 
    Recreational motor vehicles means any motor vehicle designed for, used, or capable of use for sport, amusement or recreation, whether or not eligible to be licensed for use upon streets and highways, including, but not limited to, motorbikes, motor scooters, trailbikes, minibikes, motorcycles, go-carts, hovercraft, snowmobiles converted to use with wheels, all-terrain vehicles or dune buggies, but excluding motor vehicles designed for commercial, industrial or agricultural use and snowmobiles propelled by tracks but including those vehicles described in M.S.A. § 84.90, subd. 1. 
(Code 1982, § 21.07(a)) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 66-92. - Areas of operation. 
    It shall be unlawful to operate a recreational motor vehicle within the city: 
(1)  Upon private property without the written permission of the owner or person entitled to possession thereof; provided, however, that this subsection shall not apply to motor vehicles registered under M.S.A. ch. 168, when operated by a driver licensed under M.S.A. ch. 171 upon private driveways, roadways, lanes, ways or parking lots where the operation of licensed motor vehicles is not expressly prohibited by posted notice. 
(2)  Upon any school grounds, public park, playground, recreational area, golf course, or other public property, except at such times and places as the governing body having jurisdiction over such area may authorize or designate; provided, however, no operation whatsoever shall be allowed on the foregoing areas or places described in this subsection if: 
a.  The operator of the recreational motor vehicle is less than 12 years of age; or 
b.  The recreational motor vehicle does not bear a registration tag evidencing registration pursuant to M.S.A. ch. 168. 
(3)  Upon any public sidewalk, walkway or boulevard. 
(4)  Upon the right-of-way of any public street or highway unless: 
a.  The recreational motor vehicle is licensed under M.S.A. ch. 168; 
b.  The operator is licensed under M.S.A. ch. 171; and 
c.  The vehicle is operated upon the improved portion of the right-of-way. 
(Code 1982, § 21.07(b)) 
Sec. 66-93. - Hours of operation. 
    Except for licensed motor vehicles operated upon streets or highways by licensed operators, no recreational motor vehicle shall be operated between the hours of 9:00 p.m. and 8:00 a.m. upon any public property. 
(Code 1982, § 21.07(c)) 
Sec. 66-94. - Movement of unlicensed vehicles. 
    No unlicensed recreational motor vehicle may be moved along or across a street or highway with a person seated thereon, whether or not the engine is operating. Any such vehicle may be moved along or across a street or highway by pushing, and only when doing so does not create a hazard to moving vehicular traffic on the street or highway. 
(Code 1982, § 21.07(d)) 
Sec. 66-95. - Noise limits. 
    Recreational motor vehicles shall meet the noise limits established for motorcycles pursuant to M.S.A. ch. 169. 
(Code 1982, § 21.07(f)) 
Sec. 66-96. - Operation of motorized golf carts and four-wheel, all-terrain vehicles on city streets. 
(a)  The provisions of M.S.A. § 169.045, subds. 1, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7 and 8, are hereby adopted by reference thereto and made a part of this Code. 
(b)  In addition to the statutory provisions adopted in subsection (a) of this section, the following additional provisions shall apply: 
(1)  Permits for operation of a motorized golf cart or four-wheel all-terrain vehicle on city streets shall be issued by the city administrator upon application of any person desiring a permit. All applications shall be accompanied by evidence of insurance complying with the provisions of M.S.A. § 65B.48, subd. 5, and shall also be accompanied by the certificate of a licensed physician, attesting that the applicant is able to safely operate a motorized golf cart or four-wheel all-terrain vehicle on the roadways for which application is made. Prior to issuance, all applications for such permits shall be referred to the chief of police for approval of the roadways designated within the application. In granting or withholding approval, the chief of police shall consider the needs of the applicant, as well as the welfare and safety of the applicant and others. 
(2)  All permits issued under this section shall expire on the last day in their year of issue, and may be renewed annually thereafter, provided that evidence of required insurance and a currently dated physician's certificate must accompany the renewal application. The permit fee shall be established by the city council, by ordinance or resolution. The fee for permits issued for less than a full calendar year shall be prorated. 
(c)  Subject to future amendment by ordinance or resolution of the city council, the fee for a permit to operate a motorized golf cart or four-wheel all-terrain vehicle upon the city roadways shall be the sum of $25.00, prorated for any permit issued for the period of less than one full calendar year. 
(d)  Any person violating any provision of this section shall, upon conviction thereof, be subject to the penalties set forth in section 1-13 of this Code. 
(Ord. No. 504, §§ 1-3, 6-17-91) 
Secs. 66-97-66-130. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - SNOWMOBILES 

Sec. 66-131. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Operate means to ride in or on and control the operation of a snowmobile. 
    Operator means every person who operates or is in actual physical control of a snowmobile. 
    Owner means a person other than a lienholder having the property in or title to a snowmobile, entitled to the use or possession thereof. 
    Roadway means that portion of a street or highway improved, designed or ordinarily used for vehicular travel. 
    Snowmobile means a self-propelled vehicle designed for travel on snow or ice or on natural terrain, steered by skis or runners. 
    Street means a platted street or alley. 
(Code 1982, § 21.08(a)) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 66-132. - Operation on streets and highways. 
(a)  No person shall operate a snowmobile upon the roadway shoulder or inside bank or slope of any street within the city, except as provided in this article. 
(b)  A snowmobile may be driven on the streets within the city between the residence of the operator and any public or private property upon which the operation of a snowmobile is permitted, provided: 
(1)  The route used shall be the most direct route between the residence of the operator and the place of operation of such snowmobile; 
(2)  The driver shall yield the right-of-way to all pedestrian and vehicular traffic; and 
(3)  No snowmobile shall be driven upon any streets within the city at a speed in excess of ten miles per hour. 
(c)  No snowmobile shall be operated upon a public street unless it is equipped with at least one headlamp and one taillamp, and with brakes which conform to standards prescribed by a rule of the state commissioner of highways pursuant to the authority vested in him by law. 
(d)  A snowmobile may be operated upon a public street other than as provided by subsection (b) of this section in an emergency during the period of time when and at locations where snow upon the roadway renders travel by automobile impractical. 
(e)  All provisions of section 66-1 shall apply to the operation of snowmobiles upon streets within the city, except for those relating to required equipment, not required by the terms of this article, and except those which, by their nature, have no application. 
(f)  All snowmobiles operated within the city shall be equipped with a muffler in good operating condition and of the type and design as specified as original equipment by the manufacturer of such snowmobile, or equivalent thereto. 
(Code 1982, § 21.08(b)) 
Sec. 66-133. - Hours of operation. 
    It shall be lawful to operate a snowmobile within the limits of the city only between the hours of 7:00 a.m. to 10:00 p.m. on Sundays through Thursdays, and only between 7:00 a.m. to 12:00 midnight on Fridays and Saturdays. The only exception to such time limitations will be for the purpose of returning to the residence of the operator by the most direct route at a speed not exceeding ten miles per hour. All other hours of operation are unlawful. 
(Code 1982, § 21.08(c)) 
Sec. 66-134. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 706, § 1, adopted March 3, 2014, renumbered the former § 66-134 as § 66-6. The historical notation has been retained with the amended provisions for reference purposes. 
Chapter 70 - UTILITIES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Public works commission, § 2-221 et seq.; buildings and building regulations, ch. 18; gas installers, § 22-156 et seq.; house movers, § 22-286 et seq.; standards for public utilities regarding flooding, § 34-112; sewer and water connections regarding excavations, § 58-58. 
State Law reference- Authority to build and maintain waterworks systems and sewage disposal plants, M.S.A. § 444.075. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 70-1-70-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - WATER SYSTEM 

Sec. 70-31. - Application for connection permit. 
(a)  Any party desiring water service from the water system of this city for premises not theretofore connected with the system shall apply for a connection permit on a form provided by the public works supervisor. Such application shall state an exact description of the premises to be served, the uses, both general and special, to which the water is to be put, and the estimated amount of water to be used per quarterly period. Such application shall be filed with the public works supervisor, and the applicant, in addition to any other amounts due under the provisions of subsection (b) or (c) of this section, shall pay to the public works supervisor the connection permit fee set forth in chapter 42 of this Code. All such permits shall expire 90 days after the date issued and a new permit shall be required for any unfinished work covered by such permit. 
(b)  If application is made for water service to property which, prior to the date of such application, has never been assessed by the city for benefits accruing to such property for the construction of the city water system and general appurtenances thereto, then and in every such event, no permit shall be issued for the connection of such property to the city water system unless, prior thereto, the applicant shall pay to the city administrator such amount as may be determined by the city council to be the just and equitable benefit which has accrued to such property by virtue of the construction of the city water system and appurtenances thereto. 
(c)  If application is made for water service to property which, prior to the date of such application, has been assessed for benefits accruing thereto for construction of the city water system and general appurtenances thereto and which assessments have been cancelled, prior to full payment, by action other than official action of the city council, then and in every such event, no permit shall be issued for connection of such property to the city water system unless, prior thereto, the applicant shall pay to the city administrator the total unpaid balance of such assessment, together with interest thereon from the date of such cancellation to the date of such application. 
(d)  Once a connection to the city's water system has been established, it cannot be terminated nor a well established to furnish the property with water for primary use. 
(Code 1982, § 25.010; Ord. No. 672, § 1, 6-6-11) 
Sec. 70-32. - Application for water service. 
    Any party desiring water service for premises where a connection has been made pursuant to section 72-31 shall make written application therefor as in cases described in section 72-31, but no additional charge for such connection shall be required. 
(Code 1982, § 25.011) 
Sec. 70-33. - Meter fees. 
(a)  At the time of filing any application under sections 70-31 and 70-32, the applicant shall pay to the public works department a meter service and maintenance fee in the amount set forth in chapter 42 of this Code. 
(b)  All water meters shall be owned and installed by the city and shall be open to the inspection of the public works department, or other authorized city officers, at all reasonable times. 
(Code 1982, § 25.012; Ord. No. 593, § 1, 7-21-03) 
Sec. 70-34. - Separate meter and curb cock required. 
    Unless special permission is granted by the public works department, each premises shall have a separate and distinct service connection, and where permission is granted for branch service systems, each branch system must have its own separate meter and separate curb cock to be installed at the curbline. 
(Code 1982, § 25.013) 
Sec. 70-35. - Consumer's expenses. 
    The cost of the original installation of all plumbing between the water main in the street and any service devices maintained by the consumer and all extensions made to such plumbing, as well as all repairs and maintenance, shall be borne entirely by the consumer, although such plumbing and services, as well as the meters, shall at all reasonable times be subject to inspection by duly authorized representatives of the city. Any repairs found to be necessary by such representative shall be made promptly or the city will discontinue service. 
(Code 1982, § 25.014; Ord. No. 631, § 1, 6-18-07; Ord. No. 709, § 1, 8-4-14) 
Sec. 70-36. - Meter placement, testing. 
    A meter shall be located in accordance with the provisions of section 70-34. If at any time the consumer desires to have the meter tested for accuracy, such testing shall be done by the city and a fee of $20.00 charged therefor to the consumer. If the meter registers less than 98 percent to 102 percent accurate, it shall be replaced by the city at no cost and the testing fee shall be refunded. If any meter shall be damaged by lack of proper care by the consumer, the cost of repairing or replacing the meter shall be charged to and paid by the consumer. 
(Code 1982, § 25.015) 
Sec. 70-37. - Tampering with meters prohibited. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to use water from any premises without the consent of the owner, or to use water from the city water system except as may be drawn through a meter installed by the city. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person, except an authorized representative of the public works department, to turn on or off or tamper with any curb cock or water meter. 
(c)  The owner of any building, or the occupant of any building if not the owner, in which a water meter is located shall be responsible for all damages resulting from any misuse of, or tampering with, any water meter located therein, and shall ensure that all seals of such water meters remain intact and unbroken. If any seal is broken or any water meter is damaged by misuse of, or tampering with, any such water meter, the owner or occupant of the building in which such meter is located shall pay all costs of repair of such meter, and addition thereto, a penalty in the amount of $200.00. Failure to pay any costs of repair or penalty shall be grounds for discontinuance of service to the premises. 
(Code 1982, § 25.016) 
Sec. 70-38. - Claims for defective service. 
    All claims for defective water service shall be made in writing and filed with the city administrator or public works supervisor on or before the tenth day of the month next succeeding such defective service, or be deemed waived by the claimant; and if any such claim is so filed, it shall be the duty of the public works supervisor to investigate the facts alleged in such claim and determine the amount, if any, which should be refunded to such claimant by reason of such defective service, and report such determination to the city council, and if approved by that body, such amount shall be allowed as a credit on the following bill or paid as other claims; but no claim shall be made against the city for any fire losses or any injuries to the person or property of any consumer of water under this article by reason of defective service. 
(Code 1982, § 25.017) 
Sec. 70-39. - Consent to rules and regulations. 
    Every person applying for water service from the city system and every owner of property for which such application is made shall be deemed by such application to consent to all the rules, regulations and rates contained in the codes of the city and to all modifications thereof and to all new rules, regulations, or rates duly adopted. 
(Code 1982, § 25.018) 
Sec. 70-40. - Discontinuance of service. 
    The city reserves the right to discontinue service to any or all customers of the water system without notice, when necessary for repairs or for nonpayment of bills or for disregard of regulations; such service shall not be resumed except upon payment of the bills, together with interest thereon, full compliance with the regulations and the payment to the public works department of the appropriate reconnection charge. 
(Code 1982, § 25.019) 
Sec. 70-41. - Certain work to be done by licensed plumbers. 
    All work in connection with street excavations, installation of all pipes from main to curb, installation of curb cocks and curb boxes shall be performed only by a duly licensed plumber. 
(Code 1982, § 25.0110) 
Sec. 70-42. - Construction of service pipes. 
    All service pipes connected with the water system shall be type K copper tube and shall be laid seven feet below the established grades, or as low as the street mains. 
(Code 1982, § 25.0111) 
Sec. 70-43. - Location of curb cocks. 
    All corporation cocks shall be Mueller thread and shall be tapped in only by employees of the public works department. The licensed plumber shall make all excavations and shall install pipe from the main to a point one foot from the property line and at this point shall install T-handled Minneapolis pattern curb stop. The curb stop shall be installed in a 11/2-inch or larger adjustable curb box equal to Mueller type H10302. There shall be a gate valve or equal on each side of the meter, the valve on the street side to be two feet from the point of entrance, and on the house side of meter there shall be installed a swing-check valve or equal. 
(Code 1982, § 25.0112) 
Sec. 70-44. - Outside meter registers. 
    Remote outside meter registers shall be installed on all new meter installations and on all present premises served by the city water system. Remote registers shall be installed at eye level on the end or at the rear of the building in a location agreeable to the owner and the public works supervisor, and shall be accessible to the meter reader at all times. A fee equal to the nearest plus dollar of the current cost of such remote meter register shall be charged to the owner of the premises by the city and shall be paid in cash to the city by the owner of such premises. 
(Code 1982, § 25.0113) 
Sec. 70-45. - Water shortage emergency. 
(a)  Because critical shortages of water may result from time to time and such shortages may come about suddenly, emergency procedures are hereby established. These procedures shall be followed at all times when the emergency board, as established in this section, or the council, determines that an emergency exists. 
(b)  The emergency board shall consist of the mayor, city administrator, and public works supervisor. 
(c)  Whenever, in the judgment of any two or more members of the emergency board, the pressures or quantities of water in any part of the city water system have become or are about to become inadequate for fire or other needs, a water emergency shall be declared by posted notice within the city and by announcement through such other avenues of communication as may be available. Upon posting of such notice, sprinkling of all lawns within the city shall be restricted so that property with addresses that end with an odd number may be sprinkled only on odd-numbered days, and property with addresses that end with an even number may be sprinkled only on even-numbered days. Such emergency shall continue until notice of termination of such emergency shall have been given in the same manner as notice declaring such water emergency. 
(d)  In addition to penalties otherwise provided in this article, the public works supervisor shall have authority to discontinue water service to any property where the occupant thereof is found violating the terms of any provision of this article. 
(Code 1982, § 25.0114) 
Sec. 70-46. - Rates and charges for water service. 
(a)  Rates and charges for water service supplied by the city shall be as follows: 
(1)  The first 8,000 gallons per quarter ..... $28.14 
(2)  All gallons in excess of 8,000 per quarter, per 1,000 gallons ..... 2.56 
(3)  All gallons in excess of 25,000 per quarter, per 1,000 gallons ..... 2.84 
(4)  Minimum charge per quarter ..... 28.14 
(5)  In addition to the rates and charges set forth in paragraphs (a)(1), (2), (3) and (4), each premises shall pay a basic water service fee of $4.54 per quarter. 
(b)  All bills computed by application of the rates and charges set forth in subsection (a) of this section for water and water service supplied by the city for any residence in which the head of the household is 65 years of age or older and which residence uses less than 8,000 gallons per quarter, shall be reduced by 50 percent. 
(c)  A resident qualifying for the rate set forth in subsection (b) of this section must file annually, between October 1 and November 1, an affidavit with the city council stating that the owner and head of such household is 65 years of age or older. This discounted rate does not apply to rental property or multiple family dwellings. 
(Code 1982, § 25.0115; Ord. No. 484, § 1, 9-18-89; Ord. No. 537, § 1, 9-6-94; Ord. No. 539, § 1, 9-5-95; Ord. No. 572, § 1, 12-4-00; Ord. No. 598, § 1, 12-15-03; Ord. No. 613, § 1, 6-20-05; Ord. No. 638, § 1, 12-1-08; Ord. No. 649, § 1, 9-8-09; Ord. No. 662, § 1, 9-7-10; Ord. No. 674, § 1, 9-6-11; Ord. No. 686, § 1, 9-4-12; Ord. No. 703, § 1, 12-2-13; Ord. No. 723, § 1, 12-21-15; Ord. No. 733, § 1, 12-19-16; Ord. No. 739, § 1, 10-16-17)
