d.  The provisions of section 74-91(e) are considered and satisfactorily met. 
(3)  Preschools accessory to established public and private educational institutions or religious institutions. 
(4)  Residential planned unit developments, as regulated by section 74-66 through 74-69 provided no flexibilities are granted beyond subdivision right-of-way widths and the standards found in section 74-391. 
(Code 1982, § 15.173; Ord. No. 654, § 3, 2-16-10; Ord. No. 698, § 1, 6-17-13; Ord. No. 700, § 2, 9-16-13) 
Sec. 74-390. - Interim use permits. 
    Reserved. 
(Ord. No. 700, § 2, 9-16-13) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 700, § 2, adopted September 16, 2013, created a new § 74-391 as herein set out and renumbered the former §§ 74-390, 74-391 as §§ 74-391, 74-392. 
Sec. 74-391. - Lot and building requirements and setbacks. 
    The following minimum requirements shall be observed in an R-1 district, subject to additional requirements, exceptions and modifications set forth in this chapter: 
(1)  Lot area: 9,000 square feet. 
(2)  Lot width: 75 feet. 
(3)  Setbacks. 
a.  Front yards: Not less than 30 feet. 
b.  Side yards: 
1.  Interior lots: Not less than five feet on any one side. 
2.  Corner lots: Not less than five feet on the interior side, nor less than 30 feet on the side yard abutting a public street right-of-way. 
c.  Rear yards: 30 feet. 
(4)  Building height: No structure in an R-1 district shall exceed three stories or 35 feet in height, whichever is least. 
(Code 1982, § 15.174; Ord. No. 700, § 2, 9-16-13; Ord. No. 731, § 2, 11-21-16) 
Sec. 74-392. - Garage requirement. 
    All single family homes shall be constructed with a minimum 440 square foot garage for each unit. 
(Code 1982, § 15.175; Ord. No. 700, § 2, 9-16-13) 
Secs. 74-393-74-420. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - R-2 SINGLE- AND TWO-FAMILY RESIDENTIAL DISTRICT 

Sec. 74-421. - Purpose. 
    The purpose of the R-2, single- and two-family residential district is to provide for low to moderate density one-unit and two-unit dwellings and directly related, complementary uses. 
(Code 1982, § 15.18) 
Sec. 74-422. - Permitted uses. 
    The following are permitted uses in an R-2 district: 
(1)  All permitted uses allowed in an R-1 district. 
(2)  Two-family dwelling units. 
(Code 1982, § 15.181) 
Sec. 74-423. - Accessory uses. 
    The following are permitted accessory uses in an R-2 district: All accessory uses as allowed in an R-1 district. 
(Code 1982, § 15.182) 
Sec. 74-424. - Conditional uses. 
    The following are conditional uses in an R-2 district requiring a conditional use permit based upon the procedures set forth in and regulated by section 74-91 et seq.: 
(1)  All conditional uses, subject to the same conditions as allowed in an R-1 district. 
(2)  Manufactured home parks meeting the standards of section 74-391 for each unit and 74-516. 
(Code 1982, § 15.183; Ord. No. 700, § 3, 9-16-13) 
Sec. 74-425. - Interim uses. 
    Reserved. 
(Ord. No. 700, § 3, 9-16-13) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 700, § 3, adopted September 16, 2013, created a new § 74-425 as herein set out, and renumbered the former § 74-425 as § 74-426. 
Sec. 74-426. - Lot and building requirements and setbacks. 
    The following minimum requirements shall be observed in an R-2 district, subject to additional requirements, exceptions and modifications set forth in this chapter: 
(1)  Lot area: 
a.  Single-family dwellings, 9,000 square feet. 
b.  Two-family dwellings, 12,000 square feet. 
(2)  Lot width: 
a.  Single-family dwellings, 75 feet. 
b.  Two-family dwellings, 100 feet. 
(3)  Setbacks. 
a.  Front yards: Not less than 30 feet. 
b.  Side yards: 
1.  Interior lots: Not less than five feet on any one side. 
2.  Corner lots: Not less than five feet on the interior side, nor less than 30 feet on the side yard abutting a public street right-of-way. 
c.  Rear yards: 30 feet. 
(4)  Building height: No structure in an R-2 district shall exceed three stories or 35 feet in height, whichever is least. 
(Code 1982, § 15.184; Ord. No. 700, § 3, 9-16-13; Ord. No. 731, § 3, 11-21-16) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 700, § 3, adopted September 16, 2013, repealed the former § 74-426 and renumbered the former § 74-425 as § 74-426 as set out herein. The former § 74-426 pertained to building height and derived from Code 1982, § 15.185. 
Sec. 74-427. - Garage requirement. 
    All single and two-family homes shall be constructed with a minimum 440 square foot garage for each unit. 
(Code 1982, § 15.186; Ord. No. 700, § 3, 9-16-13) 
Secs. 74-428-74-450. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - R-3 MEDIUM DENSITY RESIDENTIAL DISTRICT 

Sec. 74-451. - Purpose. 
    The purpose of the R-3, medium density residential district is to provide for medium density housing in small apartment structures ranging up to and including six units and directly related, complementary uses. 
(Code 1982, § 15.190) 
Sec. 74-452. - Permitted uses. 
    The following are permitted uses in an R-3 district: 
(1)  Multiple-family dwelling structures containing six or less dwelling units. 
(2)  State licensed residential facilities serving up to 16 residents. 
(3)  Public parks and playgrounds. 
(4)  Essential services. 
(Code 1982, § 15.191; Ord. No. 700, § 4, 9-16-13) 
Sec. 74-453. - Accessory uses. 
    The following are permitted accessory uses in an R-3 district: 
(1)  All permitted accessory uses allowed in an R-2 district. 
(2)  Off-street loading. 
(3)  State licensed day care facilities serving up to 16 persons. 
(Code 1982, § 15.192; Ord. No. 700, § 4, 9-16-13) 
Sec. 74-454. - Conditional uses. 
    The following are conditional uses in an R-3 district, requiring a conditional use permit based upon the procedures set forth in and regulated by section 74-91 et seq.: 
(1)  All conditional uses allowed in an R-2 district. 
(2)  Day care and group nursery, provided that: 
a.  No overnight facilities are provided for the children served; children are delivered and removed daily. 
b.  The front yard depth shall be a minimum of 35 feet. 
c.  Adequate off-street parking and access is provided in compliance with article V. 
d.  Adequate off-street loading and service entrances are provided in compliance with article VI. 
e.  The site and related parking and service shall be served by an arterial or collector street of sufficient capacity to accommodate the traffic which will be generated. 
f.  All signing and informational or visual communications devices shall be in compliance with section 74-321 et seq. 
g.  The provisions of section 74-91(e) are considered and satisfactorily met. 
h.  The regulations and conditions of the Minnesota Department of Public Welfare, Public Welfare Manual II 3130, as adopted, amended and/or changed are satisfactorily met. 
i.  A written indication of preliminary, pending or final license approval from the regulatory welfare agency is supplied to the city. 
(2)  Manufactured home parks meeting the standards of section 74-391 for each unit and 74-516. 
(Code 1982, § 15.193; Ord. No. 700, § 4, 9-16-13) 
Sec. 74-455. - Interim uses. 
    Reserved. 
(Ord. No. 700, § 4, 9-16-13) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 700, § 4, adopted September 16, 2013, created a new § 74-455 as herein set out, and renumbered the former § 74-455 as § 74-456. 
Sec. 74-456. - Lot and building requirements and setbacks. 
    The following minimum requirements shall be observed in an R-3 district, subject to additional requirements, exceptions and modifications set forth in this chapter: 
(1)  Lot area: 
a.  Interior: 13,500 square feet. 
b.  Corner: 15,000 square feet. 
(2)  Lot width: 
a.  Interior: 85 feet. 
b.  Corner: 100 feet. 
(3)  Setbacks. 
a.  Front yards: Not less than 30 feet. 
b.  Side yards: 
1.  Interior lots: Not less than fifteen on any one side. 
2.  Corner lots: Not less than fifteen feet on the interior side, nor less than 30 feet on the side yard abutting a public street right-of-way. 
c.  Rear yards: 30 feet. 
(4)  Building height: No structure in an R-3 district shall exceed three stories or 35 feet in height, whichever is least. 
(Code 1982, § 15.194; Ord. No. 700, § 4, 9-16-13; Ord. No. 731, § 4, 11-21-16) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 700, § 4, adopted September 16, 2013, repealed the former § 74-456 and renumbered the former § 74-455 as § 74-456 as set out herein. The former § 74-456 pertained to building height and derived from Code 1982, § 15.185. 
Sec. 74-457. - Garage requirement. 
    At least one enclosed garage space for each dwelling unit in an R-3 district shall be provided for all multiple-family dwelling structures. 
(Code 1982, § 15.196; Ord. No. 700, § 4, 9-16-13) 
Secs. 74-458-74-475. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 5. - R-4 SOUTHWEST AREA RESIDENTIAL DISTRICT[9] 

Footnotes: 
--- (9) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 645, § 1, adopted May 18, 2009, repealed the former Div. 5, §§ 74-476-74-481, and enacted a new Div. 5 as set out herein. The former Div. 5 pertained to R-4 medium and high density residential district and derived from §§ 15.200-15.205 of the 1982 Code. 

Sec. 74-476. - Purpose. 
    The purpose of the R-4, southwest area residential district, is to provide for a variety of residential housing types that are sensitive to the environmental features of the district, that utilize the existing lot and street pattern, that facilitate the efficient use of services and strengthen the quality of housing within the community through architectural, design and performance standards consistent with the small town character of the city. 
(Ord. No. 645, § 1, 5-18-09) 
Sec. 74-477. - Permitted uses. 
    The following are permitted uses in the R-4 district: 
(1)  A single-family detached dwelling. 
(2)  Two-family dwellings. 
(3)  Townhouses. 
(4)  Condominiums and apartments. 
(Ord. No. 645, § 1, 5-18-09) 
Sec. 74-478. - Accessory uses. 
    The following are permitted accessory uses in a R-4 southwest area residential district: 
(1)  Accessory buildings of 150 square feet or less. 
(2)  Private garages for licensed and operable passenger cars and trucks not to exceed a gross weight of 12,000 pounds, as regulated by article V (off-street parking) of this chapter. Private garages are intended for use of the family or families resident upon the premises, and in which no business is operated. 
(3)  Noncommercial greenhouses and conservatories. 
(Ord. No. 645, § 1, 5-18-09) 
Sec. 74-479. - Conditional uses. 
    The following are conditional uses in an R-4 southwest area residential district. Such uses require a conditional permit based upon procedures set forth in and regulated by section 74-91 et seq. 
(1)  Public or semipublic neighborhood or community centers, public and private educational institutions and religious institutions, provided that: 
a.  Side yards shall be double that required for the district, but shall be no greater than 30 feet. 
b.  Adequate screening from adjacent uses and landscaping is provided in compliance with section 72-222. 
c.  Adequate off-street parking and access is provided on the site or lots directly abutting a public street or alley to the principal use in compliance with article V and that such parking is adequately screened and landscaped from surrounding and abutting residential uses in compliance with section 74-222. 
d.  Adequate off-street loading and service entrances are provided and regulated where applicable by article VI. 
e.  The provisions of section 74-91(e) are considered and satisfactorily met. 
(2)  Government and public regulated utility buildings and structures necessary for the health, safety and general welfare of the community, provided that: 
a.  Equipment is completely enclosed in a permanent structure with no outside storage. 
b.  Adequate screening from adjacent uses and landscaping is provided in compliance with section 72-222. 
c.  The provisions of section 74-91(e) are considered and satisfactorily met. 
(3)  Home-based day care, provided that: 
a.  No overnight facilities are provided for the children served; children are delivered and removed daily. 
b.  Adequate off-street parking and access is provided in compliance with article V. 
c.  Adequate off-street loading and service entrances are provided and regulated where applicable by article VI. 
d.  The provisions of section 74-91(e) are considered and satisfactorily met. 
e.  The regulations and conditions of the Minnesota Department of Public Welfare, Public Welfare Manual II 3130, as adopted, amended and/or changed are satisfactorily met. 
f.  A written indication of preliminary, pending or final license approval from the regulatory welfare agency is supplied to the city. 
(4)  Development projects that exceed the construction of one single-family dwelling but that do not conform to the criteria in section 74-481. 
(Ord. No. 645, § 1, 5-18-09) 
Sec. 74-480. - Relationship to the critical area. 
    All development within the critical area is also subject to the provisions of the RD district, section 74-791 et seq. 
(Ord. No. 645, § 1, 5-18-09) 
Sec. 74-481. - Land use and development standards. 
    The following standards cannot be modified or waived except as specifically stated: 
(1)  Minimum site. The minimum size of a southwest area residential district site is three acres. 
(2)  Density. Residential developments in the R-4 district shall have an overall minimum average density of eight dwelling units per gross acre of residential land. A specific residential component within the district shall not have a density greater than 12 dwelling units per net acre. 
(3)  Housing mix. A complete range of permitted housing types, cited in section 74-477, is encouraged in the district and within any individual development, to the extent reasonably feasible, depending upon the size of the parcel. The following minimum standards are intended to promote such variety: 
a.  A minimum of two housing types shall be required on any development parcel three acres or larger, including parcels that are part of a phased development. A minimum of three housing types shall be required on and development parcel seven acres or larger. 
b.  A single housing type shall not constitute more than 60 percent of the total number of dwelling units within any individual development. 
c.  An exception to the housing mix required by section 74-481(3), subsections a. and b. is permitted, at the sole discretion of the city council, for the construction, use and maintenance of senior citizen housing developed wholly or in part by the Washington County Housing and Redevelopment Authority. 
(4)  Development standards for housing types. The following lot, setback and height requirements shall apply to the construction of permitted housing types for the R-4 district: 
STANDARD SINGLE-FAMILY AND TWO FAMILY TOWNHOUSE CONDOMINIUM AND APARTMENT Minimum lot size 5600 s.f. 6500 s.f./corner lot 4000 s.f. per unit 4000 s.f. per unit Minimum lot width 40 feet 50 feet/corner lot none none Maximum height within bluffline setback in the RD overlay district 30 feet 30 feet 30 feet Maximum height within 200 feet of the river, excluding bluffline setback in RD overlay district 30 feet 30 feet 30 feet Maximum height elsewhere in the RD overlay district and the R-4 southwest area residential district 35 feet 35 feet 35 feet Maximum front yard setback 20 feet 15 feet 15 feet Minimum front yard setback 15 feet 10 feet 10 feet Minimum street side yard setback 10 feet 10 feet 10 feet Minimum interior side yard setback 5 feet 0 feet 5 feet Minimum rear yard setback 15 feet 15 feet 15 feet Maximum building coverage 50 percent 50 percent 50 percent Maximum impervious cover 60 percent 60 percent 60 percent  
(5)  Additional standards. The following standards apply to the development of all housing types in the R-4 district: 
a.  Buildings. 
1.  Similar land uses should face across streets, and dissimilar land uses should abut at rear lot lines or across alleys. 
2.  There may be not more than eight townhouse dwelling units in a single building. 
3.  There may be not more than twelve condominium dwelling units in a single building. 
4.  A front porch or stoop is required on a single-family or two-family residential structure. Front porches and stoops, provided they are not enclosed, may intrude into the required minimum front yard setback. 
5.  Every building containing three or more dwelling units shall have at least one building entry or doorway facing the adjacent street. 
b.  Garages. Garages in the R-4 district are subject to the following guidelines: 
1.  Access to a garage from an alley is required unless otherwise approved by the city council. Garages may be located one foot from the rear lot line. 
2.  If driveway access is provided from the street the garage or carport may not face the street unless it is located a minimum of 20 feet behind the front facade of the principal structure. 
3.  Garage doors may be located on another side of dwelling (side loaded) provided that the side of the garage facing the front street has windows or other architectural details that mimic the features of the living portion of the dwelling. 
4.  Garages for townhouse and condominium developments shall not exceed 30 feet in length. A minimum of five feet of landscaping must provided between any two such garages. Doorways providing access to the rear yard from the garage shall be provided. 
c.  Roofs. Flat roofs are prohibited in the R-4 district. 
d.  Utilities. All public and private utilities, including cable television and electrical service systems, shall be installed underground. 
e.  Open space. A minimum of 25 percent of each individual development within the R-4 district shall be designated open space. Such open space is subject to the following guidelines: 
1.  Use. Open space shall be available as landscaped area, or for unstructured or passive recreation, either as private open space or private open space subject to a conservation easement to permit public use. 
2.  Ownership and maintenance. Such open space may, at the discretion of the city, be acquired by the city, through dedication or purchase, or be privately owned and maintained by the developer or property owners association. 
3.  Location. Such open space shall be formed by the pattern of streets and lots and easily observed from streets. Rear facades and rear yards of dwellings shall not abut more than two sides or more than 50 percent of the perimeter of such open space. 
4.  Accessible to pedestrians. All parts of such open space shall be safety and easily accessible by pedestrians. 
5.  Accessible to housing types. At least 75 percent of the dwellings in each development of minimum size shall be located within one-fourth mile of either private open space or private open space subject to a conservation easement to permit public use that is located either within the individual development of minimum size or within an adjacent development, which distance shall be measured along the street frontage without crossing either a collector or an arterial street. 
6.  Landscaping. Landscaping shall be provided as set forth in this section. 
7.  Improvements. Improvements may consist of walking paths, sheltered spaces, benches, picnic tables and other features for various age groups. 
f.  Pedestrian pathways. Pedestrian pathways shall be provided within the R-4 district, subject to the following guidelines: 
1.  Location. Pedestrian pathways, to the extent reasonably feasible, shall provide passage through blocks, running from street to street. They shall be located parallel to the property line adjacent to the street and shall be separated from the street by a parkway. 
2.  Minimum width. The minimum width of pedestrian pathways shall be five feet. 
g.  Landscaping. Landscaping shall be provided within the R-4 district, subject to the following guidelines: 
1.  Landscaping shall be provided on parkways, in required open space areas and all areas on a development site that are not covered by buildings, structures, paving or other impervious surface. The selection and location of landscaping elements, including trees, shall be used to prevent erosion and to meet the functional and visual purposes of defining spaces, defining circulation patterns, attracting attention to building entrances and visually integrating buildings with the landscape area and with each other. 
2.  All site plans shall include landscape plans. 
h.  Tree protection. Existing trees in the R-4 district shall be protected, in connection with an approved development plan, subject to the following guidelines: 
1.  Existing significant trees within the development site shall be preserved to the extent that is reasonably feasible. 
2.  Significant trees that are removed shall be replaced by not less than one and not more than three replacement trees sufficient to mitigate the loss of value of the removed significant tree. 
3.  Existing significant trees and replacement trees shall be noted on the required landscaping plan. 
i.  Street trees. Trees shall be planted in the center of all parkways adjacent to the development site at a minimum of 30-foot intervals. 
j.  [Minimum tree sizes.] Trees, including trees planted within the development site and as street trees, shall be of minimum size. The following minimum tree sizes shall be required: 
1.  Canopy shade tree: Two-inch caliper balled and burlapped, or equivalent. 
2.  Canopy shade tree used as a street tree: One and one-fourth-inch caliper container or equivalent. 
3.  Evergreen tree: Six-foot height balled and burlapped, or equivalent. 
4.  Shrubs: Five-gallon. 
(Ord. No. 645, § 1, 5-18-09) 
Sec. 74-482. - Submission requirements and procedures for processing an R-4 southwest area residential development. 
    All development within the R-4 southwest residential district is subject to the submission requirements and procedures of sections 74-68 and 74-69. 
(Ord. No. 645, § 1, 5-18-09) 
Secs. 74-483-74-510. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 6. - R-5 MANUFACTURED HOME PARK DISTRICT[10] 

Footnotes: 
--- (10) --- 
Editor's note- Ordinance No. 583, § 1, adopted June 2, 2003, repealed §§ 74-511-74-516 and added new sections 74-511-74-516. Formerly, such sections pertained to R-5 mobile home park district and derived from §§ 15.210-15.215 of the 1982 Code. 

Sec. 74-511. - Purpose. 
    The purpose of an R-5, manufactured home park district is to provide a separate district for manufactured home parks, distinct from other residential areas. Development in this district is not allowed without public sewer. 
(Ord. No. 583, § 1, 6-2-03) 
Sec. 74-512. - Permitted uses. 
    The following uses are permitted uses in an R-5 district: Manufactured homes. 
(Ord. No. 583, § 1, 6-2-03) 
Sec. 74-513. - Accessory uses. 
    The following are permitted accessory uses in an R-5 district: Any accessory use permitted in an R-1 district. 
(Ord. No. 583, § 1, 6-2-03) 
Sec. 74-514. - Conditional uses. 
    The following are conditional uses in an R-5 district, requiring a conditional use permit based upon the procedures set forth in and regulated by section 74-91 et seq.: All conditional uses, subject to the same conditions as allowed in an R-1 district. 
(Ord. No. 583, § 1, 6-2-03) 
Sec. 74-515. - Lot requirements and setbacks. 
    The following minimum requirements shall be observed in an R-5 district, subject to additional requirements, exceptions and modifications set forth in this chapter: 
(1)  Lot area: 6,000 square feet. 
(2)  Lot width: 50 feet. 
(3)  Lot depth: 120 feet. 
(4)  Setbacks: No unit shall be parked closer than ten feet to its side lot lines nor closer than 30 feet to its front lot line, or within ten feet of its rear lot line. 
(Ord. No. 583, § 1, 6-2-03) 
Sec. 74-516. - Development regulations. 
(a)  General provisions. The following provisions shall govern development in an R-5 district: 
(1)  All land areas shall be adequately drained, landscaped to control dust, and clean and free from refuse, garbage, rubbish and debris. 
(2)  No tents shall be used for other than recreational purposes in a manufactured home park. 
(3)  There shall be no outdoor camping anywhere in a manufactured home park. 
(4)  Access to manufactured home parks shall be as approved by the city. 
(5)  The area beneath a manufactured home shall be enclosed except that such enclosure must have access for inspection. 
(b)  Site plan requirements. Site plan requirements are as follows: 
(1)  Legal description and size in acres of the proposed manufactured home park. 
(2)  Location and size of all manufactured home sites, dead storage areas, recreation areas, laundry drying areas, roadways, parking sites, and all setback dimensions (parking spaces, exact manufactured home sites, etc.) 
(3)  Detailed landscaping plans and specifications. 
(4)  Location and width of sidewalks. 
(5)  Plans for sanitary sewage disposal, surface drainage, water systems, electrical service, and gas service. 
(6)  Location and size of all streets abutting the manufactured home park and all driveways from such streets to the manufactured home park. 
(7)  Road construction plans and specifications. 
(8)  Plans for any and all structures. 
(9)  Such other information as required or implied by this article or requested by public officials. 
(c)  Recreation. 
(1)  All manufactured home parks shall have at least ten percent of the land area developed for recreational use (tennis courts, children's play equipment, swimming pool, golf green, etc.) developed and maintained at the owner or operator's expense. 
(2)  In lieu of land dedication for public park purposes, a cash contribution shall be paid to the city, in accordance with the parkland dedication requirements as contained in the subdivision regulations of the city. 
(d)  Landscaping. 
(1)  Each manufactured home park site shall be properly landscaped with trees, hedges, grass, fences, windbreaks, and the like. 
(2)  A compact hedge, redwood fence, or landscaped area shall be installed around each manufactured home park and be maintained in first class condition at all times as approved. 
(3)  All areas shall be landscaped in accordance with landscaping plan approved by the city council. 
(e)  Lighting. 
(1)  Artificial light shall be maintained during all hours of darkness in all buildings containing public toilets, laundry equipment, and the like. 
(2)  The manufactured home park grounds shall be lighted as approved by the city from sunset to sunrise. 
(f)  Storage. Enclosed storage lockers, when provided, shall be located either adjacent to the manufactured home in a manufactured home park or at such other place in the park as to be convenient to the unit for which it is provided. Storage of large items such as boats, boat trailers, etc. shall be accommodated in a separate secured area of the park. 
(g)  Registration. 
(1)  It shall be the duty of the operator of the manufactured home park to keep a record of all manufactured home owners and occupants located within the park. The register shall contain the following information: 
a.  The name and address of each manufactured home occupant. 
b.  The name and address of the owner of each manufactured home. 
c.  The make, model, year and license number of each manufactured home. 
d.  The state, territory or county issuing such license. 
e.  The date of arrival and departure of each manufactured home. 
(2)  The manufactured home park operator shall keep the register available for inspection at all times by authorized city, state and county officials, public health officials and other public officials whose duty necessitates acquisition of the information contained in the register. The register shall not be destroyed until after a period of three years following the date of departure of the registrant from the park. 
(h)  Maintenance. The operator of any manufactured home park, or duly authorized attendant and/or caretaker, shall be responsible at all times for keeping the manufactured home park, its facilities and equipment in a clean, orderly, operable, and sanitary condition. The attendant or caretaker shall be answerable, along with such operator, for the violation of any provision of this article to which such operator is subject. 
(i)  Submittal, review of information. All informational elements in this section shall be submitted to the city in accordance with the normal time schedule outlined for zoning district amendments, whether or not the proposal requires zoning. Proposals for manufactured home park expansions on properly zoned land shall be reviewed for compliance with the applicable standards and requirements as contained in this section by all designated and official city reviewing bodies. 
(Ord. No. 583, § 1, 6-2-03) 
Secs. 74-517-74-550. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 7. - MIXED-USE ZONING FOR THE MARINA AREA 

Sec. 74-551. - Purpose. 
    The purpose of the mixed use district is to provide for areas of multiple use development that is carefully planned to promote efficient use of the land; to ensure sensitivity to resources of the critical area; to ensure sensitivity to the surrounding neighborhood; to retain open space by encouraging cluster development; to promote innovative site design; to ensure high quality architectural design and materials; to encourage reductions in impervious surfaces by minimizing surface parking; and, to provide good pedestrian and bicycle access. 
(Ord. No. 646, § 1, 5-18-09) 
Sec. 74-552. - Permitted uses through the floating zone. 
(a)  The following are permitted uses in a mixed-use district provided that a specific development contains uses from at least three of the following four categories: 
(1)  Private marina facilities, provided that: 
a.  All storage areas are fenced and screened in accordance with section 74-222. 
b.  Written approval from the state fire marshal, Federal Environmental Protection Agency, state pollution control agency, state department of natural resources, and fire marshal of the city is obtained for any on- or off-water fueling facilities. 
(2)  Business uses limited to the following: 
a.  Bakery goods and baking of goods for retail sales on the premises. 
b.  Bicycle sales and repair. 
c.  Books. 
d.  Camera and photographic supplies. 
e.  Convenience market. 
f.  Dry cleaning and laundry pickup stations. 
g.  Florist shop. 
h.  Marina sales and services. 
i.  Laundromat. 
j.  Restaurant, including delicatessen and specialty foods, but excluding fast food restaurants. 
k.  On-sale liquor in connection with the operation of a restaurant. 
(3)  Institutional uses limited to the following: 
a.  Community center. 
b.  Library. 
c.  Parks/usable open space/outdoor recreation. 
d.  Passive open space/public plazas in excess of minimum usable open space requirements. 
e.  Indoor recreation. 
(4)  Residential uses limited to the following: 
a.  Cluster housing. 
b.  Multiple-family dwellings. 
c.  Senior citizen housing. 
d.  Ordinance. 
(b)  With the exception of the marina acreage in existence prior to the effective date of this division, the principal use is defined as that having the greatest floor area on the preliminary and final site plan. In phased projects, at least 40 percent of the floor area of the approved principal use must be constructed in the first phase. 
(c)  With the exception of the marina acreage in existence prior to the effective date of this ordinance, the floor area of any one category uses shall not exceed 55 percent of the total floor area of any phase of the development. 
(Ord. No. 646, § 1, 5-18-09) 
Sec. 74-553. - Accessory uses. 
    The following are permitted accessory uses in a mixed-use district: 
(a)  Private garages for licensed and operable passenger cars and trucks not to exceed a gross weight of 12,000 pounds, as regulated by article V (off-street parking) of this chapter. Private garages are intended for the storage of private passenger vehicles of the residents upon the premises; no commercial or industrial business shall be carried on in private garages. 
(b)  Tool houses and similar buildings for the storage of domestic, non-commercial supplies and equipment, not to exceed 150 square feet. 
(c)  Nonresidential storage buildings necessary for the principal use, not to exceed five percent of the gross floor area of the building(s) of the principal use. 
(d)  Home occupations. 
(e)  Non-commercial greenhouses and conservatories. 
(f)  Off-street parking, provided that ten percent of the parking lot area is landscaped according to an approved landscape plan. 
(g)  Visitor lodging associated with senior citizen housing. 
(Ord. No. 646, § 1, 5-18-09) 
Sec. 74-554. - Conditional uses. 
    The following are conditional uses in a mixed-use district: 
(a)  Governmental and public related utility buildings and structures necessary for the health, safety and general welfare of the community provided that: 
(1)  Equipment is completely enclosed in a permanent structure with no outside storage. 
(2)  Adequate screening from adjacent uses and landscaping is provided in compliance with section 74-222. 
(3)  The provisions of section 74-91(e) are considered and satisfactorily met. 
(b)  Development projects that exceed modification of one single-family residence but that do not conform to the requirements of section 74-556. 
(Ord. No. 646, § 1, 5-18-09) 
Sec. 74-555. - Relationship to the critical area. 
    All development within the critical area is also subject to the provisions of the RD district, section 74-791 et seq. 
(Ord. No. 646, § 1, 5-18-09) 
Sec. 74-556. - Design and performance standards/general requirements. 
    The following standards and requirements for developments within the MX-1 district cannot be modified or waived except as specifically stated: 
(a)  The minimum site area is ten acres. The site may include more than one contiguous property, designed and maintained as a unit. 
(b)  At least 30 percent of the building ground coverage is concentrated in structures of a minimum height of 30 feet, thereby conserving open space within the site. Maximum height shall be regulated by the following: 
(c)  Maximum building and structure height within 100 feet of the bluffline: 30 feet. Maximum building and structure height elsewhere in the RD overlay district: 35 feet. 
(d)  The site shall include a minimum of 25 percent usable open space based on total site area. Open space shall be available for either landscaping, or unstructured or passive recreation, either as private open space or private open space subject to a conservation easement to permit public use. Such open space shall be easily observed from streets. All parts of such open space shall be safely and easily accessible by pedestrians. Landscaping shall be provided as set forth in this section. 
(e)  Building setbacks shall be regulated by the final site plan approved by the city council upon the following findings: 
(1)  The setbacks provide adequate distances from uses in adjacent districts and conform to distances from adjacent residential districts, as set forth in subsection (j). 
(2)  A yard is provided along all street frontages so that there is a consistent relationship between buildings and pedestrian access; such yard shall not be more than 15 feet in width, except as specifically modified by the final site plan. Exceptions shall be permitted at the sole discretion of the city council in order to form an outdoor space, such as plaza, courtyard or garden between the building and the sidewalk. 
(f)  Cumulative parking requirements may be reduced by up to 25 percent of required spaces at the sole discretion of the city council if one or more of the following are provided: 
(1)  Joint parking/shared parking arrangements between uses. 
(2)  Off-site employee parking and/or employee car/van pooling. 
(g)  All trash and loading areas must be interior and use screening consisting of the same exterior facing materials as the principal building. 
(h)  Truck circulation and loading areas must be separated from streets and properties adjoining the site by a buffer. 
(i)  Reserved. 
(j)  Reserved. 
(k)  Notwithstanding subsection (b), buildings are subject to the following height restrictions based on distances from adjacent residential districts and from the adjacent city-owned park: 
(1)  Within a distance equal to the minimum lot width of an adjacent residential district, the maximum height shall not exceed 30 feet. 
(2)  Adjacent to a city-owned park, the height shall not exceed 25 feet. 
(l)  At least one main entrance of any principal building shall face and open directly onto a connecting walkway with pedestrian frontage. 
(m)  Pedestrian pathways shall be provided, subject to the following guidelines: 
(1)  Pedestrian pathways, to the extent reasonably feasible, shall provide passage through blocks, running from street to street. They shall be located parallel to the property line adjacent to the street and shall be separated from the street by a parkway. 
(2)  Minimum width. The minimum width of pedestrian pathways shall be five feet. 
(n)  Signage shall be allowed in conformance with the approved final site plan and development agreement in accordance with the following conditions: 
(1)  Pylon signs are not permitted; and 
(2)  Freestanding monument signs shall use the same exterior materials as the principal building(s); and 
(3)  Maximum allowable numbers, sizes and heights shall be regulated by sections 74-321 through 74-329, except as specifically modified by the final site plan and development agreement at the sole discretion of the city council. 
(o)  The following criteria shall apply to landscaping, street trees and tree protection within each site: 
(1)  Landscaping shall be provided on parkways, in required open space areas and all areas on a development site that are not covered by buildings, structures, paving or other impervious surface. The selection and location of landscaping including trees shall be used to prevent erosion and to meet the functional and visual purposes of defining spaces, defining circulation patterns, attracting attention to building entrances and visually integrating buildings with the landscaped area and with each other. 
(2)  All site plans shall include landscape plans. 
(3)  Existing significant trees within the development site shall be preserved to the extent that is reasonably feasible. 
(4)  Significant trees that are removed shall be replaced by not less than one and not more than three replacement trees sufficient to mitigate the loss of value of the removed significant tree. 
(5)  Existing significant trees and replacement trees shall be noted on the required landscaping plan. 
(6)  Street trees shall be planted in the center of all parkways adjacent to the development site at a minimum of 30-foot intervals. 
(7)  Minimum tree size. Trees, including trees planted within the development site and as street trees, shall be of minimum size. The following minimum sizes shall be required: 
a.  Canopy shade tree: Two-inch caliper balled and burlapped, or equivalent. 
b.  Canopy shade tree used as a street tree: One and one-fourth-inch caliper container or equivalent. 
c.  Evergreen tree: Six-foot height balled and burlapped, or equivalent. 
d.  Shrubs: Five-gallon. 
(p)  The final site plan shall address at a minimum: approved site and building design criteria, approved sign locations and design criteria, construction phasing, bonding or other financial surety for construction of on- and off-site improvements generated by the development and maintenance. 
(Ord. No. 646, § 1, 5-18-09; Ord. No. 679, § 2, 3-19-12) 
Sec. 74-557. - Submission requirements and procedures for processing a floating zone development. 
    All development within the MX-1 district is subject to the submission requirements of section 74-68 and the procedural requirements of section 74-91. 
(Ord. No. 646, § 1, 5-18-09) 
Secs. 74-558-74-575. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 8. - B-1 LIMITED NEIGHBORHOOD BUSINESS DISTRICT 

Sec. 74-576. - Purpose. 
    The purpose of the B-1, limited neighborhood business district, is to provide for the establishment of local retail or service outlets. These outlets are to provide services and goods only for the surrounding neighborhoods and are not intended to draw customers from the entire community. 
(Code 1982, § 15.230; Ord. No. 569, 7-17-00) 
Sec. 74-577. - Permitted uses. 
    The following are permitted uses in a B-1 district: 
(1)  Barbershops. 
(2)  Beauty parlors. 
(3)  Essential services. 
(4)  Convenience grocery stores (not supermarket type, and not to include accessory gasoline sales). 
(5)  Laundromat, self-service washing and drying. 
(Code 1982, § 15.231) 
Sec. 74-578. - Accessory uses. 
    The following are permitted accessory uses in a B-1 district: 
(1)  Commercial or business buildings and structures for a use accessory to the principal use, but such use shall not exceed 30 percent of the gross floor space of the principal use. 
(2)  Off-street parking as regulated by article V of this chapter, but not including semitrailer trucks. 
(3)  Off-street loading as regulated by article VI of this chapter. 
(Code 1982, § 15.232) 
Sec. 74-579. - Conditional uses. 
    The following are conditional uses in a B-1 district, requiring a conditional use permit based upon the procedures set forth in and regulated by section 74-91 et seq.: 
(1)  Governmental and public regulated utility buildings and structures necessary for the health, safety and general welfare of the community, provided that: 
a.  Conformity with the surrounding neighborhood is maintained and required setbacks and side yard requirements are met. 
b.  Equipment is completely enclosed in a permanent structure with no outside storage. 
c.  Adequate screening and landscaping from neighboring residential districts is provided in accordance with section 74-222. 
d.  The provisions of section 74-91(e) are considered and satisfactorily met. 
(2)  Professional and commercial offices, provided that: 
a.  The services which are provided are for the local area rather than the community or region. 
b.  The traffic generated will not raise traffic volumes beyond the capacity of the surrounding streets. 
c.  The architectural appearance of the building housing the office use shall reflect the building character of the area and shall not be so dissimilar as to cause impairment of property values or constitute a blighting influence within the neighborhood. 
d.  The provisions of section 74-91 et seq., are considered and satisfactorily met. 
(Code 1982, § 15.233) 
Sec. 74-580. - Lot requirements and setbacks. 
    The following minimum requirements shall be observed in a B-1 district, subject to additional requirements, exceptions and modifications set forth in this chapter: 
(1)  Lot area: 9,000 square feet. 
(2)  Lot width: 75 feet. 
(3)  Setbacks: 
a.  Front yards: Not less than 30 feet. 
b.  Side yards: 
1.  Not less than 15 feet on any one side. 
2.  Corner lots abutting a major street: Not less than 15 feet on the interior side yard, nor less than 30 feet on the side yard abutting the major street. 
c.  Rear yards: 30 feet. 
(Code 1982, § 15.234) 
Sec. 74-581. - Building height. 
    No structure in a B-1 district shall exceed three stories or 35 feet in height, whichever is least. 
(Code 1982, § 15.235) 
Secs. 74-582-74-610. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 9. - B-2 RETAIL BUSINESS DISTRICT 

Sec. 74-611. - Purpose. 
    The purpose of the B-2, retail and general business district, is to provide for low intensity, retail or service commercial outlets providing goods and services for customers from the community and from the region surrounding the community. The uses allowed in this district are to be located in areas which are well served by collector or arterial street facilities at the edge of residential districts. 
(Code 1982, § 15.240; Ord. No. 569, 7-17-00) 
Sec. 74-612. - Permitted uses. 
    The following are permitted uses in a B-2 district: 
(1)  All permitted uses as allowed in the B-1, limited neighborhood business district. 
(2)  Animal clinic, excluding outdoor kennel facilities. 
(3)  Antique shop. 
(4)  Bakery goods and baking of goods for retail sales on the premises. 
(5)  Bank credit union, finance company and other financial institutions. 
(6)  Bicycle sales and repair. 
(7)  Books; office supplies; art supplies. 
(8)  Camera and photographic supplies. 
(9)  Clothing repair and alteration. 
(10)  Coin and philatelic stores. 
(11)  Commercial and professional offices. 
(12)  Copy service, but not including printing press or newspaper. 
(13)  Dry cleaning and laundry pickup stations, including incidental repair and assembly, and including accessory processing and pressing. 
(14)  Drugstore. 
(15)  Electronic merchandise, including incidental repair accessory to retail sales but not fabricating or manufacturing. 
(16)  Florist shop. 
(17)  Frozen food store, not including a locker plant. 
(18)  Fruit or vegetable store, but not including sales from moveable, motorized vehicles. 
(19)  Furrier when conducted only for retail trade on premises. 
(20)  Garden supply stores. 
(21)  General merchandise. 
(22)  Grocery, supermarket. 
(23)  Hardware. 
(24)  Household furnishings, including furniture, carpets, rugs and tile; paint and wallpaper. 
(25)  Jewelry stores and watch repairs. 
(26)  Locksmith. 
(27)  Meat market, but not including processing for a locker plant. 
(28)  Medical and dental offices and clinics. 
(29)  Public utility collection offices. 
(30)  Restaurant, including delicatessen and specialty foods. 
(31)  Sewing machine sales and service. 
(32)  Off-sale liquor stores. 
(33)  Wearing apparel and accessories, including clothing rental. 
(34)  Brewpub. 
(35)  Microdistillery with cocktail room. 
(36)  Small brewery, minor. 
(37)  Body art and tattoo establishment. 
(Code 1982, § 15.241; Ord. No. 569, 7-17-00; Ord. No. 727, § 2, 5-16-16; Ord. No. 734, § 3, 12-19-16) 
Sec. 74-613. - Accessory uses. 
    The following are permitted accessory uses in a B-2 district: All permitted accessory uses as allowed in a B-1 district. 
(Code 1982, § 15.242) 
Sec. 74-614. - Conditional uses. 
    The following are conditional uses in a B-2 district, requiring a conditional use permit based upon the procedures set forth in and regulated by section 74-91 et seq.: 
(1)  Governmental and public regulated utility buildings and structures necessary for the health, safety and general welfare of the community, provided that: 
a.  Conformity with the surrounding neighborhood is maintained and required setbacks and side yard requirements are met. 
b.  Adequate screening from neighboring uses and landscaping is provided in accordance with section 74-222. 
c.  The provisions of section 74-91(e) are considered and satisfactorily met. 
(2)  Commercial planned unit development as regulated by section 74-66 et seq. 
(3)  Open and outdoor storage as an accessory use, provided that: 
a.  The area is fenced and screened from view of neighboring residential uses or if abutting a residential district in compliance with section 74-222. 
b.  Storage is screened from view from public right-of-way in compliance with section 74-222. 
c.  Storage area is grassed or surfaced to control dust. 
d.  All lighting shall be hooded and so directed that the light source shall not be visible from the public right-of-way or from neighboring residences and shall be in compliance with section 74-224. 
e.  The provisions of section 74-91(e) are considered and satisfactorily met. 
(4)  Open or outdoor service, sale and rental as an accessory use, provided that: 
a.  Outside service, sales and equipment rental connected with the principal use is limited to 30 percent of the gross floor area of the principal use. 
b.  Outside sales areas fenced or screened from view of neighboring residential uses or an abutting residential district in compliance with section 74-222. 
c.  All lighting shall be hooded and so directed that the light source shall not be visible from the public right-of-way or from neighboring residences and shall be in compliance with section 74-224. 
d.  Sales area is grassed or surfaced to control dust. 
e.  The provisions of section 74-91(e) are considered and satisfactorily met. 
(5)  Small Brewery, provided that: 
a.  The brewery facility provides adequate space for off-street loading. 
b.  Loading docks shall be located and designed to not be visible from adjacent public streets and residential areas. 
c.  Outdoor storage is not permitted. 
d.  The building design shall be compatible with other retail commercial buildings. 
(Code 1982, § 15.243; Ord. No. 569, 7-17-00; Ord. No. 727, § 3, 5-16-16) 
Sec. 74-615. - Lot requirements and setbacks. 
    The following requirements shall be observed in a B-2 district, subject to additional requirements, exceptions and modifications set forth in this chapter: 
(1)  Lot area: None. 
(2)  Lot width: Minimum of 50 feet. 
(3)  Setbacks: None. 
(Code 1982, § 15.244; Ord. No. 569, 7-17-00) 
Sec. 74-616. - Building height. 
    No structure in a B-2 district shall exceed three stories or 35 feet in height, whichever is least. 
(Code 1982, § 15.245) 
Secs. 74-617-74-640. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 10. - B-3 AUTO-ORIENTED BUSINESS DISTRICT 

Sec. 74-641. - Purpose. 
    The purpose of the B-3 highway oriented business district is to provide for the establishment of relatively high intensity highway oriented or dependent commercial outlets providing goods and services for customers from the region. The uses allowed in this district are those that are well served by nearby arterial highways. 
(Code 1982, § 15.250; Ord. No. 569, 7-17-00) 
Sec. 74-642. - Permitted uses. 
    The following are permitted uses in a B-3 district, provided that the construction, use and operation are consistent with the criteria in sections 74-66-through 74-69 and, additionally, the criteria in section 74-647: 
(1)  All permitted uses as allowed in the B-2, retail and general business district. 
(2)  Auto accessories. 
(3)  Car washes. 
(4)  Commercial recreational uses. 
(5)  Department and discount stores. 
(6)  Convenience markets. 
(7)  Motor vehicle gas stations with accessory auto repair. 
(8)  Motor vehicle and recreational vehicle sales, including accessory garages. 
(9)  Motels, motor hotels and hotels. 
(10)  Restaurants, coffee shops and drive-in restaurants. 
(11)  On-sale and off-sale liquor. 
(12)  Private social and fraternal organizations serving food and beverage. 
(13)  Brewpub. 
(14)  Microdistillery with cocktail room. 
(15)  Small brewery, minor. 
(Code 1982, § 15.251; Ord. No. 569, 7-17-00; Ord. No. 727, § 4, 5-16-16) 
Sec. 74-643. - Accessory uses. 
    The following are permitted accessory uses in a B-3 district: 
(1)  All permitted accessory uses as allowed in a B-2 retail business district. 
(Code 1982, § 15.252; Ord. No. 569, 7-17-00) 
Sec. 74-644. - Conditional uses. 
    The following are conditional uses in a B-3 district, requiring a conditional use permit based upon the procedures set forth in and regulated by section 74-91 et seq.: 
(1)  Reserved. 
(2)  Open or outdoor service, sale and rental as an accessory use, provided that: 
a.  Outside services, sales and equipment rental is limited to 30 percent of the gross floor area of the principal use. 
b.  Outside sales areas are fenced or screened from view of neighboring residential uses or an abutting R district in compliance with section 74-222. 
c.  All lighting shall be hooded and so directed that the light source shall not be visible from the public right-of-way or from neighboring residences and shall be in compliance with section 74-224. 
d.  Sales area is grassed or surfaced to control dust in a manner approved by the city engineer. 
e.  Does not take up parking spaces as required for conformity to this chapter. 
f.  The provisions of section 74-91(e) are considered and satisfactorily met. 
(3)  Accessory, enclosed retail, rental or service activity other than that allowed as a permitted use or conditional use within this section, provided that: 
a.  Such use is allowed as a permitted use in a B-1 or B-2 district. 
b.  Such use does not constitute more than 30 percent of the lot area and not more than 50 percent of the gross floor area of the principal use. 
c.  Adequate off-street parking and off-street loading in compliance with the requirements of articles V and VI of this chapter is provided. 
d.  All signing and informational or visual communication devices shall be in compliance with section 74-321 et seq. 
e.  The provisions of section 74-91(e) are considered and satisfactorily met. 
(4)  Commercial planned unit development as regulated by section 74-66 et seq. 
(5)  Buildings in excess of three stories, provided that: 
a.  The site is capable of accommodating the increased intensity of use. 
b.  The increased intensity of use does not cause an increase in traffic volumes beyond the capacity of the surrounding streets. 
c.  Public utilities and services are adequate. 
d.  For each additional story over three stories or for each additional ten feet above 40 feet, front and side yard setback requirements shall be increased by five feet. 
e.  The provisions of section 74-91(e) are considered and satisfactorily met. 
(6)  Small brewery, provided that: 
a.  The brewery facility provides adequate space for off-street loading. 
b.  Loading docks shall be located and designed to not be visible from adjacent public streets and residential areas. 
c.  Outdoor storage is not permitted. 
d.  The building design shall be compatible with other retail commercial buildings. 
(Code 1982, § 15.253; Ord. No. 548, § 1, 11-4-96; Ord. No. 569, 7-17-00; Ord. No. 680, §§ 1, 2, 3-19-12; Ord. No. 727, § 5, 5-16-16) 
Sec. 74-645. - Design and performance standards. 
    Notwithstanding the provisions of sections 74-66 through 74-69, the following standards and requirements cannot be modified or waived except as specifically stated: 
(1)  The minimum PUD site area is one acre. The PUD may include more than one contiguous property, designed and maintained as a unit. 
(2)  At least 30 percent of the building ground coverage is concentrated in structures of three stories in height, thereby conserving open space within the PUD site. 
(3)  The PUD site shall include a minimum of 15 percent usable open space based on total PUD land area. 
(4)  Building setbacks shall be regulated by the final PUD site plan and development agreement approved by the city council upon the following findings: 
a.  The setbacks provide adequate distances from uses in adjacent districts and conform to distances from adjacent residential districts, as set forth in subsection (12). 
(5)  An adequate yard is provided along all street frontages; such yard shall not be less than 15 feet in width, except as specifically modified by the final PUD site plan at the sole discretion of the city council. 
(6)  Cumulative parking requirements may be reduced by up to 25 percent of required spaces at the sole discretion of the city council if one or more of the following are provided: 
a.  Joint parking/shared parking arrangements between uses. 
b.  Off-site employee parking, employee car/van pooling, and/or provision for employee transit passes. 
(7)  Drive-in commercial uses must also comply with the following conditions: 
a.  Drive through facilities and stacking areas shall not be located adjacent to any residential district or any residential use within the PUD. 
b.  A buffer shall be provided between drive-through facilities and stacking areas and adjacent streets and properties. 
c.  Stacking shall be provided for a minimum of six cars for each customer service point. 
d.  Stacking shall be prohibited on public streets, in fire lanes and in areas that interfere with on-site vehicular and pedestrian circulation. 
(8)  All trash and loading areas must be interior and use screening consisting of the same exterior facing materials as the principal building. 
(9)  Truck circulation and loading areas must be separated from streets and properties adjoining the PUD site by a buffer. 
(10)  Reserved. 
(11)  Reserved. 
(12)  Buildings are subject to the following height restrictions based on distances from adjacent residential districts: 
Within a distance equal to the minimum lot width of an adjacent residential district, the maximum height shall not exceed the height allowed in the adjacent residential district. 
(13)  Signage shall be allowed in conformance with the approved final PUD site plan and development agreement in accordance with the following conditions: 
a.  Pylon signs are not permitted; 
b.  Freestanding monument signs shall use the same exterior materials as the principal building(s); and 
c.  Maximum allowable numbers, sizes and heights shall be regulated by sections 74-321 through 74-329, except as specifically modified by the final PUD site plan and development agreement at the sole discretion of the city council. 
(14)  The following criteria shall apply to landscaping, street trees and tree protection within each site: 
a.  Landscaping shall be provided in required open space areas and all areas on a development site that are not covered by buildings, structures, paving or other impervious surface. The selection and location of landscaping elements, including trees, shall be used to prevent erosion and to meet the functional and visual purposes of defining spaces, defining circulation patterns, attracting attention to building entrances and visually integrating buildings with the landscaped area and with each other. 
b.  All site plans shall include landscape plans. 
c.  Existing significant trees within the development site shall be preserved to the extent that is reasonably feasible. 
d.  Significant trees that are removed shall be replaced by not less than one and not more than three replacement trees sufficient to mitigate the loss of value of the removed significant tree. 
e.  Existing significant trees and replacement trees shall be noted on the required landscaping plan. 
f.  Street trees shall be planted in the center of all parkways adjacent to the development site at a minimum of 30-foot intervals. 
g.  Minimum tree size. Trees, including trees planted within the development site and as street trees, shall be of minimum size. The following minimum sizes shall be required: 
1.  Canopy shade tree - 2.0 inch caliper balled and burlapped, or equivalent. 
2.  Canopy shade tree used as a street tree - 1.25 inch caliper container or equivalent. 
3.  Evergreen tree - 6.0 foot height balled and burlapped, or equivalent. 
4.  Shrubs - Five gallons. 
(15)  At least one main entrance of any principal building shall face and open directly onto a connecting walkway with pedestrian frontage. 
(16)  Pedestrian pathways shall be provided between buildings within the PUD site and to appropriate and reasonable entrances to the PUD site. The minimum width of pedestrian pathways shall be five feet. 
(17)  A development agreement is required as part of the final PUD approval and shall address at a minimum: approved site and building design criteria, approved sign locations and design criteria, construction phasing, bonding or other financial surety for construction of on- and off-site improvements generated by the development and maintenance. 
(Ord. No. 569, 7-17-00; Ord No. 679, § 3, 3-19-12; Ord. No. 680, § 3, 3-19-12) 
Editor's note- Ordinance No. 569, adopted July 17, 2000, deleted and added a new § 74-645. Formerly, such section pertained to lot requirements and setbacks and derived from § 15.254 of the 1982 Code. 
Secs. 74-646-74-670. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ordinance No. 569, adopted July 17, 2000, deleted § 74-646 in its entirety. Formerly, such section pertained to building height and derived from § 15.255 of the 1982 Code. 
DIVISION 11. - RESERVED[11] 

Footnotes: 
--- (11) --- 
Editor's note- Ordinance No. 569, adopted July 17, 2000, deleted §§ 74-671-676. Formerly, such sections pertained to B-4 General Business District and derived from §§ 15.260-15.265 of the 1982 Code. 

Secs. 74-671-74-700. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 12. - RESERVED[12] 

Footnotes: 
--- (12) --- 
Editor's note- Ordinance No. 569, adopted July 17, 2000, deleted §§ 74-701-706. Formerly, such sections pertained to B-W Business Warehousing District and derived from §§ 15.270-15.275 of the 1982 Code. 

Secs. 74-701-74-730. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 13. - I-1 LIMITED INDUSTRIAL DISTRICT 

Sec. 74-731. - Purpose. 
    The purpose of the I-I limited industrial district is to provide for the establishment of wholesale commercial business, warehousing and light industry manufacturing and processing. The overall character of the I-i district is intended to be transitional in nature, with permitted uses limited to those which can compatibly exist adjacent to lower intensity business uses. 
(Code 1982, § 15.280; Ord. No. 569, 7-17-00) 
Sec. 74-732. - Permitted uses. 
    The following are permitted uses in an I-1 district: 
(1)  Radio and television station. 
(2)  Trade school. 
(3)  Warehouse. 
(4)  Laboratories, including research, medical, dental and optical. 
(5)  Governmental and public utility buildings and structures. 
(6)  Commercial printing establishments. 
(7)  Wholesale business. 
(8)  Private clubs for sporting activities. 
(9)  Commercial offices. 
(10)  Veterinary clinic. 
(11)  Hospitals and clinics. 
(12)  Brewery. 
(13)  Distillery. 
(Code 1982, § 15.281; Ord. No. 569, 7-17-00; Ord. No. 680, §§ 4-6, 3-19-12; Ord. No. 696, § 1, 5-20-13; Ord. No. 727, § 6, 5-16-16) 
Sec. 74-733. - Accessory uses. 
    The following are permitted accessory uses in an I-1 district: All permitted accessory uses as allowed in the B-1 district. 
(Code 1982, § 15.282) 
Sec. 74-734. - Conditional uses. 
    The following are conditional uses in an I-1 district: 
(1)  Cartage and express facilities. 
(2)  Light manufacturing. 
(3)  Building materials sales. 
(4)  Garden centers and nurseries. 
(5)  Transportation terminals. 
(6)  Enclosed storage facilities limited to residential type storage. 
(7)  Funeral homes and mortuaries. 
(8)  Automobile service and repair. 
(9)  Machine shops. 
(10)  Service business, off-site. 
(11)  Processing or assembly. 
(12)  Private utility buildings or structures. 
(13)  Industrial planned unit developments with meeting the following minimum standards: 
a.  The minimum PUD site area is one acre. The PUD may include more than one contiguous property, designed and maintained as a unit. 
b.  The PUD site shall include a minimum of ten percent usable open space based on total PUD land area. 
c.  Building setbacks shall be regulated by the final PUD site plan and a development agreement approved by the city council upon the following findings: 
The setbacks provide adequate distances from uses in adjacent districts and conform to distances from adjacent residential districts, as set forth in subsection (h). 
d.  An adequate yard is provided along all street frontages: such yard shall not be less than 15 feet in width, except as specifically modified by the final PUD site plan at the sole discretion of the city council. 
e.  Cumulative parking requirements may be reduced by up to 25 percent of required spaces at the sole discretion of the city council if one or both of the following are provided: 
Employee car/van pooling, and/or provision for employee transit passes. 
f.  All trash and loading areas must be interior to the building and must use screening consisting of the same exterior facing materials as the principal building. 
g.  Truck circulation and loading areas must be separated from streets and properties adjoining the PUD site by a buffer. 
h.  Buildings are subject to the following height restrictions based on distances from adjacent residential districts: 
Within a distance equal to the minimum lot width of an adjacent residential district, the maximum height shall not exceed the height allowed in the adjacent residential district. 
i.  Signage shall be allowed in conformance with the approved final PUD site plan and development agreement in accordance with the following conditions: 
1.  Pylon signs are not permitted; 
2.  Freestanding monument signs shall use the same exterior materials as the principal building(s); and 
3.  Maximum allowable numbers, sizes and heights shall be regulated by sections 74-321 through 74-330, except as specifically modified by the final PUD site plan and development agreement at the sole discretion of the city council. 
j.  The following criteria shall apply to landscaping, street trees and tree protection within each site: 
1.  Landscaping shall be provided in required open space areas and all areas on a development site that are not covered by buildings, structures, paving or other impervious surface. The selection and location of landscaping elements, including trees, shall be used to prevent erosion and to meet the functional and visual purposes of defining spaces, defining circulation patterns, attracting attention to building entrances and visually integrating buildings with the landscaped area and with each other. 
2.  All site plans shall include landscape plans. 
3.  Existing significant trees within the development site shall be preserved to the extent that is reasonably feasible. 
4.  Significant trees that are removed shall be replaced by not less than one and not more than three replacement trees sufficient to mitigate the loss of value of the removed significant tree. 
5.  Existing significant trees and replacement trees shall be noted on the required landscaping plan. Street trees shall be planted in the center of all parkways adjacent to the development. 
k.  A development agreement is required as part of the final PUD approval and shall address at a minimum: approved site and building design criteria, approved sign locations and design criteria, construction phasing, bonding or other financial surety for construction of on- and off-site improvements generated by the development and maintenance. 
(14)  Taproom accessory to a brewery. 
(15)  Cocktail room accessory to a microdistillery. 
(Ord. No. 569, 7-17-00; Ord. No. 679, § 4, 3-19-12; Ord. No. 680, § 7, 3-19-12; Ord. No. 696, § 2, 5-20-13; Ord. No. 727, § 7, 5-16-16) 
Sec. 74-735. - Lot requirements, setbacks, and building height. 
(a)  Minimum lot size: 20,000 square feet. 
(b)  Minimum lot width: 100 feet 
(c)  Front yard and/or right-of-way setback: 30 feet 
(d)  Side yard setback: 10 feet, 30 to residential districts. 
(e)  Rear yard setback: 30 feet. 
(f)  Maximum building height: 35 feet. 
(Ord. No. 696, § 3, 5-20-13) 
Secs. 74-736-74-780. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ordinance No. 569, adopted July 17, 2000, deleted § 74-736 in its entirety. Formerly, such section pertained to lot requirements and setbacks. See the Code Comparative Table for complete derivation. 
DIVISION 14. - I-2 GENERAL INDUSTRIAL DISTRICT 

Sec. 74-761. - Purpose. 
    The purpose of the I-2, general industrial district is to provide for the establishment of heavy industrial and manufacturing development and use which because of the nature of the product or character of activity requires isolation from residential or commercial use. 
(Code 1982, § 15.290) 
Sec. 74-762. - Application of performance requirements. 
    All uses provided for under the I-2 district shall show proof of ability to comply with the performance requirements of this chapter prior to issuance of any construction permit. 
(Code 1982, § 15.291) 
Sec. 74-763. - Permitted uses. 
    The following are permitted uses in an I-2 district: 
(1)  Any use permitted in the I-1, limited industrial district. 
(2)  The manufacturing, compounding, assembly, packaging, treatment, or storage of products and materials. 
(3)  Automobile major repair. 
(Code 1982, § 15.292) 
Sec. 74-764. - Accessory uses. 
    The following are permitted accessory uses in an I-2 district: All permitted accessory uses allowed in an I-1, limited industrial district. 
(Code 1982, § 15.293) 
Sec. 74-765. - Conditional uses. 
    The following are conditional uses in an I-2 district, requiring a conditional use permit based upon the procedures set forth in and regulated by section 74-91 et seq.: 
(1)  All conditional uses allowed in an I-1, limited industrial district. 
(2)  Reserved. 
(3)  Incineration or reduction of waste material other than customarily incidental to a principal use (recycling center). 
(4)  Reserved. 
(5)  Crude oil, gasoline, or other liquid storage tanks. 
(6)  Truck sales, accessory, provided: 
a.  The use is accessory to a permitted cartage facility. 
b.  The site is surfaced to control dust and drainage in the opinion of the city engineer. 
c.  A 30-foot drive aisle is maintained through the site. 
d.  Trucks for sale are restricted to a display area 30 feet by 200 feet or less. 
e.  The display area shall be at least five feet from the right-of-way. 
f.  Off-street parking shall be provided. 
(Code 1982, § 15.294; Ord. No. 661, § 1, 8-16-10; Ord. No. 680, §§ 8, 9, 3-19-12) 
Sec. 74-766. - Lot requirements and setbacks. 
    The following minimum requirements shall be observed in an I-2 district, subject to additional requirements, exceptions and modifications set forth in this chapter: 
(1)  Lot area: One acre. 
(2)  Lot width: 150 feet. 
(3)  Setbacks: 
a.  Front yards: Not less than 40 feet. 
b.  Side yards: 
1.  Not less than 20 feet on any one side. 
2.  Corner lots abutting a major street: Not less than 20 feet on the interior side yard, nor less than 40 feet on the side yard abutting the major street. 
3.  Side yards abutting residentially zoned property: Not less than 40 feet on the side yard abutting the residentially zoned property, nor less than 20 feet on the other side yard. 
c.  Rear yards: 30 feet. 
(Code 1982, § 15.295) 
Sec. 74-767. - Building height. 
    No structure in an I-2 district shall exceed four stories or 45 feet in height, whichever is least. 
(Code 1982, § 15.296) 
Sec. 74-768. - Interim uses. 
    The following are interim uses in an I-2 district, requiring an interim use permit based upon the procedures set forth in and regulated by section 74-94 et seq.: 
(1)  Temporary offices. Temporary office facilities (not including construction trailers associated with an approved project) may be placed on a site due to unique employee training periods, office overcrowding, and other similar office shortage situations; or due to a natural disaster provided the following conditions are met: 
a.  The structure shall be removed from the site within 18 months. 
b.  No more than one temporary office structure shall be on site at any given time. 
c.  The office use shall be accessory to a permitted use on the site. 
d.  Such temporary structure shall not be permitted to encroach on the required setbacks. 
e.  The applicant shall demonstrate adequate parking and sanitary facilities. 
(Ord. No. 687, § 1, 10-15-12) 
Secs. 74-769-74-790. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 15. - RD RIVER DEVELOPMENT DISTRICT[13] 

Footnotes: 
--- (13) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 647, § 2, adopted May 18, 2009, repealed the former Div. 15, §§ 74-791-74-799, and enacted a new Div. 15 as set out herein. The former Div. 15 pertained to similar subject matter and derived from §§ 15.300-15.308 of the 1982 Code. 

Sec. 74-791. - Purpose. 
    This article provides for the following with respect to all lands within the MNRRA/Critical Areas corridor as shown in the comprehensive plan: 
(a)  To protect and preserve a unique and valuable state and regional resource for the benefit of the health, safety, and welfare of citizens for the state, region and nation; 
(b)  To prevent and mitigate irreversible damage; 
(c)  To preserve, enhance and interpret its natural, aesthetic, cultural, archeological, ethnographic and historical resources for public use; 
(d)  To protect and preserve the river as an essential element in transportation, sewer, water and recreational systems; 
(e)  To provide for continued economic activity and development; 
(f)  To enhance opportunities for outdoor recreation, education and scenic enjoyment; 
(g)  To protect and preserve the biological and ecological functions of the corridor. 
(Ord. No. 647, § 2, 5-18-09) 
Sec. 74-792. - Boundaries. 
    The boundaries of the RD, river development district are consistent with the development zones as established under the critical areas act and as shown in the comprehensive plan for the city. The regulations and requirements imposed by the RD, river development district shall be in addition to those established for districts which jointly apply. Under the joint application of districts, the more restrictive shall apply. 
(Ord. No. 647, § 2, 5-18-09; Ord. No. 702, § 1, 10-21-13) 
Sec. 74-793. - Subdistricts. 
    The area within the RD, river development district is further divided into three subdistricts as defined by the MNRRA/critical areas regulations. The Urban Diversified subdistrict includes lands and waters from the northern boundary of the city to the centerline of Eighth Avenue. The urban developed subdistrict includes lands and waters from the centerline of Eighth Avenue to the the centerline of 14 th Avenue west of the centerline of 1 st Street and 15 th Avenue east of the centerline of 1 st Street. The remaining area south of the southerly border of the urban developed subdistrict lies within the rural open space district. 
(a)  Lands and waters within the urban diversified subdistrict shall be used and developed to maintain the present diversity of commercial, industrial, residential, and public uses of the lands, including the existing transportation use of the river; to protect historical sites and areas, natural scenic and environmental resources; and to expand public access to and enjoyment of the river. New uses may be permitted if they are compatible with these goals. 
(b)  Lands and waters within the urban developed subdistrict shall be maintained largely as residential areas. The expansion of existing and development of new nonresidential or nonrecreational uses shall be limited to preserve and enhance residential character of this subdistrict. 
(c)  Lands and waters within the rural open space subdistrict shall be used and developed to preserve their open, scenic and natural characteristics and ecological and economic functions. Presently undeveloped islands shall be maintained in their existing natural state. The transportation function of the river shall be maintained and preserved. 
(Ord. No. 647, § 2, 5-18-09; Ord. No. 702, § 1, 10-21-13) 
Sec. 74-794. - Requirements for submission and approvals. 
(a)  Landowners or developers proposing to develop land or to construct or enlarge any building or structure within the RD, river development district, shall first submit to the city a permit application and site plan, except for the following: 
(1)  No site plan shall be required for the modification of an existing single family dwelling. 
(2)  No site plan shall be required for the construction of one single family dwelling. 
(b)  The application, accompany site plan and materials, and the applicable public hearing notice for zoning ordinance amendments and discretionary actions affecting land within the MNRRA/critical area corridor boundaries, as described in section 74-792, shall be submitted to the state department of natural resources, at least 30 days prior to the public hearing to consider such actions. Discretionary actions include the following: 
(1)  A floating zone application as regulated by section 74-551 et seq., for river corridor lands where the applicable zoning is for mixed-use; 
(2)  A planned unit development application as regulated by section 74-66 et seq. for river corridor lands where the applicable zoning is residential or industrial; 
(3)  A conditional use permit application as regulated by section 74-91 et seq. 
(4)  A variance application as regulated by section 74-121. 
    Ordinance amendments and PUDs shall become effective only upon approval by the department of natural resources. The state department of natural resources shall be notified within ten days of final action on ordinance amendments and discretionary actions. 
(c)  Site plan requirements. 
(1)  Site plans shall include a detailed description of the proposed project; the detailed description shall include, but not be limited to, structure location on the site, setbacks, topography, buffering, landscaping and revegetation. Such descriptions shall include both written and visual representations of the anticipated physical changes to the site and consistency with the city code. 
(2)  Site plans shall include an impact plan, which shall describe proposed changes to the environment, topography, soil and vegetation as a result of the development and shall describe measures to address adverse environmental impacts and mitigate proposed changes. 
(3)  Site plans shall include standards to ensure that structures, roads, screening, landscaping, construction placement, maintenance, and storm water runoff, and their impacts are compatible with the character and use of the river corridor in the subdistricts described in section 74-793. 
(4)  Whenever possible, site plans shall include the establishment of open space and public viewing access of the river. 
(5)  Site plans shall contain specific designs for buffering, landscaping and revegetation. 
(6)  New development and expansion of existing development that requires a site plan shall be permitted only after the approval of site plans that adequately assess and minimize adverse environmental effects and maximize beneficial environmental effects. 
(d)  Subdivisions. No land shall be subdivided which is determined by the city or the department of natural resources to be unsuitable by reason of flooding, inadequate drainage, soil and rock formations with severe limitations for development, severe erosion potential, unfavorable topography, inadequate water supply or sewage treatment facilities or any other features likely to be harmful to the health, safety or welfare of the future residents of the proposed subdivisions. 
(e)  Planned unit developments. The DNR shall be included in all pre-application conferences described in section 74-69(a) and shall be provided opportunity to comment on all concept plans as described in section 74-69 (b) for lands within the river district. Concept plans shall be provided to the DNR no less than 30 days prior to final action. 
(Ord. No. 647, § 2, 5-18-09; Ord. No. 702, § 1, 10-21-13) 
Sec. 74-795. - Development and performance requirements. 
    The following are standards for development within the RD river development district: 
(a)  Minimum lot and setback requirements. 
(1)  Generally. Minimum requirements relative to lot size, lot width and setbacks of buildings from lot lines shall be governed by the provisions of the applicable zoning.
